{{No footnotes|date=May 2015}} The '''2015 America East Men's Lacrosse Tournament''' was the 16th edition of the [[America East Conference Men's Lacrosse Tournament]] and took place from April 30 to May 2 that year at [[John Fallon Field]] in [[Albany, New York]], United States. The winner of the tournament received the [[America East Conference]]'s [[automatic bid]] to the [[2015 NCAA Division I Men's Lacrosse Championship]]. Four teams from the [[America East]] conference will compete in the single elimination tournament. The seeds were based upon the teams regular season conference record. ==Standings== Only the top four teams in the America East conference advanced to the America East Conference Tournament. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" !Seed !School !Conference !Overall !Tiebreakers |- |1 |align=left|[[Albany Great Danes men's lacrosse|Albany]]‡* |6-0 ||16–2 | |- |2 |align=left|[[Stony Brook Seawolves men's lacrosse|Stony Brooks]]* |5–1 ||13–5 | |- |3 |align=left|[[Vermont Catamounts men's lacrosse|Vermont]]* |4–2 ||6–10 | |- |4 |align=left|[[Hartford Hawks men's lacrosse|Hartford]]* |3–3 ||7–8 | |- |5 |align=left|[[Binghamton Bearcats men's lacrosse|Binghamton]] |2-4 ||4-9 | |- |6 |align=left|[[UMBC Retrievers men's lacrosse|UMBC]] |1–5 ||5-8 | |- |7 |align=left|[[UMass Lowell River Hawks men's lacrosse|UMass Lowell]] |0–6 ||1-13 | |- | colspan=8 align=left|‡ America East regular season champions.
* Qualify for the tournament.
|} ==Schedule== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%" !Session !Game !Time* !Matchup# !Score !Television |- !colspan=6| Semi-finals – Thursday, April 30 |- |rowspan=2 align=center|1 |align=center|1 |align=right|4:30 pm |align=center|#2 '''Stony Brook''' vs. #3 Vermont |align=center|16-13 |rowspan=2 align=center|AETV |- |align=center|2 |align=right|7:00 pm |align=center|#1 '''Albany''' vs. #4 Hartford |align=center|15-6 |- !colspan=6| Championship – Saturday, May 2 |- |rowspan=1 align=center|2 |align=center|3 |align=right|10:00am |align=center| #1 '''Albany''' vs. #2 Stony Brook |align=center| 22-9 |rowspan=1 align=center|ESPN U |- |colspan=6| *Game times in [[Eastern Time Zone|EST]]. #-Rankings denote tournament seeding. |} ==Bracket== '''John Fallon Field - Albany, New York''' {{4TeamBracket | RD1=Semifinals
April 30 | RD2=Championship Game
May 2 | score-width=25 | team-width=130 | RD1-seed1=1 | RD1-team1='''[[Albany Great Danes men's lacrosse|Albany]]''' | RD1-score1='''15''' | RD1-seed2=4 | RD1-team2=[[Hartford Hawks men's lacrosse|Hartford]] | RD1-score2=6 | RD1-seed3=2 | RD1-team3='''[[Stony Brook Seawolves men's lacrosse|Stony Brooks]]''' | RD1-score3='''16''' | RD1-seed4=3 | RD1-team4=[[Vermont Catamounts men's lacrosse|Vermont]] | RD1-score4=13 | RD2-seed1=1 | RD2-team1='''[[Albany Great Danes men's lacrosse|Albany]]''' | RD2-score1='''22''' | RD2-seed2=2 | RD2-team2=[[Stony Brook Seawolves men's lacrosse|Stony Brooks]] | RD2-score2=9 }} * denotes an overtime game ==External links== *[http://www.americaeast.com/standings/Standings.dbml?&SPSID=59672&SPID=6539&DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=14000 Americaeast.com] *[http://www.americaeast.com/SportSelect.dbml?&&DB_OEM_ID=14000&SPID=6539&SPSID=65879 Americaeast.com] *[http://www.americaeast.com/mediaPortal/player.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=14000 Americaeast.com] [[Category:2015 NCAA Division I men's lacrosse season|America East]] [[Category:2015 in sports in New York (state)|America East Men's Lacrosse]] [[Category:America East Conference men's lacrosse]] {{sport-event-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Alexander Nix | image = Web Summit 2017 - Centre Stage Day 3 SAM 7378 (38286774551) (cropped).jpg | image_size = | caption = Alexander Nix at [[Web Summit]] 2017 in Lisbon | birth_name = Alexander James Ashburner Nix | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1975|5|1}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | residence = | nationality = United Kingdom | education = [[Eton College]] | alma mater = [[University of Manchester]] | occupation = Director (formerly), Emerdata
Director (formerly), [[SCL Group]]
CEO (formerly), [[Cambridge Analytica]] (formerly) | salary = | networth = | predecessor = | boards = | spouse = [[Olympia Paus]] (shipping heiress) }} '''Alexander James Ashburner Nix''' (born 1 May 1975) is the former CEO of [[Cambridge Analytica]]{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/11/06/cambridge-analytica-ceo-talks-to-techcrunch-about-trump-hilary-and-the-future/|title=Cambridge Analytica CEO talks to TechCrunch about Trump, Hillary and the future|last1=Butcher|first1=Mike|website=Techcrunch|publisher=[[Oath Tech Network]]|accessdate=19 March 2018|ref=2}} and a former director of the [[SCL Group|Strategic Communication Laboratories (SCL) Group]],{{cite web|url=https://companycheck.co.uk/company/05514098/SCL-GROUP-LIMITED/companies-house-data|title=SCL GROUP LIMITED Companies House data|website=Company Check|accessdate=21 March 2018}} a behavioural research and strategic communications consultancy, leading its elections division (SCL Elections). Cambridge Analytica helped [[Leave.EU]] with its [[Brexit]] campaign, according to both Leave.EU and Cambridge Analytica staff. The company was also engaged by the [[Ted Cruz]] and [[Donald Trump]] campaigns during the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 US presidential election]]. Both in the UK and the US campaigns, Cambridge Analytica used private information from over 87 million [[Facebook]] users harvested from their profiles without permission.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/apr/17/facebook-users-data-compromised-far-more-than-87m-mps-told-cambridge-analytica|title=Far more than 87m Facebook users had data compromised, MPs told|last=Hern|first=Alex|date=16 April 2018|website=the Guardian|access-date=23 November 2018}} On 20 March 2018, Nix was suspended from Cambridge Analytica after undercover video footage showed him claiming his company was using [[honey trapping|honey traps]], bribery [[Sting operation|stings]], and prostitutes, among other tactics, to influence more than 200 elections globally for his clients.{{cite web|url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/92390/cambridge-analytica-ceo-admits-to-dirty-tricks|title=Cambridge Analytica CEO 'admits to dirty tricks'|work=The Week |date=20 March 2018|accessdate=20 March 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180320111330/http://www.theweek.co.uk/92390/cambridge-analytica-ceo-admits-to-dirty-tricks|archivedate=20 March 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-43480048|title=Cambridge Analytica: Facebook row firm boss suspended|date=20 March 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=20 March 2018|dead-url=}}{{cite web|last1=Gilbert|first1=David|title=Cambridge Analytica Bragged About Using Fake News, Bribes, And Ukranian Hookers to Influence Elections|url=https://news.vice.com/en_us/article/bjp87a/cambridge-analytica-bragged-about-using-fake-news-bribes-and-ukranian-hookers-to-influence-elections|website=Vice News|accessdate=25 March 2018}} Nix belongs to [[Nix family|a noted banking and gentry family]] who owned [[Fuller, Banbury, Nix & Co|a London private bank]] and [[Tilgate Park|a major estate]] in [[Crawley]], and his family had strong ties to [[India]] during British colonial rule. He attended [[Eton College|Eton]] before studying art history and working in finance. He is married to Norwegian shipping heiress [[Olympia Paus]], one of the heirs to the shipping giant [[Wilh. Wilhelmsen]] and a member of a billionaire family.{{cn|date=November 2018}} Among Nix's former co-directors of SCL Group is [[Lord Ivar Mountbatten]], a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II.[https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/relationship.asp?personId=84602539&privcapId=434877108&previousCapId=72454231&previousTitle=SCL%20Group%20Limited Bloomberg Research] ==Background and early life== {{Main|Nix family}} [[File:Tilgate House, Crawley.jpg|thumb|[[Tilgate Park|Tilgate House]] in [[Crawley]], former estate of the Ashburner Nix family]] Alexander James Ashburner Nix was born on 1 May 1975.{{cite web | last=Dwilson | first=Stephanie Dube | title=Alexander Nix: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know | website=''Heavy.com'' | date=18 March 2018 | url=https://heavy.com/news/2018/03/alexander-nix-cambridge-analytica-photos-bio/ | access-date=20 March 2018}} His father Paul David Ashburner Nix (1944–2007) was an investment manager who spent twenty-seven years with the [[M&G Investments|M&G Group]] before joining Consulta in 1995, and was a shareholder of [[SCL Group]]. The Ashburner Nix family were wealthy bankers for several generations and had long-standing ties to [[India]] dating back to the [[East India Company]]'s rule from the mid 18th century; family members were prominent merchants and administrators in British-ruled India. His family owned [[Tilgate Park|Tilgate House]], a large manor and 2,185-acre estate in the [[Crawley]] area. It was purchased by the wealthy Indian-born businessman George Ashburner in 1862 and inherited by his daughter Sarah (born 1845 in [[Calcutta]]), who in 1865 married banker John Hennings Nix, one of the partners in the London [[private banking|private bank]] [[Fuller, Banbury, Nix & Co]].Joseph J. Howard, "Ashburner," in ''Miscellanea Genealogica et Heraldica''. Vol. 1. pp. 224ff. 1874. His great-grandfather Charles George Ashburner Nix sold Tilgate House in 1939.[https://www.sussexgardenstrust.org.uk/images/Downloads/Research_Articles/CrawleyParksReport2013/8.1%20History%20of%20Crawley%20Parks%20v6%20-%20Tilgate%20Park%20-%20Part%201.pdf Report On The History Of Crawley Parks] Alexander Nix is also descended from liberal politician [[James Clifton Brown]] and from the banker and politician [[Sir William Brown, 1st Baronet, of Richmond Hill|Sir William Brown]]. Alexander Nix grew up in [[Notting Hill]], in [[West London (sub-region)|West London]], attended fee-paying [[Eton College]], and studied [[art history]] at the [[University of Manchester]]. He later worked as a financial analyst with Baring Securities in [[Mexico]]{{cite web| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=84602539&privcapId=72454231|title= Executive Profile: Alexander Nix BA: Director, SCL Group Limited |author=|publisher= Bloomberg L.P. | accessdate=19 March 2018 }} for Robert Fraser & Partners LLP, a tax and corporate finance firm.{{cite news|url=https://www.campaignlive.co.uk/author/4677/Alexander-Nix|title=Alexander Nix Profile|author=|work=Campaign| accessdate=19 March 2018|ref=1}} In 2003, Nix left finance to join the [[SCL Group]]. ===Family and personal life=== [[File:Pausvillaen Christian Benneches vei 6 Bygdøy Oslo.jpeg|thumb|250 px|[[Villa Paus]] in fashionable [[Bygdøy]], [[Oslo]] was built for Olympia Paus' family in 1907 and is now the home of billionaire [[Petter Stordalen]].]] Nix is married to [[Olympia Paus]] (Caroline Victoria Olympia Paus), a Norwegian shipping heiress of aristocratic origin who was born in Athens in 1976 and raised in London. Norwegian newspaper ''[[Dagbladet]]'' noted that Olympia Paus belongs to one of Norway's most prominent families, and both her parents independently have large fortunes. On her father's side she belongs to the aristocratic [[Paus family]] ({{IPA-no|ˈpæʉs|pron}}), a family of steel industrialists and ship-owners that has been part of the Norwegian elite since medieval times, and her mother [[Cecilie Paus]] (née Wilhelmsen) belongs to the billionaire Wilhelmsen family and has been one of the main owners of [[Wilh. Wilhelmsen]], one of the world's largest shipping companies, since 1978. Olympia Paus is a granddaughter of shipping magnate [[Tom Wilhelmsen (shipping magnate)|Tom Wilhelmsen]]. Her father's family had close ties to the royal family in Norway during the 20th century and her great-grandfather, Count [[Peder Anker Wedel-Jarlsberg]], was [[Lord Chamberlain]], the King's close confidant and the highest-ranking nobleman in Norway; his rank of "[[Count#Scandinavia|feudal count]]" would broadly correspond to Duke in the United Kingdom. Her 2nd great-grandfather, steel industrialist [[Ole Paus (businessman)|Ole Paus]], was a first cousin of playwright [[Henrik Ibsen]]; [[Villa Paus]] in Oslo was built for him. She is also related to Count [[Christopher de Paus]], a philanthropist and papal chamberlain, and her uncle is the businessman [[Peder Paus (businessman)|Peder Paus]] who is married to a former [[marchioness]]. Olympia Paus has never lived in Norway as her parents left the country in 1972 for Athens and London, where her father Christopher Paus worked in the shipping industry and as an investor; he has been reported to own shares worth close to 100 million British pounds in companies in the offshore petroleum industry. Olympia is the sister of designer and socialite [[Pontine Paus]] who also lives in London. In 2012 Nix and Olympia Paus purchased a home in [[Notting Hill]] for around 5 million pounds. They have three children.{{cite web|url=https://www.dagbladet.no/nyheter/alexander-nix-norske-kone-er-rederarving-og-star-midt-i-facebook-skandalen/69689638|title=Alexander Nix' norske kone er rederarving og står midt i Facebook-skandalen|trans-title=Alexander Nix's Norwegian wife is a shipowner and stands in the midst of the Facebook scandal|work=[[Dagbladet]]|language=no}} ==Career== ===Cambridge Analytica=== In 2013, Nix set up [[Cambridge Analytica]] as an offshoot of the SCL Group, to target voters in "more than 40 political campaigns in the US, Caribbean, South America, Europe, Africa and Asia". In the United States, it was involved in the 2014 midterm elections and the 2016 presidential primaries and election, during which it received funding from the [[Robert Mercer (businessman)|Mercer family]]. Nix's firm supported both the [[Ted Cruz]] and [[Donald Trump]] campaigns for the US presidency by using "psychographic" profiles of voters built on data harvested from Facebook.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/17/us/politics/cambridge-analytica-trump-campaign.html|title=How Trump Consultants Exploited the Facebook Data of Millions|last=Rosenberg|first=Matthew|date=17 March 2018|work=The New York Times|access-date=21 March 2018}}{{cite news|first=Eric|last=Auchard|title=May very concerned by Facebook data abuse reports|date=19 March 2018|url=https://uk.mobile.reuters.com/article/amp/idUKKBN1GV1V2|agency=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=20 March 2018}} Before the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016]], Nix's firm was involved in supporting [[Leave.EU]] with its [[Brexit]] campaign, according to both [[Arron Banks]] of Leave.EU, former Cambridge Analytica employee [[Christopher Wylie]], Cambridge Analytica's business development director Brittany Kaiser, and Leave.EU's communications director Andy Wigmore.[http://uk.businessinsider.com/cambridge-analytica-has-contradicted-itself-on-its-work-for-leaveeu-2018-3 Business Insider 21 March 2018: "All the times Cambridge Analytica gave brazenly contradictory accounts of its murky work on Brexit"]; retrieved 22 March 2018.[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/feb/26/robert-mercer-breitbart-war-on-media-steve-bannon-donald-trump-nigel-farage The Observer, 26 February 2018: Robert Mercer: the big data billionaire waging war on mainstream media]; retrieved 22 March 2018.{{cite web|last= Cadwallader|first= Carole| authorlink1=Carole Cadwallader|title=The Cambridge Analytica Files : 'I made Steve Bannon's psychological warfare tool': meet the data war whistleblower|date= 17 March 2018|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/mar/17/data-war-whistleblower-christopher-wylie-faceook-nix-bannon-trump|website= The Observer|accessdate=19 March 2018}} However, according to Wigmore, the work for Leave.EU was done ''[[pro bono]]'', without any money changing hand: “Because Nigel [Farage] is a good friend of the Mercers. And Robert Mercer introduced them to us. He said, ‘Here’s this company we think may be useful to you.’ What they were trying to do in the US and what we were trying to do had massive parallels. We shared a lot of information. Why wouldn’t you?” Behind Trump’s campaign and Cambridge Analytica, he said, were “the same people. It’s the same family.” In February 2018, Nix told the British parliament's [[Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee]] that his company had not received data from Facebook; following further media reports the committee's chairman, [[Damian Collins]], said "We will be contacting Alexander Nix next week asking him to explain his comments."{{cite news| last1= Cadwalladr | first1= Carole| authorlink1= Carole Cadwalladr | last2= Graham-Harrison | first2= Emma| title= Facebook and Cambridge Analytica face mounting pressure over data scandal |date= 19 March 2018| url= https://www.theguardian.com/news/2018/mar/18/cambridge-analytica-and-facebook-accused-of-misleading-mps-over-data-breach| work= [[The Observer]]| accessdate= 19 March 2018}} Nix denies deliberately misleading the parliamentary Select Committee.{{cite web| last= Rajan | first= Amol | title= Data and the threat to democracy|date= 19 March 2018| url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-43461779| publisher= [[BBC News]]| accessdate= 19 March 2018}} In March 2018, ''[[The Observer]]'' reported that Nix talked "unguardedly about the company's practices" when he was secretly filmed by [[Channel 4 News]] reporters posing as prospective clients and that Cambridge Analytica was trying to stop the broadcast of the resulting programme. Nix offered "beautiful [[Prostitution in Ukraine|Ukrainian girls]]" to discredit political opponents in [[Sri Lanka]]."[https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/british-firm-sends-girls-to-entrap-politicians-wpthxqhwv Cambridge Analytica sends 'girls' to entrap politicians]". ''The Times''. 20 March 2018. The secret filming was screened on 19 March as part of a 30-minute segment, with a follow-up scheduled for the next day, focusing on its involvement in the Trump campaign. The conversation appears to portray Nix including entrapment and bribery as potential Cambridge Analytica services.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/19/us/cambridge-analytica-alexander-nix.html|title=Cambridge Analytica, Trump-Tied Political Firm, Offered to Entrap Politicians|last=Rosenberg|first=Matthew|date=19 March 2018|work=The New York Times|access-date=20 March 2018|issn=0362-4331}} On 20 March 2018, Nix was suspended from Cambridge Analytica. On 11 April 2018, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' published an article about the CEO position at Cambridge Analytica, saying Nix "has officially resigned from his position, according to a person close to the company", but also that a "company spokesman ... denied that Mr. Nix had submitted his resignation".https://www.wsj.com/articles/cambridge-analytica-ceo-post-goes-to-julian-wheatland-1523474751 On 2 May 2018, Cambridge Analytica announced they were "closing and starting insolvency proceedings".https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/may/02/cambridge-analytica-closing-down-after-facebook-row-reports-say On 8 October 2018, the Guardian reported that Nix referred to the [[Mia Mottley]], the elected Prime Minister of [[Barbados]] and other government figures via the racial slur of "[[Nigger]]s" in email communications.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/oct/08/former-cambridge-analytica-chief-alexander-nix-used-n-word-to-describe-barbados-pm|title=Former Cambridge Analytica chief used N-word to describe Barbados PM|last=Garside|first=Juliette|last2=Osborne|first2=Hilary|date=2018-10-08|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-08}} === Emerdata === On 23 January 2018, Nix was appointed director of Emerdata Ltd.,{{cite web |title=EMERDATA LIMITED Filing History|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/10911848/officers |website=Companies House |accessdate=21 March 2018}} a new company incorporated in August 2017, along with SCL chairman Julian Wheatland and Cambridge Analytica chief data officer Alexander Tayler. On 16 March 2018, [[Rebekah Mercer|Rebekah]] and Jennifer Mercer were also appointed directors, members of the Mercer family which backed Cambridge Analytica financially (by at least $15 million, according to the New York Times). Another director of Emerdata is Chinese businessman [[Johnson Chun Shun Ko]], deputy chairman and executive director[https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:ZxP_7GlfGIIJ:https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp%3FpersonId%3D8286844%26ticker%3DVARXF+&cd=1&hl=en Bloomberg, Executive Profile of Chun Shun Ko (cached)] Linked 2018-03-22 of [[Frontier Services Group]], a private security firm which mostly operates in Africa and is chaired by US businessman and strong Trump supporter [[Erik Prince]], who is best known for founding private military group [[Blackwater USA]] and being the brother of US education secretary [[Betsy DeVos]].[http://uk.businessinsider.com/cambridge-analytica-executives-and-mercer-family-launch-emerdata-2018-3 Business Insider, Mar. 21, 2018: "The power players behind Cambridge Analytica have set up a mysterious new data company"] Linked 2018-03-22 On 13 April 2018, Nix's role of director was terminated. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nix, Alexander}} [[Category:1975 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English chief executives]] [[Category:Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016]] [[Category:United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Manchester]] [[Category:People educated at Eton College]] [[Category:People from Notting Hill]] [[Category:People associated with the United States presidential election, 2016]] [[Category:Cambridge Analytica]]

{{distinguish|Beats Music|Big beat}} {{redirect-multi|2|Merseybeat|Mersey Sound|other uses of Merseybeat|Merseybeat (disambiguation)|the poetry anthology|The Mersey Sound (anthology)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox music genre |name =Beat |color =white |bgcolor =Crimson |stylistic_origins = {{hlist|[[British rock and roll]]|[[Pop music|pop]]|[[doo-wop]]|[[rhythm and blues]]|[[skiffle]]}} |cultural_origins =Late 1950s – early 1960s, United Kingdom |instruments ={{hlist|[[Guitar]]|[[bass guitar]]|[[Drum kit|drums]]|[[Singing|vocals]]|[[Electronic keyboard|keyboards]]|[[harmonica]]}} |popularity =Mainstream popularity worldwide from 1964-1967 |derivatives = {{hlist|[[Garage rock]]|[[power pop]]|[[pop punk]]|[[Britpop]]|[[yé-yé]]|[[psychedelic rock]]|[[group sounds]]|[[Wong shadow]]|[[string (Thai pop)]]}} |subgenrelist = |subgenres =[[Freakbeat]] |fusiongenres = |regional_scenes =Merseybeat ([[Merseyside]])
[[Brum Beat|Brumbeat]] ([[Birmingham]])
[[Nederbeat]] (Netherlands)
Tottenham Sound ([[London]])
[[VIA (music)|VIA]] ([[Soviet Union]])
[[Big-beat (Eastern Bloc)|Big-beat]] ([[Czechoslovakia]], Hungary, Poland) |local_scenes = |other_topics = {{hlist|[[British Invasion]]|[[Carnaby Street]]|[[Swinging London]]}} }} '''Beat music''', '''British beat''', or '''Merseybeat''' (after bands from [[Liverpool]] and nearby areas beside the [[River Mersey]]) is a [[popular music]] genre that developed in the United Kingdom in the early 1960s. Beat music is a fusion of [[rock and roll]] (mainly [[Chuck Berry]] guitar style and the [[midtempo]] beat of artists like [[Buddy Holly]]), [[doo-wop]], [[skiffle]] and [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]].{{cn|date=November 2018}} The genre provided many of the bands responsible for the [[British Invasion]] of the American pop charts starting in 1964, and provided the model for many important developments in pop and rock music, including the format of the [[rock group]] around [[lead guitar|lead]], [[Rhythm guitar|rhythm]] and [[bass guitar]]s with [[drum kit|drums]].{{cn|date=November 2018}} ==Origin== The exact origins of the terms 'beat music' and 'Merseybeat' are uncertain. The "beat" in each, however, derived from the driving [[rhythm]]s which the bands had adopted from their rock and roll, rhythm and blues and soul music influences, rather than the [[Beat Generation]] literary movement of the 1950s. As the initial wave of rock and roll declined in the later 1950s, "big beat" music, later shortened to "beat", became a live dance alternative to the balladeers like [[Tommy Steele]], [[Marty Wilde]] and [[Cliff Richard]] who were dominating the charts.B. Longhurst, ''Popular Music and Society'' (Polity, 2nd edn., 2007), {{ISBN|0-7456-3162-2}}, p. 98. The German anthropologist and music critic [[Ernest Bornemann|Ernest Borneman]], who lived in England from 1933 to 1960, claimed to have coined the term in a column in ''Melody Maker'' magazine to describe the British imitation of American Rock'n'Roll, Rhythm and Blues and Skiffle bands.{{cite book |last1=Borneman |first1=Ernest |title=Sex im Volksmund. Der obszöne Wortschatz der Deutschen |date=1984 |publisher=Manfred Pawlak |location=Herrsching |isbn=3-88199-145-X |page=[4] |language=German |chapter=Über die sexuelle Umgangssprache |quote="Während der fünfziger Jahre schrieb ich eine wöchentliche Spalte in der englischen Musikzeitschrift 'Melody Maker'. Um den englischen Imitationen der amerikanischen Rhythm-and-Blues, Rock-and-Roll und Skiffle Bands einen Namen zu geben, erfand ich das Wort 'beat music', das sich mittlerweile in vielen Sprachen eingebürgert hat."}} The name ''[[Mersey Beat (magazine)|Mersey Beat]]'' was used for a Liverpool music magazine founded in 1961 by [[Bill Harry]]. Harry claims to have coined the term "based on a [[Beat (police)|policeman's beat]] and not that of the music". The band the Pacifics were renamed the Mersey Beats in February 1962 by [[Bob Wooler]], [[Master of Ceremonies|MC]] at the [[Cavern Club]], and in April that year they became [[the Merseybeats]].B. Eder and R. Unterberger, [http://www.allmusic.com/artist/p4903/biography "The Merseybeats"], ''Allmusic'', retrieved 16 June 2009. With the rise of the Beatles in 1963, the terms Mersey sound and Merseybeat were applied to bands and singers from Liverpool, the first time in British pop music that a sound and a location were linked together.{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=Zx_OpMptTFQC&pg=PA11#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=The Beat Goes on: Liverpool, Popular Music and the Changing City (editors Marion Leonard, Robert Strachan) |page=11|author=Ian Inglis|chapter=Historical approaches to Merseybeat|publisher=Liverpool University Press|year= 2010 |accessdate=20 June 2013|isbn=9781846311901 }} The equivalent scenes in Birmingham and London were described as [[Brum beat]] and the [[Tottenham]] Sound respectively.B. Eder, [http://www.allmusic.com/album/r210426 "Various artists: ''Brum Beat: the Story of the 60s Midland Sound''"], ''Allmusic'', retrieved 5 February 2011. ==Characteristics== The most distinctive characteristic of beat music was its strong beat, using the [[Beat (music)#Backbeat|backbeat]] common to [[rock and roll]] and [[rhythm and blues]], but often with a driving emphasis on all the beats of 4/4 bar.P. Hurry, M. Phillips and M. Richards, ''Heinemann Advanced Music'' (Heinemann, 2001), p. 158. The rhythm itself—described by [[Alan Clayson]] as "a changeless four-four offbeat on the snare drum"—was developed in the clubs in [[Hamburg]], West Germany, where many English groups, including the Beatles, performed in the early 1960s and where it was known as the ''mach schau'' (make show) beat. The 8/8 rhythm was flexible enough to be adopted for songs from a range of genres. In addition, according to music writer [[Dave Laing]],{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/?id=cK-gFIUijQYC&pg=PA44&dq=%22beat+music%22#v=onepage&q=%22beat%20music%22&f=false |title=Britpop and the English Music Tradition (editors Andy Bennett, Jon Stratton) |pages=41–46|author=Jon Stratton|chapter=Englishing Popular Music in the 1960s|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd., 2010|year=2010 |accessdate=2 July 2013|isbn=9780754668053 }}
"[T]he chord playing of the rhythm guitar was broken up into a series of separate strokes, often one to the bar, with the regular plodding of the bass guitar and crisp drumming behind it. This gave a very different effect from the monolithic character of rock, in that the beat was given not by the duplication of one instrument in the rhythm section by another, but by an interplay between all three. This flexibility also meant that beat music could cope with a greater range of time-signatures and song shapes than rock & roll had been able to".
Beat groups usually had simple [[guitar]]-dominated line-ups, with [[Human voice|vocal]] [[harmonies]] and catchy tunes.J. Shepherd, ''Continuum Encyclopedia of Popular Music of the World: Volume II: Performance and Production'' (Continuum, 2003), {{ISBN|0-8264-6322-3}}, p. 78. The most common instrumentation of beat groups featured lead, rhythm and bass guitars plus drums, as popularized by [[the Beatles]], [[The Searchers (band)|the Searchers]], and others. Beat groups—even those with a separate lead singer—often sang both verses and choruses in [[Close and open harmony|close harmony]], resembling doo wop, with nonsense syllables in the backing vocals.[[Nell Irvin Painter]], ''Creating Black Americans: African-American History and Its Meanings, 1619 to the Present'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2006), p. 261. ==Emergence== [[File:Dave Clark Five 1966.JPG|thumb|[[The Dave Clark Five]] appearing on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' in 1966]] In the late 1950s, a flourishing culture of groups began to emerge, often out of the declining [[skiffle]] scene, in major urban centres in the UK like Liverpool, Manchester, Birmingham and London. This was particularly true in Liverpool, where it has been estimated that there were around 350 different bands active, often playing ballrooms, concert halls and clubs.[http://www.triumphpc.com/mersey-beat/about/founders-story2.shtml Mersey Beat - the founders' story]. Liverpool was perhaps uniquely placed within Britain to be the point of origin of a new form of music. Commentators have pointed to a combination of local solidarity, [[deindustrialization|industrial decline]], social deprivation, and the existence of a large population of Irish origin, the influence of which has been detected in Beat music. It was also a major port with links to America, which made for much greater access to American records and instruments like guitars, which could not easily be imported due to trade restrictions.R. Stakes, "Those boys: the rise of Mersey beat", in S. Wade, ed., ''Gladsongs and Gatherings: Poetry and its Social Context in Liverpool Since the 1960s'' (Liverpool: Liverpool University Press, 2001), {{ISBN|0-85323-727-1}}, pp. 157–66. As a result, Beat bands were heavily influenced by American groups of the era, such as [[The Crickets|Buddy Holly and the Crickets]] (from which group [[the Beatles]] derived their name, combining it with a pun on the beat in their music),{{sfn |Gilliland |1969 |loc=show 27, track 4}} and to a lesser extent by [[British rock and roll]] groups such as [[the Shadows]].W. Everett, ''The Beatles as Musicians: The Quarry Men through Rubber Soul'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2001), {{ISBN|0-19-514105-9}}, pp. 37–8. After the national success of the Beatles in Britain from 1962, a number of Liverpool performers were able to follow them into the charts, including [[Gerry & The Pacemakers]],{{sfn |Gilliland |1969 |loc=show 29}} [[The Searchers (band)|the Searchers]], and [[Cilla Black]]. The first act who were not from Liverpool or managed by [[Brian Epstein]] to break through in the UK were [[Freddie and the Dreamers]], who were based in Manchester, a short distance away,[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2006/05/20/ufreddie.xml&sSheet=/news/2006/05/20/ixnews.html ''Daily Telegraph''] "'Dreamers' star Freddie Garrity dies", 20 May 2006, accessed August 2007. as were [[Herman's Hermits]] and [[the Hollies]].V. Bogdanov, C. Woodstra, and S. T. Erlewine, ''All Music Guide to Rock: the Definitive Guide to Rock, Pop, and Soul'' (Backbeat Books, 2002), {{ISBN|0-87930-653-X}}, p. 532. Outside of Liverpool many local scenes were less influenced by rock and roll and more by the [[rhythm and blues]] and later directly by the [[blues]]. These included bands from Birmingham who were often grouped with the beat movement, the most successful being [[the Spencer Davis Group]] and [[the Moody Blues]]. Similar blues influenced bands who broke out from local scenes to national prominence were [[the Animals]] from [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]]{{sfn |Gilliland |1969 |loc=show 29}} and [[Them (band)|Them]] from [[Belfast]].I. Chambers, ''Urban Rhythms: Pop Music and Popular Culture'' (Basingstoke: Macmillan, 1985), {{ISBN|0-312-83469-1}}, p. 75. From London, the term ''Tottenham Sound'' was largely based around [[the Dave Clark Five]], but other London-based [[British rhythm and blues]] bands who benefited from the beat boom of this era included [[the Rolling Stones]],{{sfn |Gilliland |1969 |loc=show 30}} [[the Kinks]] and [[the Yardbirds]].J. R. Covach and G. MacDonald Boone. ''Understanding Rock: Essays in Musical Analysis'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), {{ISBN|0-19-510005-0}}, p. 60. ===British Invasion=== {{Main|British Invasion}} [[File:The Beatles in America.JPG|right|thumb|The arrival of [[the Beatles]] in the U.S., and subsequent appearance on ''The Ed Sullivan Show'', marked the start of the British Invasion]] The term "British Invasion" was mainstreamed by T.V. reporter [[Walter Cronkite]] to describe the Beatles' arrival in the United States and the outbreak of [[Beatlemania]] in 1964.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} Their appearance on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' soon after led to chart success.{{sfn |Gilliland |1969 |loc=show 28}} During the next two years, [[the Animals]], [[Petula Clark]], [[the Dave Clark Five]],{{sfn |Gilliland |1969 |loc=show 29}} the [[Rolling Stones]],{{sfn |Gilliland |1969 |loc=show 30}} [[Donovan]],{{sfn |Gilliland |1969 |loc=show 48}} [[Peter and Gordon]], [[Manfred Mann]], [[Freddie and the Dreamers]], [[The Zombies]], [[Wayne Fontana and the Mindbenders]], [[Herman’s Hermits]], and [[the Troggs]] would have one or more number one singles in America.{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/80244/British-Invasion|title=British Invasion|work=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=23 January 2016}} ==Decline== By 1967 beat music was beginning to sound out of date, particularly compared with the "harder edged" [[blues rock]] that was beginning to emerge. Most of the groups that had not already disbanded by 1967, like the Beatles, moved into different forms of [[rock music]] and [[pop music]], including [[psychedelic rock]] and eventually [[progressive rock]].E. Macan, ''Rocking the Classics: English Progressive Rock and the Counterculture'' (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1997), {{ISBN|0-19-509888-9}}, p. 11. ==Influence== Beat was a major influence on the American [[garage rock]]V. Bogdanov, C. Woodstra and S. T. Erlewine, ''All music guide to rock: the definitive guide to rock, pop, and soul'' (Backbeat Books, 3rd end., 2002), pp. 1320-1. and [[folk rock]] movements,R. Unterberger, [http://www.allmusic.com/explore/essay/merseybeat-t680 "Merseybeat"], retrieved 5 February 2011. and would be a source of inspiration for subsequent rock music subgenres, including Britpop in the 1990s.D. B. Scott, "The Britpop sound", in A. Bennett and J. Stratton, eds., ''Britpop and the English Music Tradition'' (Aldershot: Ashgate, 2010), {{ISBN|0-7546-6805-3}}, pp. 103-122. ==Notable artists== ===Merseybeat=== [[File:Gerry and the Pacemakers group photo 1964.JPG|thumb|[[Gerry and the Pacemakers]] in 1964]] {{Div col|colwidth=15em}} * [[The Beatles]] * [[The Big Three (English band)|The Big Three]] * [[The Cryin' Shames]] * [[Lee Curtis and the All-Stars]] * [[The Dakotas (band)|The Dakotas]] * [[The Dennisons]] * [[Derry and the Seniors]] * [[The Escorts (Liverpool band)|The Escorts]] * [[The Fourmost]] * [[Gerry and the Pacemakers]]{{sfn |Gilliland |1969 |loc=show 29}} * [[Billy J. Kramer]] * [[The Liverbirds]] * [[The Merseybeats]] * [[The Mindbenders]] * [[The Mojos]] * [[Rory Storm|Rory Storm and the Hurricanes]] * [[Kingsize Taylor and the Dominoes]] * [[The Searchers (band)|The Searchers]] * [[The Swinging Blue Jeans]] * [[The Undertakers]] {{Div col end}} ===Other British beat groups=== [[File:Hermans Hermits 1965.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Herman's Hermits]] in 1965]] {{Div col|colwidth=15em}} * [[The Animals]] * [[The Applejacks (British band)|The Applejacks]] * [[Cliff Bennett and the Rebel Rousers]] * [[The Dave Clark Five]]{{sfn |Gilliland |1969 |loc=show 29}} * [[Dave Dee, Dozy, Beaky, Mick & Tich]] * [[Eddy Grant]] and [[The Equals]] * [[Freddie and the Dreamers]] * [[Herman's Hermits]][http://www.allmusic.com/explore/style/merseybeat-d407/artists "Merseybeat (Top Artists)"], ''Allmusic'', retrieved 5 February 2011. * [[The Honeycombs]] * [[The Hollies]] * [[The Kinks]] * [[Lulu (singer)|Lulu]] and [[The Luvvers]] * [[Manfred Mann]] * [[The Move]] * [[Brian Poole and the Tremeloes]] * [[The Pretty Things]] * [[The Rolling Stones]] * [[The Small Faces]] * [[The Troggs]] * [[The Who]] * [[The Zombies]] {{Div col end}} ==See also== * [[:Category:Beat groups]] * [[British rhythm and blues]] * [[Freakbeat]] * [[Garage rock]] * [[Popular beat combo]] {{-}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== * {{Gilliland |show=28 |title=The British Are Coming! The British Are Coming!: The U.S.A. is invaded by a wave of long-haired English rockers |ref=harv}} * Leigh, S., (2004) ''Twist and Shout!: Merseybeat, The Cavern, The Star-Club and The Beatles'' (Nirvana Books), {{ISBN|0-9506201-5-7}} (updated version of ''Let's Go Down to the Cavern'') ==External links== *[http://www.triumphpc.com/mersey-beat/ Mersey Beat magazine, including history of genre] *[http://www.merseybeatnostalgia.co.uk/ Merseybeat Nostalgia] {{rock}} {{pop rock}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Beat Music}} [[Category:1960s in music]] [[Category:20th-century music genres]] [[Category:British Invasion]] [[Category:British music history]] [[Category:British styles of music]] [[Category:English styles of music]] [[Category:Pop music genres]] [[Category:Rhythm and blues music genres]] [[Category:Rock music genres]] [[Category:The Beatles music]] [[Category:Beat music| ]]

{{refimprove|date=March 2013}} {{use British English|date=January 2016}} [[File:Samuel Henry Alken - Bull Baiting.jpg|thumb|right|Bull-baiting in the 19th century, painted by Samuel Henry Alken.]] '''Bull-baiting''' is a [[blood sport]] involving pitting a bull against another animal, usually a dog.<ref name="Irving1837">{{Citation |first=Irving |last=Washington |authorlink=Washington Irving |title=The Adventures of Captain Bonneville, U.S.A., in the Rocky Mountains and the far West |chapter=Gay life at Monterey – Mexican horsemen – A bold dragoon – Use of the lasso – Vaqueros – Noosing a bear – Fight between a bull and a bear – Departure from Monterey – Indian horse stealers – Outrages committed by the travellers – Indignation of Captain Bonneville |url=http://irving.thefreelibrary.com/Adventures-of-Captain-Bonneville-USA-in-the-Rocky-Mountains-and-/1-39#vaquero |year=1837 |accessdate=2009-08-11 |postscript = }}</ref>
==History== ===England=== [[File:Bull and Bear Baiting arenas shown on the Agas Map of London of 1560.JPG|thumb|Bull- and bear-baiting arenas shown on the [[Woodcut map of London|woodcut map of London]] of c.–1561 (the dogs are shown coming out of pens to each side)]] In England during the time of [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Queen Anne]], bull-baiting was practised in [[London]] at [[Hockley-in-the-Hole]], twice a week – and was also reasonably common in provincial towns. At [[Tutbury]], a bull was tied to an iron stake so that it could move within a radius of about 30 feet. The object of the sport was for the dogs to immobilise the bull.
Before the event started, the bull's nose was blown full of [[black pepper|pepper]] to enrage the animal before the baiting. The bull was often placed in a hole in the ground. A variant of bull-baiting was "pinning the bull", where specially-trained dogs would set upon the bull one at a time, a successful attack resulting in the dog fastening his teeth strongly in the bull's [[snout]]. The extinct [[Old English Bulldog]] was bred especially for this sport.
Bull-baiting was not only practised as a form of recreation: there existed a "long-held belief" that baiting improved the flesh.{{clarify|date=February 2018|reason=Improved the flesh of the bull? The spectator? Improved how?}}<ref>{{Citation|title=Aspects of British Calendar Customs|year=1993|editor-first1=Theresa|editor-last1=Buckland|editor-first2=Juliette|editor-last2=Wood|first=Bob|last=Bushaway|pages=76-77|chapter=Bulls, Ballads, Minstrels and Manors: Some Observations on the Defence of Customs in Eighteenth-Century England|isbn=1-850-75243-5|location=Sheffield|publisher=Sheffield Academic Press}}</ref> By the early nineteenth century, the sport began to die out, both because the baiting caused a public nuisance and because of new concerns about animal cruelty.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Griffin|first=Emma|title=Sports and Celebrations in English Market Towns, 1660–1750|journal=Historical Research|date=May 2002|volume=75|issue=188|page=200|doi=10.1111/1468-2281.00147}}</ref>
A Bill for the suppression of the practice was introduced into [[British House of Commons|the House of Commons]] in 1802, but was defeated by thirteen votes. It was not finally outlawed until parliament passed the [[Cruelty_to_Animals_Act_1835|Cruelty to Animals Act of 1835]], which forbade the keeping of any house, pit, or other place for baiting or fighting any bull, bear, dog, or other animal.
===Ireland=== Bull-baiting ({{Lang-ga|tarbh-ghríosú}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teanglann.ie/en/eid/bull-baiting|title=English–Irish Dictionary (de Bhaldraithe): bull-baiting|website=www.teanglann.ie}}</ref>) was widespread in [[Ireland]] in the 17th–19th centuries.
In [[Dublin]], bull-baiting took place near the Cornmarket and in [[Smithfield, Dublin|Smithfield]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/james-kelly-interview-sport-ireland-1600s-1446547-May2014/|title=So what was sport in Ireland like in the 1600s?|first=Paul|last=Fennessy|publisher=}}</ref> On [[St Stephen's Day]] 1789 a riot followed a bull-bait, soldiers fired on the crowd and four were killed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://comeheretome.com/2016/05/18/bull-baiting-in-eighteenth-century-dublin/|title=Bull-baiting in eighteenth century Dublin.|date=18 May 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
In [[Wexford]], the activity arrived in 1621, brought by the Guild of [[Butchers]]; bulls were baited twice a year and their [[Hide (skin)|hides]] presented to the Mayor. The area where bull-baiting took place is still called the Bullring.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wexfordhub.com/history/bullring/|title=The Bullring, Wexford|publisher=}}</ref>
In [[Kilkenny]] it took place at the site called The Ring, first in 1609, and commonly on the feast-day of [[John the Baptist]] (December 27). The last recorded bull-bait was in 1837, after they had become illegal under an 1835 Act.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=2h6DCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA90&lpg=PA90&dq=%22bull+baiting%22+kilkenny&source=bl&ots=y6ZzDyeyeC&sig=19mjr-aV-70FSUl_OwsojyukRtc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwie7Jr_3vfVAhXJL8AKHY-XDW4Q6AEIOTAD#v=onepage&q=%22bull+baiting%22+kilkenny&f=false|title=Sport and Ireland: A History|first=Paul|last=Rouse|date=8 October 2015|publisher=OUP Oxford|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=yz6oCQGzIZEC&pg=PA561&lpg=PA561&dq=%22bull+baiting%22+kilkenny&source=bl&ots=i_zmIDtcQo&sig=H2AnAmpdPczOeo4UiWosZ-8UnOo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwie7Jr_3vfVAhXJL8AKHY-XDW4Q6AEIPDAE#v=onepage&q=%22bull+baiting%22&f=false|title=Drama and the Performing Arts in Pre-Cromwellian Ireland: A Repertory of Sources and Documents from the Earliest Times Until C. 1642|first=Alan John|last=Fletcher|date=27 August 2017|publisher=Boydell & Brewer|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://rothehouse.com/2008/08/05/peter-brennan-anca-pioneer-potter-in-kilkenny/|title=Peter Brennan, ANCA, Pioneer Potter in Kilkenny|first=|last=roisin|date=5 August 2008|publisher=}}</ref>
Bull-baiting also took place in [[Waterford]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=MQA-AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA85&dq=%22bull+baiting%22+ireland&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjws5vr1_fVAhXmB8AKHa6QADkQ6AEIMTAC#v=onepage&q=%22bull+baiting%22+ireland&f=false|title=Sketches of Ireland sixty years ago|date=27 August 2017|publisher=Jam. MacGlashan|via=Google Books}}</ref> [[Naas]], [[Drogheda]], [[Tuam]], [[Carrickfergus]], [[Belfast]] and [[Athlone]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.ie/books?id=2h6DCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA40&dq=%22bull+baiting%22+ireland&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjws5vr1_fVAhXmB8AKHa6QADkQ6AEIJTAA#v=onepage&q=%22bull+baiting%22+ireland&f=false|title=Sport and Ireland: A History|first=Paul|last=Rouse|date=8 October 2015|publisher=OUP Oxford|via=Google Books}}</ref>
===North America=== {{See also|Bear-baiting#North_America}} [[File:Bull and Bear Fight New Orleans 1853.jpg|thumb|A bull and bear fighting in [[New Orleans]], 1853.]]
In the 19th Century, and during [[Spanish Empire|Spanish Colonial Rule]], bulls used to be pitted against [[bear]]s, in [[California]] and [[Mexico]]. Kingsley (1920) said that the bulls that fought the bears, at least while California was part of the United States, were not domesticated [[Hereford (cattle)|Hereford]] bulls, but [[Spanish Fighting Bull]]s, whose weight, agility, speed, sharp horns and hot temper were said to be dangerous to both bears and humans, and Wistar (1937) said that those bulls were fearless.<ref name="Irving1837"/><ref name="Storer & Tevis 1955">{{cite book |author1=Tracy Irwin Storer |author2=Lloyd Pacheco Tevis |title=California Grizzly |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1QVZFQu01KcC&pg=PA149 |year=1996 |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0-520-20520-8 |pages=42–187 |accessdate=2016-03-23}}</ref><ref name="Brown 1996">{{cite book |last1=Brown |first1=David E. |title=The Grizzly in the Southwest: Documentary of an Extinction |date=1996 |publisher=University of Oklahoma Press |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fTVBI9bmH4wC&dq=pissini+Sierra+Madre&source=gbs_navlinks_s |accessdate=2016-03-25}}</ref> In a case of the bull winning, victory could come early, when the bull used its strength to gore the bear to death with its horns, or toss the bear into the air.<ref name="Storer & Tevis 1955"/>
===Dogs in bull baiting=== [[File:Circle of James Ward (1769-1859) British. A Bull Baiting Scene.jpg|thumb|Bull-baiting with dogs, 19th century]] Bull baiting [[dog]]s, including [[bulldog]]s and [[bull and terrier]]s, were bred to bait animals, mainly bulls and bears.<ref>*{{cite book |last=Jenkins |first=Robert |authorlink= |author2=Ken Mollett |title=The Story of the Real Bulldog |publisher=[[TFH Publications]] |year=1997 |location=Neptune, NJ |isbn=0-7938-0491-4}}</ref> During bull-baiting the dog would attempt to flatten itself to the ground, creeping as close to the bull as possible, then darting out and attempting to bite the bull in the nose or head area.<ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Traditional British Rural Sports |year=2005|publisher=Routledge (UK)|url=https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN041535224X&id=jKjYyGF8hSwC&pg=RA2-PA52&lpg=RA2-PA52&dq=Bull-baiting&ie=ISO-8859-1&output=html|isbn=0-415-35224-X}}</ref> The bull would often be tethered by a collar and rope which was staked into the ground. As the dog darted at the bull, the bull would attempt to catch the dog with his head and horns and throw it into the air.
In 1835, the Cruelty to Animals Act was passed in Parliament that outlawed "Blood Sport" in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite book | last=Fogle | first=Bruce |author2=Tracy Morgan | title =The new encyclopedia of the dog | publisher=Dorling Kindersley | year=2000 | location=New York | url= | isbn=0-7894-6130-7 | page=381}}</ref> The bulldog's work was suddenly over and the bulldog rapidly started dying out. Around 1865 dog fanciers began developing dog clubs which eventually culminated into [[conformation show]]s. Many fanciers utilized various remnants of the dog utilized for "Blood Sport" to resurrect the "Bull" dog and ultimately developed today's modern English bulldog.
==Literature== [[Washington Irving]], in his book, ''The Adventures of [[Benjamin Bonneville|Captain Bonneville]]'', wrote that a bear was [[bear-baiting|baited]], and likewise, a wild, fierce bull, before they were brought by [[Cowboy|vaqueros]] to an [[arena]] in a small [[amphitheatre]] in [[Monterey, California]], to fight each other. He called the fight "a favorite, though barbarous sport." In this case, he said that the bear used its sharp claws against the nose of the bull, before catching its tongue, after being repeatedly gored by the bull. Then the bull overturned it "with a desperate effort," and then 'dispatched' it rather easily.<ref name="Irving1837"/>
==See also== {{Portal|Discrimination|Animal rights}} * [[Stamford Bull Run]] * [[Bullfighting]] * [[Bull running]] * [[Dog-baiting]] * [[Beargarden]] * [[List of dog fighting breeds]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Traditional British Rural Sports |year=2005|publisher=Routledge (UK)|url=https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN041535224X&id=jKjYyGF8hSwC&pg=RA2-PA52&lpg=RA2-PA52&dq=Bull-baiting&ie=ISO-8859-1&output=html|isbn=0-415-35224-X}} *{{cite book|last=Griffin|first=Emma|title=England's Revelry: A History of Popular Sports and Pastimes|year=2005|publisher=Oxford University Press}}
==External links== {{commons category|Bull-baiting}} {{EB1911 Poster|Bear-Baiting and Bull-Baiting|Bull-baiting}} *[http://www.umich.edu/~ece/student_projects/trial/bullbaiting.html The Trial of 2 Centuries: Animal v. Animal Sport: Bull-Baiting] *[http://www.essex-family-history.co.uk/bullbaiting.htm Bull baiting in the Eastern Essex area of the UK]
{{Baiting}}
