revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=July 2013}}
The '''Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien''' (English:''The Centre for the Arthurian Imaginary'', but often referred to as the '''Centre Arthurien''', English:''The Arthurian Centre'') is a cultural centre dedicated to the [[Matter of Britain]]. It was founded in 1988 in [[Rennes]] through the influence of different specialists in [[Arthurian legend]], local politicians, artists and writers. Since 1990 its headquarters has been at the [[Château de Comper]] in [[Paimpont forest|Paimpont Forest]].
It organises an annual exhibition with the theme of the Arthurian legends and a cultural season with many events, including the Pentecôte du Roi Arthur (''[[Pentecost]] of [[King Arthur]]''), Rencontres de l'imaginaire de Brocéliande (''Encounters with the Imaginary of [[Brocéliande]]'') and the Semaine du dragon (''[[Dragon]] Week''). The Centre's investment in publicising the art, culture and history of the Arthurian legends and its support for open access to education has brought it public recognition. The members of the Centre also founded the publishing house '''Artus''' which publishes books on those themes.
[[:fr:Claudine Glot|Claudine Glot]] has been president of the Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien since its foundation, its membership includes numerous personalities like [[:fr:Philippe Le Guillou|Philippe Guillou]], [[Gilbert Durand]] and [[:fr:Michel Le Bris|Michel le Bris]]. The elficologist [[Pierre Dubois (author)|Pierre Dubois]], artists [[:fr:Séverine Pineaux|Séverine Pineaux]], [[:fr:Bruno Brucéro|Bruno Brucéro]] and [[:fr:Didier Graffet|Didier Graffet]] and academics [[:fr:Philippe Walter|Philippe Walter]] and [[:fr:Bernard Sergent|Bernard Sergent]] are also among the Centre's mainstays. [[:fr:Nicolas Mezzalira|Nicolas Mezzalira]] has been the Director since 2008. The Centre receives an average 30000 visiters per year, nearly a third of whom are scholars, but also among them have been celebrities such as [[Mario Vargas Llosa]], [[Nolwenn Leroy]] and [[Patrick Poivre d'Arvor]].
==Foundation and Ojectives== [[File:Conférence dans la Salle aux Images..jpg|thumb|Claudine Glot in conference in the image Image Room at the château de Comper.]] The foundation of the Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien met the needs of the people of the [[Ploërmel]] area and the visitors to the forest of [[Brocéliande]] (which has been identified with Paimpont Forest) who were looking for a source of information on the legendary King Arthur. It owes much to the contributors of the journal ''Artus'', a publication devoted to the Celtic countries, including specialists such as [[Gilbert Durand]].<ref name="InterviewCG">Tsaag Valren and Harmonia Amanda, [[n:Interview de Claudine Glot, spécialiste de la légende arthurienne|Interview with Claudine Glot, specialist in the Arthurian legends]], Wikinews, 13 November 2011 {{fr icon}}</ref>
The Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien has the objectives of reaching out to the general public on the Arthurian legends, disseminating artistic works (writing, visual arts, music, street arts, storytelling...), promoting the Matter of Britain to contemporary creatives so that they understand and perpetuate it, and enhancing the legendary cultural heritage. In an interview with [[France 3]], Claudine Glot summarised the aims of the Centre by saying that it has a vocation to attract enthusiasts of the Celtic, medieval and Arthurian worlds, and talk about all the works that they inspire, including [[Heroic fantasy|Heroic Fantasy]].<ref>{{cite AV media|url=http://bretagne.france3.fr/2012/09/07/itineraires-concoret-72655.html|title=Reportage Itinéraires à Brocéliande: la légende du roi Arthur |year = 2012 |language=French}}</ref> It disseminates all that is artistically or historically related to the Arthurian legends and the Forest of Brocéliande<ref>Andrée Corvol et Paul Arnould, ''La forêt: Perceptions et représentations'', coll. Alternatives rurales, éditions L'Harmattan, 1997, {{ISBN|273845352X}}, p. 260 {{fr icon}}</ref><ref>Jacky Ealet, ''Dictionnaire de la Table Ronde'', Éditions Jean-paul Gisserot, 2007, {{ISBN|2877479099}}, p. 19 {{fr icon}}</ref> and is seen as an organisation that "maintains the myth".<ref>Samuel Bertrand et Jacky Ealet (ill. Samuel Bertrand), ''Les personnages de Brocéliande'', éditions Jean-paul Gisserot, 2001, {{ISBN|2877475697}}, p. 27 {{fr icon}}</ref> Claudine Glot attaches great importance to the surrounding "forest of the soul" where "legend breathes.".<ref name="UtBretagne">{{harvsp|Fesselier-Haguet|Becaert|Labourdette|Hervé|2010|p=20}}</ref>
==History== [[File:François Lavallée au château de Comper.jpg|thumb|left|The storyteller François Lavallée performing at the Château de Comper in April 2012.]]
From its inception in 1988, the Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien has led in multiple areas. Its [[wikt:Special:Search/eclectic|eclectic]] exhibitions include modern works as well as [[Preraphaelite]] paintings. It organises (and hosts) spectacles, storytelling,<ref>{{cite AV media|url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/xp06wu_presentation-de-contes-du-centre-de-l-imaginaire-arthurien-en-sceance-publique_webcam |title= Présentation de contes du centre de l'imaginaire arthurien en séance publique|date = 3–4 December 2011 |medium=video |publisher=Bernard Martin |language=French}}</ref> concerts, conferences, guided tours in the forest and educational presentations for school groups. The Centre participates in drafting catalogues, educational projects, [[:fr:journées du patrimoine|journées du patrimoine]] (''heritage days'')<ref>{{cite AV media|url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x6yxp9_journee-du-patrimoine-au-centre-art_travel |title=Journée du Patrimoine au Centre Arthurien |date = 21 September 2008 |medium=video |publisher=Brocéliande TV |language=French}}</ref> and outreach in schools and universities, assists in [[documentary research]], and compiles [[bibliography|bibliographies]] and [[iconography|iconographies]]. There are many scholars from different countries among its members.<ref name="Histso"/>
In addition, members of the Centre publish books on these themes through their publishing house Artus: fine art books on Brocéliande, Brittany, Ireland and Scotland; essays (''Le Gant de Verre'', ''Les Guerriers de Finn'' by [[:fr:Michel Cazenave|Michel Cazenave]]) and theatre with ''La Légende de [[Deirdre]]''.<ref name="Artus"/>
===1988-1990=== In 1988, the Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien was officially established in Rennes, thanks to the willing efforts of several academics, regional politicians and writers. [[:fr:Michel Le Bris|Michel Le Bris]] was among the principal founders, with [[:fr:Claudine Glot|Claudine and Hervé Glot]].<ref name="InterNicolas"/> The [[International Arthurian Society]] and academic writer Gilbert Durand were supporters of the project.<ref name="Histso"/>
The first exhibitions were devoted to [[King Arthur]] (''Arturus Rex'', in collaboration with the [[Université catholique de Louvain|Université Catholique de Louvain]], 1988), [[Brocéliande]] and the Forest (1989), [[Megalith]]s and Stones(1990) with the participation of Pieter-Paul Koster. These were mounted at various locations in the region, including Ploërmel, Rennes and colleges. In 1990, the exhibition was installed in the Château de Comper and opened throughout the summer. At the same time new activities commenced, such as tours of the [[Paimpont forest|Paimpont Forest]]. Following the fire that raged over 500 hectares of Brocéliande from the 7 to 11 September 1990 the Centre had to begin again and rehabilitated itself.<ref name="Histso"/>
===1991-1996=== [[Image:Guidage en forêt de Brocéliande..jpg| thumb | [[Nicolas Mezzalira]], storytelling with a group during a visit to Forest of Brocéliande.]] In 1991, the exhibition was devoted to cinema and especially the film [[Excalibur (film)|Excalibur]], and the director [[John Boorman]] was welcomed at Comper. [[France 3 Bretagne]] produced a documentary, then the Centre was involved in planting the l'Arbre d'Or (''golden tree'') at the entrance to the [[Val sans retour]]. It was also in 1991 that the first spactacles were organized in the park at the Château de Comper.<ref name="Histso"/>
In 1992, the exhibition focused on [[graphic novel]]s, with the participation of [[François Bourgeon]]. In addition to spectacles, music and storytelling were hosted. The Centre was invited to exhibit in Paris, and to participate in conferences between December 1992 and March 1993.<ref name="Histso"/>
From 1993 to 1996, the Centre collected and highlighted information about [[Merlin]], monarchs and magicians, and the Knights of the [[Round Table]]. School groups were invited, [[:fr:Michel Le Bris|Michel Le Bris]], [[:fr:Michel Cazenave|Michel Cazenave]], [[:fr:Christian Joseph Guyonvarc'h|Christian Guyonvarc'h]] or [[:fr:Philippe Le Guillou|Philippe Le Guillou]] held conferences. It organised the exhibits at the Festival des mythes et légendes (''Festival of Myths and Legend''s) at the [[Château d'Amboise]] (2 to 5 March 1994), and exhibited in the area to the south-east of Rennes for a period of six months. In 1995, the municipal library at Rennes organised the literary event, Un Automne Arthurien (''An Arthurian Autumn''). In April 1996, the book ''Hauts-lieux de Brocéliande'' (''Significant places in Brocéliande'') - born from the work of Centre members - was published by [[:fr:éditions Ouest-France|éditions Ouest-France]].<ref name="Histso"/>
===1996-2005=== [[File:PierreDuboisArthurien.JPG| thumb | right | The members of the Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien, guests of honour at the [[médiévales de provins|27th médiévales de Provins]] en 2010.]] On 8 and 9 March 2001, the symposium ''Le monde et l'autre monde'' (''The World and the Other World'') was held in Rennes with the participation of members of the Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien.<ref>[[Denis Hüe]] and [[Christine Ferlampin-Acher]], ''Le monde et l'autre monde: actes du colloque arthurien de Rennes (8-9 mars 2001)'', Paradigme, 2002, {{ISBN|2868782353}}, 457 p. {{fr icon}}</ref> The 2005 exhibition ''Les Enchantements de Bretagne'' (''The Enchantments of Brittany''), described the adventures experienced by the characters the Arthurian legends. The year 2005 also saw the establishment of a [[live action role-playing game]] and a [[treasure hunt (game)|treasure hunt]].
===2006-2007=== In 2006, the exhibition presented the relations between [[fairy|faeries]] and knights in the medieval [[Romance (heroic literature)|romance]] and in more recent works. Celtic and medieval faeries, the warriors of Ireland and the Knights of the Round Table were featured, including [[Lancelot]] and [[Lady of the Lake|Viviane]]. Sets, costumes and accessories were created by artists and artisans.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://foret-broceliande.fr/La-Fee-et-le-Chevalier?debut_breves=5|title=La Fée et le Chevalier|publisher=foret-broceliande.fr|accessdate=19 January 2013 |language=French}}</ref>
In 2007, the annual exhibition was devoted to the Knights of the Round Table. The season was marked by the Knight's Pentecost, a temporary exhibition ''Naissance de la féerie'' (''Birth of Faerie'') with texts by [[Pierre Dubois (author)|Pierre Dubois]] and photographs by Hervé Glot, stories, music ([[harp]]), three lectures by Claudine Glot, a medieval [[kermesse (festival)|kermesse]] and a show devoted to the Forest.<ref name="Acus2007"/> The guest of honour at the Rencontres de l'Imaginaire was [[Olivier Ledroit]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://foret-broceliande.fr/Rencontres-de-l-Imaginaire-2007|title=Rencontres de l'Imaginaire 2007|publisher=foret-broceliande.fr|accessdate=19 January 2013 |language=French}}</ref> The last event of the season was the [[European Heritage Days]].<ref name="Acus2007">{{cite web|url=http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/Copie%20de%20actualite.html|title=Actualités 2007|publisher=Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien|accessdate=19 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101212133423/http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/Copie%20de%20actualite.html|archivedate=12 December 2010|df=}}</ref>
===2008-2010=== [[File:Contecentrearthurien.JPG|thumbnail|left | A story session at Comper in July 2010 (right Claudine Glot and Pierre Dubois)]] In 2008, the chosen theme of the exhibition was entitled ''Des Celtes au roi Arthur'' (''From the Celts to King Arthur''). It demonstrated the Celtic heritage of medieval romances and legends from the [[Irish mythology|Irish epics]]. During the months of May and June, a photo exhibition devoted to [[Scotland]] was mounted. The guests of honour at Rencontres de l'Imaginaire were [[:fr:Barbara Canepa|Barbara Canepa]] and [[:fr:Alessandro Barbucci|Alessandro Barbucci]].<ref name="Prog2008">{{cite web|url=http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/info%20accueil.html|title=Programme 2008|publisher=Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien|accessdate=18 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081019081006/http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/info%20accueil.html|archivedate=19 October 2008|df=}}</ref> The theme of the 2009 exhibition, ''Dans la forêt de Merlin'' (''In Merlin's Forest''), focused on the different facets of the enchanter and his forest.<ref name="Prog2009"/> To celebrate the publication of the graphic novel ''[[:fr:Merlin (bande dessinée, Istin)|Merlin]]'' by [[:fr:Soleil Productions - Soleil Celtic|Soleil Celtic]] the guests of honour at Rencontres de l'Imaginaire in that year were [[:fr:Aleksi Briclot|Aleksi Briclot]] and Jean-Sébastien Rossbach.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/Flyer_2009.pdf|title=Flyer du programme 2009|publisher=Centre de l'imaginaire arthurien|accessdate=19 January 2013|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226162453/http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/Flyer_2009.pdf|archivedate=26 December 2010|df=}}</ref>
In 2010, the Centre's exhibition was devoted to Arthurian legends and magic. An exhibition and a book dedicated to the Lai of [[Lanval]] were created through collaboration with artists from [[Devon]] in England. It included works by Breton and English artists such as [[Terri Windling]].<ref>{{harvsp|Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien|Chagford Filmmaking group|2010|p=}}</ref> A partnership with [[Chagford Filmmaking Group]] based in [[Exeter]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisexeter.co.uk/news/Feast-fairies-brings-fantasy-city-castle/article-3011774-detail/article.html|title=Feast of fairies brings fantasy and legend to city castle|publisher=This is Exeter|accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref> brought the realisation of the film ''Sir Lanval''.<ref>{{YouTube|kpB11AbBjMo|Sir Lanval}}</ref> The Centre was also invited to be the guest of honour at the 27th Médiévales de Provins.<ref>{{citation |newspaper=Le Parisien |title=Provins vous fait vivre le Moyen Age|date=12 June 2010|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/seine-et-marne-77/provins-vous-fait-vivre-le-moyen-age-12-06-2010-961032.php|language=fr}}</ref>
===2011-2012=== [[File:Représentation de la Compagnie du Lysandore.jpg|thumb|The ''Compagnie du Lysandore'' during Rencontres de l'Imaginaire in Brocéliande, 2012.]] In 2011, the exhibition focused on two faeries: [[Morgan le Fay|Morgana]] and [[Melusine]]. Pierre Dubois and [[René Hausman]] were the guests of honor at the 2011 Rencontres de l'Imaginaire.<ref>Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien, [http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/images/depliant_2011_1.jpg Programme 2011] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314192515/http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/images/depliant_2011_1.jpg |date=March 14, 2012 }}</ref> At the end of June, the singer [[Nolwenn Leroy]] came with a team from [[France 2]] to shoot a documentary about the Arthurian legends and the Forest of Brocéliande with the help of the Centre.<ref>{{Citation |last=Cléro |first=Olivier |url=http://www.ouest-france.fr/actu/actuLocale_-Nolwenn-Leroy-fera-decouvrir-la-foret-de-Broceliande-sur-France-2-_56043-avd-20110701-60816640_actuLocale.Htm |title=Nolwenn Leroy fera découvrir la forêt de Brocéliande sur France 2|date=1 July 2011|newspaper=Ouest-France|language=fr}}</ref> According to the director Nicolas Mezzalira, in November 2011 the association that manages the Centre comprised about 300 members.<ref name="InterNicolas"/> It launched a campaign to restore and open La Petite Maison des Légendes (''The Little House of Legends'') in Concoret on 14 December.<ref name="Hiverimaginaire"/>
In addition to the usual days of storytelling, musical events and lectures, 2012 was punctuated by signings with [[:fr:Séverine Pineaux|Séverine Pineaux]] and [[:fr:Jerome Lereculey|Jerome Lereculey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/Prog_CIA_2012.pdf|title=Programme 2012 du Centre arthurien|publisher=centre-arthurien-broceliande.com|accessdate=8 January 2013|language=French|format=pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121004045759/http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/Prog_CIA_2012.pdf|archivedate=4 October 2012|df=}}</ref> During the [[:fr:Printemps des Légendes#2012|Printemps des Légendes en 2012]] (''Spring of Legends'' organised at [[Monthermé]] the Centre was guest of honour,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lunion.presse.fr/article/autres-actus/montherme-les-trois-coups-du-printemps-des-legendes|title=Les trois coups du Printemps des légendes}}</ref> making camp and mounting an exhibition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fabyrinthe.com/expeditions/ardennes/581-printemps-des-legendes-2012-compte-rendu-et-rendez-vous-conte-reussi-?8bc04e4b7059a1bccad99c91782caef0=4392bc40d2508457cc1cca115278ee56|title=Printemps des Légendes 2012 : compte-rendu, et rendez-vous conte réussi !|author=Amélie Tsaag Valren|publisher=Fabyrinthe|date=17 April 2012|accessdate=20 July 2012 |language=French}}</ref> According to the French newspaper [[L'Union]], this festival in the Ardennes was a great success.<ref name="Monthermé"/> The guests of honour at the Rencontres de l'Imaginaire 2012 were [[:fr:Arleston|Arleston]] and [[:fr:Guillaume Sorel|Guillaume Sorel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://centreimaginairearthurien.files.wordpress.com/2012/07/2012-flyer-ri-web-4.jpg|title=Flyer des Rencontres de l'Imaginaire 2012|date=7 January 2012| language=French}}</ref>
At the end of November 2012, La Petite Maison des Légendes officially opened, thanks to a grant by the [[:fr:fondation du patrimoine|Fondation du Patrimoine]] (''Heritage Foundation'') in Brittany,<ref name="PetiteMaisonFondation">{{cite web|url=http://www.fondation-patrimoine.org/fr/bretagne-6/tous-les-projets-335/detail-la-petite-maison-des-legendes-a-concoret-1245|title=La petite maison des légendes à Concoret|publisher=Fondation-patrimoine|author=Claudine Glot|accessdate=4 January 2013|language=French}}</ref> to private donations and to subsidies from the [[:fr:Communauté de Communes de Mauron en Brocéliande|Communauté de Communes de Mauron en Brocéliande]], the [[:fr:Conseil Général du Morbihan|Conseil Général du Morbihan]] and from the region.<ref name="Hiverimaginaire">Voir [http://centreimaginairearthurien.wordpress.com/2012/11/26/la-petite-maison-des-legendes-a-broceliande-des-nouvelles/ le scan de l'article « Pas d'hiver pour l'imaginaire »]</ref> The first event was organised with the Congolese storyteller Jorus Mabiala, and the second marked the publication of the ''Chats, le livre secret'' (''Cats, the Secret Book'')by Séverine Pineaux.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://broceliande.valsansretour.com/spip.php?rubrique2&date=2012-12-19&date_mode=jour|title=Agenda du 19 décembre 2012|publisher=Office de tourisme du pays de Mauron en Brocéliande|accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> {{Clear}}
{{Gallery Message|Costume performances during events at the Centre in 2012}} <center> <gallery perrow="5"> Image:Présentation des chevaliers 170.jpg|[[Lancelot]] and [[Perceval]] Image:Le roi Arthur et la reine Guenièvre.jpg|[[King Arthur|Arthur]] et [[Guinevere]] Image:Keu le sénéchal 180.jpg|[[Seneschal]] [[Sir Kay|Kay]] </gallery> </center>
===Annual Exhibition Themes=== *1988 : ''Arturus Rex'' Le roi Arthur *1989 : ''Brocéliande et l'obscur des forêts'' *1990 : [[Mégalithe]]s et pierres *1991 : ''[[Excalibur (film)|Excalibur]]'' (de [[John Boorman]]) *1992 : ''[[Les Compagnons du crépuscule]]'' (de [[François Bourgeon]]) *1993 : ''Souveraines et Magiciennes'' *1994 : ''[[Merlin (magicien)|Merlin]]'' *1995 : ''Chevaliers !'' (Les Chevaliers de la Table Ronde) *1996 : ''Les Guerriers d'Or'' *1997 : ''[[Tristan et Iseut]]'' *1998 : ''Le roi Arthur'' *1999 : ''Charmes et Chevalerie'' *2000 : ''Légendes de Brocéliande'' *2001 : ''La quête du [[Holy Grail|Graal]]'' *2002 : ''Merlin'' *2004 : ''Légendes Celtiques'' *2005 : ''Les enchantements de Bretagne'' *2006 : ''La fée et le chevalier'' *2007 : ''Les Chevaliers de la Table Ronde'' *2008 : ''Des Celtes au roi Arthur'' *2009 : ''Dans la forêt de Merlin''<ref name="Prog2009">{{cite web|url=http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/Info_groupes_CIA_2009.pdf|title=Info groupes et exposition 2009|publisher=Centre de l'Imaginaire arthurien|accessdate=5 January 2013|language=French|format=pdf}}{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *2010 : ''Légendes et féerie'' *2011 : ''De [[Fée Morgane|Morgane]] à [[Mélusine (fée)|Mélusine]]''<ref>{{cite web|author=Richard Ely|url=http://peuple-feerique.com/2011/04/15/de-morgane-a-melusine-chateau-de-comper-en-broceliande/|title=De Morgane à Mélusine – Château de Comper-en-Brocéliande|date=15 April 2011|accessdate=5 January 2013|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817105909/http://peuple-feerique.com/2011/04/15/de-morgane-a-melusine-chateau-de-comper-en-broceliande/|archivedate=17 August 2011|df=}}</ref> *2012 : ''Femmes-fées''<ref>{{YouTube|ZOvk823aV74|Teaser Femmes-Fées {Exposition 2012 du Centre Arthurien} }}</ref>
==Organisation== [[Claudine Glot|Claudine and Hervé Glot]] (respectively President and Secretary),<ref name="InterNicolas"/> [[Gilbert Durand]] (Research Fellow, Honorary President) and [[Michel Le Bris]] (Writer, Honorary President)<ref name="Histso"/> were among the founders of '''Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien'''. Except for [[Gilbert Durand]], who died in late 2012, all remain in office. The elficologist[[Pierre Dubois (author)|Pierre Dubois]] joined them a few years later and became Chancellor. Artists such as Carmelo de la Pinta and Sophie Busson, as well as researchers ([[Christian Guyonvarc'h]] and the archaeologist [[Jacques Briard]] who has undertaken excavations in Paimpont Forest) promote or have actively supported the Centre.<ref name="InterNicolas">{{cite web|url=http://planetegaia.fr/interview-du-directeur-du-centre-de-l%E2%80%99imaginaire-arthurien-au-chateau-de-comper-monsieur-nicolas-mezzalira/|title=Interview du directeur du centre de l'imaginaire arthurien au château de Comper : Monsieur Nicolas MEZZALIRA|date=23 November 2011|accessdate=4 January 2013|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130701223521/http://planetegaia.fr/interview-du-directeur-du-centre-de-l%E2%80%99imaginaire-arthurien-au-chateau-de-comper-monsieur-nicolas-mezzalira/|archivedate=1 July 2013|df=}}</ref> The composition of the officers has changed over time.
<small>The following information is from the ''l'ours'' (bears) of the Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien, published on the official website</small> <div style="margin:auto; text-align:left; background-color:#FFFFFF; border: 1px solid; #aaa font-size:90%; width:100%;"> * President: [[Claudine Glot]] * Co-President: [[Philippe Le Guillou]] * Honorary Presidents: [[Gilbert Durand]], [[Michel Le Bris]], Guy and Jean Aubert Kersabiec * Chancellor: [[Pierre Dubois (author)|Pierre Dubois]] * Secretary: Hervé Glot * Treasurer: Roselyne Saulier * Scientific Committee: [[Denis Hüe]], [[Philippe Walter]] and [[Bernard Sergent]] * Director: [[Nicolas Mezzalira]] * Team: Dominique Robertière, Christophe Germier and Aurore Charles. </div>
==Important Locations== The Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien is open to the public at the [[château de Comper]] from the beginning of March to the end of November. Since the end of 2012 Ls Petite Maison des Légendes is open to the public during the winter months when the Château is closed. Both are situated in the [[Communes of France|Commune]] of [[Concoret]] ([[Morbihan]], Brittany).
Since 2009, the Centre has taken part in event outside Brittany every year (Médiévales de Provins, [[Printemps des Légendes]]<ref name="Monthermé">{{citation |title=L'apothéose du Printemps des Légendes |last=Spasic |first=Mirko |newspaper=L'Union |date=16 April 2012|url=http://www.lunion.presse.fr/article/ardennes/diapo-l%E2%80%99apotheose-du-printemps-des-legendes?xtcr=3&xtmc=Printemps%20des%20l%C3%A9gendes|language=fr}}</ref>...).
===Château de Comper=== [[File:ChateauComper.jpg|thumb|left|The [[château de Comper]], at [[Concoret]], on the shores of the Faery Vivian's lake]] {{main|Château de Comper}}
{{quotation|C’est le lieu le plus magique que l'on puisse avoir. Comper a réellement « fait » le centre arthurien. Le château est au croisement de la légende et de l’Histoire.
''It's the most magical place that we could have. Comper has really made the Arthurian Centre. The Château is at the crossroads of legend and history''.|Claudine Glot|[[n:Interview de Claudine Glot, spécialiste de la légende arthurienne|Interview accordée à Wikimedia France]]}}
The Centre de l’Imaginaire Arthurien has lodged at the Château since 1990. It is open to the public from the beginning of March until the end of October.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://foret-broceliande.fr/Centre-de-l-Imaginaire-Arthurien|title=Centre de l’Imaginaire Arthurien|publisher=foret-broceliande.fr|accessdate=4 January 2012|language=French}}</ref> The Centre rents the entire west wing of the main building. The ground floor is equipped with a bookshop offering hundreds of volumes (books, graphic novels, fine art books etc.) on the legends, the Celts and the Middle Ages, as well the permanent and temporary exhibitions on the theme of the Authurian legends. The projection room, on the first room, enables visiters to watch documentaries (films, reportage, etc.).<ref name="InterNicolas"/>
The Château is the starting point for guided visits to the forest. Different events (storytelling, lectures, craft fairs, book signings etc.) are organised there on specific dates:<ref name="InterNicolas"/> the Pentecôte du Roi Arthur, the Rencontres de l'imaginaire de Brocéliande and the Semaine du Dragon, among others. The Château is itself associated with a legend of the faery Viviane which is often told to interested visiters.<ref>{{harvsp|Le Divenah|Jigourel|2010|p=91}}</ref>
===Petite Maison des Légendes=== [[File:La Petite Maison des Légendes à Concoret.jpg|thumb|La Petite Maison des Légendes at [[Concoret]] in 2013.]] La Petite Maison des Légendes opened at the end of November 2012. It includes a permanent bookshop and hosts events organised by the Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien (exhibitions, displays, briefings) when the Château de Comper is closed in the winter months. La Petite Maison also accommodates the [[artist-in-residence]].<ref name="PetiteMaisonFondation"/>
Built in the red [[schist]] typical of the region, the building is owned by the Centre's Treasurer who has made it available to the Centre for fifteen years. It has been restored thanks to a grant from the Fondation du Patrimoine and public and private donations. Notably, this enabled the repair of the external woodwork.<ref name="PetiteMaisonFondation"/> {{clear}}
==Events Organised by the Arthurian Centre== [[File:Echassiers et musiciens.jpg|thumb|Stilt walkers and musicians in the courtyard of the Château de Comper during the medieval market in August 2012.]] Each year, the Arthurian Centre's opening season is marked by events, some of which have now been held for more than ten years. The three principal event are the Pentecôte du Roi Arthur, the Rencontres de l'imaginaire de Brocéliande and the Semaine Du dragon. The Château de Comper also hosts conjurers and illusionists during the Samedis de la Magie (''Magic Saturdays'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://foret-broceliande.fr/Les-Samedis-de-la-Magie,762|title=Les samedis de la Magie|publisher=foret-broceliande.fr|accessdate=9 January 2013|language=French}}</ref> The medieval market in August is an occasion to welcome [[artisan|craftspeople]] and organise a [[Kermesse (festival)|Kermesse]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://foret-broceliande.fr/Marche-artisanal-et-Kermesse,654|title=Marché artisanal et Kermesse médiévale|publisher=foret-broceliande.fr|accessdate=9 January 2013|language=French}}</ref>
===Pentecôte du Roi Arthur=== The Pentecôte du Roi Arthur is a medieval spectacle with jonglerie, storytellers, camps, storytelling, camps and other displays such as [[historical reenactment]] and [[living history]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.morbihan.com/la-pentecote-du-roi-arthur/concoret/tabid/7418/offreid/157cc8d4-e220-4482-86f5-72a039efb3df/detail-fetes-et-manifestations.aspx|title=La pentecôte du roi Arthur|publisher=Morbihan.com|accessdate=6 January 2013|language=French}}</ref> As the name suggests, it coincides with the date of Pentecost. It is a celebration of spring and the adventures and encounters which it brings,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://foret-broceliande.fr/La-Pentecote-du-roi-Arthur,778|title=La Pentecôte du roi Arthur|publisher=foret-broceliande.fr|accessdate=6 January 2013|language=French}}</ref> but most importantly (according to [[Ouest-France]]) it is an evocation of King Arthur's coronation day (as described by [[Robert de Boron]] in the 13th century) and his commitment to the Church. It was also on Pentecost that the [[Holy Grail]] appeared to the Knights of the Round Table.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ouest-france.fr/actu/actuLocale_-La-Pentecote-la-journee-preferee-du-Roi-Arthur-_-1828612------56165-aud_actu.Htm|title=La Pentecôte, la journée préférée du Roi Arthur|date=10 June 2011|author=olivier Cléro|publisher=Ouest-France|accessdate=6 January 2013|language=French}}</ref>
===Rencontres de l'Imaginaire de Brocéliande=== [[File:Librairie extérieure des Rencontres de l'Imaginaire..jpg|thumb|A bookshop under canvas at the Rencontres de l'Imaginaire de Brocéliande in 2012.]] [[File:Dédicace au Château de Comper..jpg|thumb|left|A signing by {{ill|Guillaume Sorel|fr}} at the Rencontres de l'Imaginaire 2012.]] The idea for Rencontres de l'Imaginaire de Brocéliande dates to 2002. It was first realised in 2004 and included an exhibition and festival in [[Concoret]] and at the [[Château de Comper]]. In the years since it has been held solely at Comper. On the last weekend of July, the Centre organises the opportunity for the authors and illustraters of graphic novels, writers and illustraters, to meet their public. It primarily facilitates book-signings, with equestrian spectacles, storytellers and lectures. Since 2011, the Recontres have been held in partnership with the communes of [[Tréhorenteuc]] and [[Paimpont]]. This intimate festival is above all else friendly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://foret-broceliande.fr/Rencontres-de-l-Imaginaire-en-foret-de-Broceliande|title=Rencontres de l’Imaginaire en forêt de Brocéliande|publisher=foret-broceliande.fr|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref>
The seventh festival which took place on 23 and 24 July 2011 was host to a score of artists and celebrities. Ouest-France, which described this festival as "essential", said that its objective is to, "montrer et donc faire découvrir tout ce qui se fait dans la littérature autour des légendes" (''show and demonstrate everything done in the literature around these legends'').<ref>{{citation|title=Les 7<sup>e</sup> rencontres de l'imaginaire commencent aujourd'hui|date=23 July 2011 |last=Hancq |first=Stéphanie |newspaper=Ouest-France |url=http://www.ouest-france.fr/actu/actuLocale_-Les-7-e-rencontres-de-l-imaginaire-commencent-aujourd-hui-_35117-avd-20110723-60954320_actuLocale.Htm|language=fr}}</ref> {{clear}}
===Semaine du Dragon=== The Semaine du dragon was conceived and directed by the Centre and the request of the Pays Touristique de l'[[Oust (rivière)|Oust]] de Brocéliande. [[Pierre Dubois (auteur)|Pierre Dubois]] is the patron. It has been held every other year since 2009 (in odd numbered years),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture-broceliande.fr/site/?page_id=1255|title=Semaine du Dragon – du 22 au 31 octobre 2011|editor=Office socio-culturel cdc Mauron|date=2 November 2011|accessdate=20 July 2012|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130225171359/http://www.culture-broceliande.fr/site/?page_id=1255|archivedate=25 February 2013|df=}}</ref> at the end of October or beginning of November, to coincide with the Celtic festival of [[Samhain]]. Various activities are organised by cultural organisations: storytelling, fire-eaters, tastings, games, meals, concerts, lectures, theatre, films and conferences. The evening of the 31 October is concluded with a vintage brew by the ''Brasserie Lancelot''.<ref name="Oust">{{cite web|url=http://www.oust-broceliande-vacances.com/broceliande-actualites/485-semaine-du-dragon-en-oust-a-broceliande.html|title=Semaine du dragon en Oust à Brocéliande|publisher=Pays touristique de l'Oust de Brocéliande|accessdate=8 January 2013|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130329031307/http://www.oust-broceliande-vacances.com/broceliande-actualites/485-semaine-du-dragon-en-oust-a-broceliande.html|archivedate=29 March 2013|df=}}</ref> In even numbered years, Le Retour de Flammes du Dragon (''The Dragon Flashback''), an event of lesser magnitude is held over three days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oust-broceliande-vacances.com/broceliande-actualites/664-le-retour-de-flamme-du-dragon-en-broceliande.html|title=le retour de flamme du dragon|publisher=Pays touristique de l'Oust de Brocéliande|accessdate=8 January 2013|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130329031313/http://www.oust-broceliande-vacances.com/broceliande-actualites/664-le-retour-de-flamme-du-dragon-en-broceliande.html|archivedate=29 March 2013|df=}}</ref> {{clear}}
==Plaudits and Influence== [[File:Devant le lac de Comper..jpg|thumb|The Team at the Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien prepare a workshop beside the lake at the Château de Comper during the [[European Heritage Days]].]] The Centre de l'Imaginaire arthurien is internationally recognised <ref>Voir par exemple la Guide pour la France de Anna E. Brooke, Nathalie Jordi, Lauren Sommer et Anna Sussman, ''MTV France'', volume 6 de MTV Guides: France, John Wiley & Sons, 2007, {{ISBN|0764587706}}, p. 248 {{fr icon}}</ref> as a 'must see' for those interested in the Arthurian legends. [[Radio France internationale|RFI]] hailed the talents of the guides, the richness of the library and the convivial atmosphere.<ref name="RFI">Ludovic Dunod et Alice Milot, ''Si loin si proche : La Forêt de Brocéliande ou l’imaginaire au pouvoir'', [[Radio France Internationale]], août 2011, [http://voyage.blogs.rfi.fr/article/2011/08/18/la-foret-de-broceliande-ou-l-imaginaire-au-pouvoir#centre_arthurien rediffusion partielle]</ref> In early February 2012 the Centre met a team from [[TF1]] at the Château de Comper for a "Closeup on Rennes",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ouest-france.fr/actu/actuLocale_-Broceliande-au-journal-de-TF1-dimanche_40817-2045340------56165-aud_actu.Htm|title=Brocéliande au journal de TF1 dimanche|publisher=Ouest-France|date=16 February 2012|accessdate=9 January 2013|language=French}}</ref> in which [[Claudine Glot]], [[Nicolas Mezzalira]] et [[Séverine Pineaux]] participated.<ref>[[TF1]], JT de 13 heures, 19 février 2012, « Zoom sur Rennes » : La forêt de Brocéliande</ref> The Centre de l'imaginaire arthurien has participated in shooting five other documentaries. The first, dedicated to the Forest of Brocéliande, was presented by [[Patrick Poivre d'Arvor]].<ref>Philippe le Guillou, Yvon Boëlle et [[Patrick Poivre d’Arvor]], ''Brocéliande ou l’obscur des forêts'', 12 min</ref> The Centre also interviewed [[John Boorman]],<ref>Serge Aillery (interview by Christian Rolland and Claudine Glot), John Boorman, FR3 Bretagne, 26 min, {{fr icon}}</ref> interviewed [[Christian-Joseph Guyonvarc'h]] twice<ref>Laurent Després, Les dieux des Celtes, entretien avec le Professeur Guyonvarc’h, FR3 Bretagne, 18 min, {{fr icon}}</ref>{{,}},<ref>Patrick Villechaize, La société celtique, entretien avec le Professeur Guyonvarc'h, FR3 Bretagne, 13 min, {{fr icon}}.</ref> an interview with [[François Bourgeon]] by Pierre Dubois,<ref>François Bourgeon and Roger Bendayan, interview par Pierre Dubois, FR3 Bretagne, 6 min, {{fr icon}}.</ref> a presentation of the legends of Brocéliande<ref>Jean-Max Peteau, Légendes de Brocéliande, 35 min.</ref> and an interview with Claudine Glot.<ref>Konan Mevel, Brocéliande, entretien avec Claudine Glot, 26 min.</ref>
Among the most prestigious visiters, the Centre includes [[Mario Vargas Llosa]] (who is a great admirer of chivalric romance)<ref name="InterviewCG"/>), [[Hugo Pratt]], [[Jean Raspail]], [[Laurent Voulzy]], [[Jéromine Pasteur]], [[Sylvain Tesson]], [[Nolwenn Leroy]] and [[Patrick Poivre d'Arvor]].<ref name="Histso"/> Between 1988 and 2010, there were more than {{formatnum:300000}} visiters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evene.fr/culture/lieux/centre-de-l-imaginaire-arthurien-7683.php|title=Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien|publisher=Evene|accessdate=4 January 2013|language=French}}</ref> Between 1990 and 1996, the Centre's official website received 130 000 visiters, 26 000 people were guided through the Forest and 600 classes held (25 000 visitors, 180 classes and 7 000 people guided through the Forest in the single year of 1996).<ref name="Histso">{{cite web|url=http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/centrearthurien_2.html|title=L'histoire du centre arthurien|publisher=Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien|accessdate=14 October 2010|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101001081709/http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/centrearthurien_2.html|archivedate=1 October 2010|df=}}</ref>
The [[Petit Futé]] rommends, "Especially take the time to devote a long afternoon to discovering the Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien, and appreciate the beauty of the exhibits as well as exploring the libraries".<ref name="UtBretagne"/> The [[Guide du Routard]] mentions the "rich exhibitions"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.routard.com/guide_agenda_detail/4688/semaines_arthuriennes_dans_la_foret_de_broceliande.htm|title=Semaines arthuriennes dans la forêt de Brocéliande|publisher=Routard.com|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref> et d'un lieu où légendes et histoire se mélangent, où l'environnement participe à l'envolée de l'imagination.<ref>{{it icon}} ''Normandia e Bretagna - Guide Routard'', Touring Editore, 2004, {{ISBN|8836530249}}, p. 344</ref> The [[MTV]] guide mentions the Centre as a, "lieu propice à l'imagination et au voyage dans le temps, soulignant par ailleurs le très bon rapport qualité-prix des visites au Château de Comper" (''a suitable place for the imagination and to travel time, further underlining the great value of visits to the Château de Comper'').<ref>Anna E. Brooke, Nathalie Jordi, Lauren Sommer et Anna Sussman, ''MTV France'', volume 6 de MTV Guides: France, John Wiley & Sons, 2007, {{ISBN|0764587706}}, p. 248</ref> The Société d'histoire et d'archéologie de l'arrondissement de Saint-Malo has also hailed the quality of the exhibitions.<ref>Société d'histoire et d'archéologie de l'arrondissement de Saint-Malo, ''Annales'', 1996, p. 296</ref>
==Éditions Artus== Éditions Artus existed prior to the foundation of the Centre de l'Imaginaire Arthurien, its origin was in the journal of the same name published by the future founders of the Centre. Published from 1979 to 1986, it contained in-depth articles devoted to the Celtic and Nordic countries in the fields of art, legends or history. The editorial board of the journal offered fine art books and research on these themes as well as postcards of drawings by [[Gustave Doré]] and the Breton landscape.<ref name="Artus">{{cite web|url=http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/artus.html|title=Artus|publisher=Centre de l'imaginaire arthurien|accessdate=4 January 2013|language=French|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130213013859/http://www.centre-arthurien-broceliande.com/artus.html|archivedate=13 February 2013|df=}}</ref>

{{multiple issues| {{notability|Events|date=August 2013}} {{unreferenced|date=August 2013}} }} {{Infobox recurring event | logo = [[File:Logo-e-commerce-asia scalewidthdownonly 235.jpg]] | image = | imagesize = | caption = | date = | begins = | ends = | frequency = | location = [[AsiaWorld-Expo]],
Hong Kong | years_active = | first = 27–28 March 2013 | participants = ~140 | attendance = ~300 | genre = | budget = | patron = | organised = Comexposium | website = {{URL|http://www.ecom-asia.com/}} | footnotes = }} '''E-Commerce Asia''' is a [[business conference]] and [[trade fair]] at [[AsiaWorld-Expo]] in [[Hong Kong]]. The subject of the event is [[e-commerce]] in [[Asia-Pacific]]. Presentations at the conference cover such topics as [[social commerce]], [[digital marketing]], [[mobile commerce]], [[customer relationship management]], and [[free and open-source software]]. E-Commerce Asia is organised by Comexposium, a joint venture of Exposium and Comexpo. E-Commerce Asia 2013 was co-promoted with Cartes Asia, another e-commerce conference in Hong Kong. Among the attending merchants were TMall, 51buy, [[360buy]], and [[China UnionPay]]. Comexposium organizes an annual European e-commerce conference, E-Commerce Paris. Comexposium is a member of the [[Paris Chamber of Commerce]], and is a subsidiary of the [[Unibail-Rodamco]] group. ==See also== * [[Bled eConference]] * [[Business networking]] * [[Etail Conferences]] * [[Online shopping]] == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.ecom-asia.com/}} * [http://en.comexposium.com/ Comexposium] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121222015920/http://www.asiaworld-expo.com/html/en/default.html AsiaWorld Expo] [[Category:Computer conferences]] [[Category:Trade fairs in Hong Kong]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use British English|date=June 2015}} {{about|the 1984 rail accident|the 1941 accident|Eccles rail crash (1941)}} {{Infobox rail accident | title = Eccles rail crash (1984) | image = 45147 at Patricroft after the Eccles rail crash.jpg | caption = | date = 4 December 1984 | time = 10:37 | location = [[Eccles, Greater Manchester]] | coordinates = | country = England | line = [[Liverpool to Manchester Line]] | operator = | type = Collision | cause = Driver's error | trains = 2 | pax = | deaths = 3 | injuries = 68 | footnotes = [[List of rail accidents in the United Kingdom|List of UK rail accidents by year]] }}
The '''1984 Eccles rail crash''' occurred on 4 December 1984 at [[Eccles, Greater Manchester]], when an express passenger train collided at speed with the rear of a freight train of [[oil tank]]ers. The driver of the express and two passengers were killed, and 68 people were injured. The cause of the accident was determined to be that the driver of the express train had [[Signal passed at danger|passed a signal at danger]].<ref>[http://www.railwaysarchive.co.uk/documents/DoT_Eccles1984.pdf Accident Enquiry Report] Retrieved on 2007-05-05</ref>
== The accident == The passenger train involved was 1E79, the 10:05 service from [[Liverpool]] to [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]], formed of a [[British Rail Class 45|Class 45]] [[diesel locomotive]] No.45147, seven passenger coaches and a parcels van. The freight train was 6E85, the 09:00 service from [[Stanlow Refinery|Stanlow Oil Refinery]], [[Ellesmere Port]] to [[Leeds]], composed of a [[British Rail Class 47|Class 47]] locomotive No.47310 and fifteen [[Tank car|tanker wagons]] containing [[fuel oil]].
The freight train had just passed [[Eccles railway station|Eccles station]] and was starting to accelerate away when the passenger train, having passed both the Eccles [[distant signal]] at caution and [[home signal]] at danger, collided heavily with its rear. It was estimated that the freight train was travelling at about 10 mph, whilst the passenger train's speed was between 45 and 50 mph.
The force of the collision threw the rearmost tanker to the side, but the next two wagons were thrown into the air, with one falling back onto the passenger locomotive. The wagons were badly damaged and escaping fuel oil was ignited by the hot exhaust gases of the locomotive, setting fire to it and the leading two coaches. Fortunately, the leading coach was empty of passengers or the death toll would probably have been much higher. However, the express driver and one passenger were killed instantly, whilst another passenger succumbed to injuries a month later. A number of people received impact injuries and burns and many were also treated for smoke inhalation. Rescue efforts were assisted by the location of the accident, which was adjacent to the [[M602 motorway]], enabling easy access for emergency services.
== The inquiry == The inquiry into the accident was inconclusive. There had been problems with the signalling in the area, and [[track circuit]]s had been affected by a maintenance gang working on the track nearby, but the inspector was satisfied that the signals which had been passed at danger were working properly and showing the correct aspects. They were, however, not fitted with the [[Automatic Warning System|AWS]] warning system to alert the driver to his error. In the absence of any conflicting medical evidence, the inquiry was forced to conclude that the driver had simply allowed his attention to wander and had missed the Eccles signals – it was testified by staff that it was rare for these signals to be at danger.
The report recommended that these signals be fitted with AWS, work which was quickly completed. The home signal was also fitted with a white back plate, in order to make it more visible against the road bridge that stands behind it.<ref name="Hall">{{cite book | first=Stanley | last=Hall | year=1987 | title=Danger Signals: an investigation into modern railway accidents | publisher= Ian Allan | isbn= 0-7110-1704-2}}</ref>
== References == <references />
{{coord|53.4847|-2.3209|display=title|region:GB|format=dms}}
{{1984 railway accidents}}
[[Category:Railway accidents and incidents in Greater Manchester]] [[Category:Railway accidents in 1984]] [[Category:1984 in England]] [[Category:Eccles, Greater Manchester]] [[Category:Disasters in Greater Manchester]] [[Category:20th century in Greater Manchester]] [[Category:Railway accidents involving a disregarded signal]] [[Category:Accidents and incidents involving British Rail]] [[Category:December 1984 events]] [[Category:Train collisions in England]] [[Category:Rail accidents caused by a driver's error]]

'''Employment fraud''' is an attempt to defraud people who are seeking or performing [[employment]] by giving them a false hope of better employment, often with higher [[wage]]s. Employment fraud involves activities such as fraudulent representation of income to a borrower who claims [[self-employment]] in a non-existent company. It also includes a small number of hours paired with a lot of free time.<ref>In-text: (Definitions.uslegal.com, 2014) Bibliography: Definitions.uslegal.com, (2014). Employment Fraud Law & Legal Definition. [online] Available at: http://definitions.uslegal.com/e/employment-fraud/ [Accessed 29 Oct. 2014].</ref>
==Fraud== Recruitment [[fraud]] involves persons misrepresenting themselves as acting on behalf of an employer to offer fictitious job opportunities. The fraud is generally conducted through the [[internet]].
===Identifying fraudulent and fictitious job offers===
The company name and/or logo may be included (without authority) on the [[documentation]]. There are usually various requests for personal information, such as passport details, bank details.
Genuine employers do not request money transfers or [[payment]]s from applicants to secure a job, either as an employee or as a contractor.<ref>Lundin-petroleum.com, (2014). Employment Fraud - Lundin Petroleum. [online] Available at: http://www.lundin-petroleum.com/eng/recruitment_fraud.php [Accessed 29 Oct. 2014].</ref>
===Examples of fraud===
*Stealing money from the company bank account – the [[perpetrator]] having got away with this once, will try it again and again. *Manipulating sales figures so as to reach target and achieve bonus – a simple version of this involves booking sales in one month then crediting them back the next. Naturally, unless the perpetrator keeps this up, the overstatement in one month will be shown as a shortfall in the next. *Theft of stock – a time-honored way to make a 'fast buck'. The perpetrator will over a period of time abscond with a number of items from the [[warehouse]], and resell these. So long as the stock losses are within [[tolerance interval|tolerance]] then it is possible for this to remain undetected for a significant period of time.<ref>Frost, K. (2012). Top ten types of fraud. [online] Metro. Available at: http://metro.co.uk/2012/10/09/top-ten-types-fraud-3817034/ [Accessed 29 Oct. 2014].</ref> *Any advertising or [[promotion (marketing)|promotion]] that misrepresents the nature, characteristics, qualities or geographic origin of goods, services or commercial activities which lures unsuspecting victims into a situation where, out of desperation or lack of knowledge, they are tricked into committing a [[crime]] or become a victim of a crime such as [[identity theft]], [[embezzlement]] or similar types of [[fraud]].<ref>TheFreeDictionary.com, (2014). False Advertising. [online] Available at: http://legal-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/False+Advertising [Accessed 31 Oct. 2014].</ref>
===Types of employment scam===
====Mystery shopper==== The victim applies to be a mystery shopper. They are asked to test a money wiring service such as Western Union, and to report back on the experience. In reality, they are helping to launder money and could be open to charges of being a money mule.
====Payment administration==== The victim is asked to handle payments on behalf of an overseas company, earning a fee for every payment handled. the companies turn out to be a front for illegal activity – again potentially landing the victim in trouble with the law.
====Guaranteed employment/income scams==== The victim is guaranteed a certain level of income or employment. To get this they first have to buy something like a business plan, start-up materials or software. They may also be asked to pay money to be put on a directory to 'guarantee' jobs. This is in fact merely a way to get the victim to spend money – there is no job waiting at the end.
====Multi-level marketing==== People selling through a multi-level marketing scheme get [[commission (remuneration)|commission]] on the sales of those they recruit, as well as on their own sales. Some multi-level marketing schemes, like selling Tupperware, are legitimate business models. But some multi-level marketing schemes are [[pyramid scheme]]s in disguise. The products are of poor quality, overpriced and hard to sell, or the victim may be asked to spend a great deal of money on training materials that are completely useless.
====Visa/work permits==== A prospective [[employer]] overseas says that they'll handle the victim's work visa application. But the victim has to send them the money to process it. Again, this will simply result in the scammer taking the money and vanishing.<ref>Cps.gov.uk, (2014). Fraud Act: Legal Guidance: The Crown Prosecution Service. [online] Available at: http://www.cps.gov.uk/legal/d_to_g/fraud_act/ [Accessed 28 Oct. 2014].</ref>
====How to resolve the issue==== If employment fraud is suspected, one should seek legal advice immediately. Whilst the main aim will be to obtain evidence that will stand up in court, one should proceed with caution. There is a risk of being taken to an employment [[tribunal]] should one's suspicions prove incorrect or should one act in a way that breaches an employee's employment law rights. In addition, the way one gathers evidence or checks personal data on employees must comply with the Human Rights Act and the Data Protection Act. Employers should always carry out a full identity check on any new employee.<ref>Nelsonslaw.co.uk, (2014). Employee Fraud: Warning SignsSolicitors: Nottingham, Leicester and Derby UK. [online] Available at: http://www.nelsonslaw.co.uk/site/library/commercialclient/employee_fraud.html [Accessed 29 Oct. 2014].</ref>
==Employment trends==
===Crime and fraud issues in international trade=== Theft of goods, money laundering, cyber crime, employee fraud, infringement of intellectual property. Businesses in international trade face a growing threat from crime. Fraud is deceit for financial profit and has cost the UK economy more than £38 billion in the past year (source: National Fraud Authority – annual fraud indicators January 2011). Currently the main threat to international traders is fraud from organised crime, including theft of your goods or your business identity, cross-border crime and road-freight crime. Other risks include infringement of intellectual property or employee fraud.<ref>Gov.uk, (2014). Investigations and enforcement: what we do, our outcomes and complaints - GOV.UK. [online] Available at: https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/insolvency-service-investigations-and-enforcement-what-we-do-our-outcomes-and-complaints [Accessed 29 Oct. 2014].</ref> The rise in online trading has created new forms of criminal activity, such as new ways of laundering money. Businesses in the EU can rely on shared laws and commercial procedures to protect them. This action-based guide explains the key risks involved, how to reduce them, and what to do if their business is targeted.<ref>Gov.uk, (2012). Crime and fraud prevention for businesses in international trade - Detailed guidance - GOV.UK. [online] Available at: https://www.gov.uk/crime-and-fraud-prevention-for-businesses-in-international-trade [Accessed 29 Oct. 2014].</ref>

[[File:MUJA-Tyrannosaurus.JPG|thumb|right|300px|[[Tyrannosaurus]] fossil exhibit in [[Jurassic Museum of Asturias]], Spain.]] '''Exhibit design''' (or '''exhibition design'''<ref>{{cite book | title=Exhibition Design | publisher=[[W. W. Norton & Company]] | author=Dernie, David | year=2006 | isbn=978-0-393-73211-5}}</ref>) is the process of developing an exhibit—from a concept through to a physical, three-dimensional exhibition. It is a continually evolving field, drawing on innovative, creative, and practical solutions to the challenge of developing communicative environments that ‘tell a story’ in a three-dimensional space.<ref>[http://www.lincoln.ac.uk/home/course/xmdxmdma/ MA Design for Exhibition and Museum], [[University of Lincoln]], UK.</ref>
[[Exhibit designer]]s (or [[exhibition designer]]s) use a wide range of technologies and techniques to develop experiences that will resonate with diverse audiences–enabling these targeted audiences to access the messages, stories and objects of an exhibit. There are many different types of exhibit, ranging from museum exhibitions, to retail and trades show spaces, to themed attractions, zoos, and visitor centers. All types of exhibits aim to communicate a message through engaging their audiences in meaningful and compelling interactions.
Exhibit design is a collaborative process, integrating the disciplines of [[architecture]], [[landscape architecture]], [[graphic design]], [[audiovisual]] engineering, [[digital media]], [[lighting designer|lighting]], [[interior design]], and content development to develop an audience experience that interprets information, involves and engages a user and influences their understanding of a subject.<ref>Lee Skolnick, [[Jan Lorenc]], and Craig Berger, ''What is Exhibition Design?'' 2007.</ref> Throughout the planning and design process, exhibit designers work closely with [[graphic designers]], content specialists, [[architects]], fabricators, technical specialists, audiovisual experts, and, in the case of museums and other [[mission statement|mission]]-based institutions, stakeholders like community members, government agencies, and other partner organizations.
The exhibit design process builds on a conceptual or [[interpretive planning|interpretive plan]] for an exhibit, determining the most effective, engaging and appropriate methods of communicating a message or telling a story. The process will often mirror the architectural process or schedule, moving from conceptual plan, through schematic design, design development, contract document, fabrication, and installation. The first phases establish a thematic direction and develop creative and appropriate design solutions to achieve the interpretive and communication goals of the exhibit. The latter phases employ technical expertise in translating the visual language of the designs into detailed documents that provide all the specifications required to fabricate and install an exhibit.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://rowman.com/ISBN/9781442230170/Museums-101|title=Museums 101|last=Walhimer|first=Mark|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=2015|isbn=9781442230187|location=|pages=|via=}}</ref> [[File:Exhibition 2013- National Museum of Iran-Darband cave-stone tools.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Showcase containing two stone tools from the Lower Paleolithic cave site of Darband, Exhibition, National Museum of Iran.]]
Exhibition design in different parts of the world are influenced by the local culture as well as the availability of materials. Exhibition design in Europe is considered as a meeting place for relationship building while in North America energy is spent on creating a sense of place and building community.
One of the major shifts in museum and exhibit design in the last decade has been a focus on visitor experience. By identifying the five types of museum visitors and their needs and expectations, museums can design their exhibits to give a positive visitor experience.<ref>John Falk, ''Identity and the museum visitor experience''2009.</ref> Participatory activities are also becoming more popular, Nina Simon has done research describing and identifying themes and trends in museums that will attract visitors and educate them in fun and engaging ways. <ref>Nina Simon, ''The Participatory Museum'' 2010.</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox song | name = Friday | cover = Rebecca Black - Friday.png | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Rebecca Black]] | album = | released = March 14, 2011{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/friday-single/id426285657 |title=Friday - Single by Rebecca Black |publisher=[[iTunes Store]]|accessdate=May 6, 2016}} | format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | recorded = December 18, 2010 in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]Rebecca (June 28, 2013). {{YouTube|zwSflBfu_Nc|DRAW MY LIFE - REBECCA BLACK}}. Accessed on August 4, 2013. | studio = | venue = | genre = | length = 3:30 (single release)
3:44 (music video version with rap) | label = [[ARK Music Factory]] | writer = [[Clarence Jey]], [[Patrice Wilson]] | producer = Clarence Jey, Patrice Wilson, Charlie Walk | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = [[My Moment (Rebecca Black song)|My Moment]] | next_year = 2011 | misc = {{External music video|{{YouTube|kfVsfOSbJY0|"Rebecca Black - Friday"}}}} }} "'''Friday'''" is a song by American singer [[Rebecca Black]], written and produced by [[Los Angeles]] record producers [[Clarence Jey]] and [[Patrice Wilson]]. It was released by [[ARK Music Factory]] as Black's debut single on March 14, 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/2011/03/14/rebecca_black_friday_horror/|title=What's behind the "Worst music video ever"? |last=Williams|first=Mary Elizabeth |work=[[Salon.com]]|date=March 14, 2011|accessdate=May 20, 2012}} The song features a rap verse from Wilson, which was uncredited on the single. Its music video caught a sudden surge of hits after ''[[Mystery Science Theater 3000]]'' and [[Rifftrax]] comedian [[Michael J. Nelson]] called it "the worst video ever made" on [[Twitter]] and the song was featured on the ''[[Tosh.0]]'' blog.{{cite web|last=Allocca|first=Kevin|title=The Rebecca Black Phenomenon|url=http://youtube-trends.blogspot.com/2011/03/rebecca-black-phenomenon.html|work=YouTube Trends|publisher=Google|accessdate=January 18, 2012}}{{cite news|newspaper=[[National Post]]|last=Baldwin|first=Stephen|title=Five things you need to know about Rebecca Black’s Friday|url=http://arts.nationalpost.com/2011/03/17/five-things-you-need-to-know-about-rebecca-blacks-friday/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130629225701/http://arts.nationalpost.com/2011/03/17/five-things-you-need-to-know-about-rebecca-blacks-friday/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=June 29, 2013|date=March 17, 2011}}{{cite news|title= How Rebecca Black Became a YouTube Sensation|author= Wasserman, Todd|newspaper= [[Mashable]]|date=March 24, 2011|url= http://mashable.com/2011/03/16/rebecca-black-youtube/|accessdate=March 31, 2011}} The song's original reception was highly negative, but it has since become a cult classic, covered by numerous artists and comedians. The original video was removed from [[YouTube]] on June 16, 2011, due to [[legal dispute]]s between ARK Music and Black herself. By then, it had already amassed more than 166 million views.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UgrCGkwJMu0 |title=YouTube's 100 Most Viewed Videos (5/30/2011) |publisher=YouTube |date=May 31, 2011 |accessdate=October 1, 2016}}. The video was uploaded to YouTube again on September 16, 2011. Since the growth in popularity of the song and video, there have been numerous parody videos and remixes.{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/technology-news/who-is-rebecca-black-and-is-she-really-bigger-than-japan-20110315-1bvkj.html|title=Who is Rebecca Black? And is she really bigger than Japan? |last=Gallo |first=Lee-Maree|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=March 15, 2011|accessdate=March 15, 2011}} ''[[Forbes]]'' stated that the notoriety of the song is another sign of the power of social media—specifically Twitter, [[Facebook]], and [[Tumblr]], in this instance—in the ability to create "overnight sensations."Pasetsky, Mark. [https://blogs.forbes.com/markpasetsky/2011/03/14/rebecca-black-why-is-she-trending-on-twitter/ Rebecca Black: Why is She Trending on Twitter?]. ''[[Forbes]]''. 2011-03-14. Retrieved March 14, 2011.Perpetua, Matthew. [https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/why-rebecca-blacks-much-mocked-viral-hit-friday-is-actually-good-20110315 Why Rebecca Black's Much-Mocked Viral Hit 'Friday' Is Actually Good]. ''[[Rolling Stone]]''. 2011-03-15. Retrieved March 15, 2011. ==Background and production== "Friday" co-writer Patrice Wilson, a worker at Ark Music Factory, explained that he wrote the lyrics "on a Thursday night going into a Friday. I was writing different songs all night and was like, 'Wow, I've been up a long time and it's Friday.' And I was like, wow, it is Friday!"{{cite web|url=http://gawker.com/#!5787213/meet-the-man-responsible-for-rebecca-black |title=Meet the Man responsible for Rebecca Black |last=Chen |first=Adrian |work=[[Gawker]] |publisher=Gawker Media |date=March 30, 2011 |accessdate=March 31, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110401011921/http://gawker.com/ |archivedate=April 1, 2011 |df=mdy }}{{cite web|url =http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2011/03/friday_mastermind_patrice_wils.html|title ='Friday' mastermind Patrice Wilson explains the lyrics|last =Barshad|first =Amor|work =[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|publisher =New York Media Holdings|date=March 30, 2011|accessdate=March 31, 2011}} An Ark Music Factory client told Black's mother about the company's production services in late 2010; Black was 13 at the time, and living in the [[Anaheim Hills]] [[planned community]] in [[Anaheim, California]].{{cite news | url=http://articles.ocregister.com/2011-03-17/news/29143204_1_music-video-history-of-pop-music-song-and-video | title=O.C.'s Rebecca Black talks about 'Friday' | accessdate=March 21, 2011 | author=Larsen, Peter | date=March 17, 2011 | publisher=Orange County Register}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-03-17/rebecca-black-friday-and-cyberbullying/|title=Rebecca Black: 'I'm Being Cyberbullied'|last=Lee|first=Chris|date=March 17, 2011|work=The Daily Beast|accessdate=March 18, 2011}} Black's mother, Georgina Kelly, paid Ark Music $4,000 for a song and accompanying video that included a choice of two pre-written songs. According to Kelly, the payment covered one half or less of the production costs of the music video, and Black's family could have paid nothing in exchange for giving up all rights to the song.{{r|larsen20110317}}{{cite news | url=http://www.ocregister.com/entertainment/rebecca-293983-straight-black.html| title=Rebecca Black's mom sets the record straight on Leno lip-sync rumors | accessdate=March 31, 2011 | author=Larsen, Peter | date=March 29, 2011 | publisher=[[Orange County Register]]}} Black chose "Friday", as "the other song was about adult love – I haven't experienced that yet. I felt like it was my personality in that song."{{cite web | url=http://blogdailyherald.com/2011/03/18/finally-friday/ | title=Finally "Friday" | accessdate=April 6, 2011 | author=Levison, Sam | date=March 18, 2011 | work=Blog Daily Herald}}{{cite news|last=Lee|first=Chris|title=Rebecca Black: 'I'm Being Cyberbullied'|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/03/17/rebecca-black-friday-and-cyberbullying.html|accessdate=11 November 2012|newspaper=The Daily Beast|date=17 March 2011}} Ark Music extensively used the pitch-correcting software [[Auto-Tune]].Sloame, Joanne. [http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music/2011/03/15/2011-03-15_rebecca_black_friday_youtube_viral_video_pales_in_comparison_to_justin_bieber_hi.html Rebecca Black 'Friday' YouTube viral video pales in comparison to Justin Bieber hits]. ''[[New York Daily News]]''. 2011-03-15. Retrieved March 15, 2011. Although Kelly had some doubts over the quality of the lyrics, Black assured her that "I sang it as they wrote it, Mom." ==Composition== {{listen | filename = Rebecca Black Friday Clip.ogg | title = "Friday" | description = A 22-second sample of "Friday" featuring the chorus where Black sings, "Friday, Friday, gotta get down on Friday". | pos = right }} "Friday" uses the [[50s progression]], an I-VI-IV-V [[chord progression]] that many popular songs have used such as "[[Heart and Soul (1938 song)|Heart and Soul]]" and "[[Unchained Melody]]". It is performed in the key of B major at a [[tempo]] of 112 beats per minute. According to Randy Lewis of ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', the familiar structure contributes to the song's catchiness, making it what others have called an [[earworm]].{{cite news | url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2011/03/rebecca-black-friday-youtube-patrice-wilson.html | title=Rebecca Black's 'Friday': There are a million good reasons you can't get it out of your head | accessdate=March 31, 2011 | author=Lewis, Randy | date=March 31, 2011 | publisher=Los Angeles Times}} The song also sees Black on a [[harmony]] track.{{cite web|url =http://www.orangecounty.com/entertainment/rebecca-17844-straight-black.html|title =Rebecca Black's mom sets the record straight on Leno lip-sync rumors|last =Larsen|first =Peter|date =March 28, 2011|publisher =OrangeCounty.com|accessdate =April 19, 2011}} In a review for ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', writer Matthew Perpetua described the vocals as having "a peculiar tonality that inadvertently highlights the absurdity of boilerplate pop lyrics," adding that the tone in the refrain "sounds unlike anything else in pop music." He noted the sound as being not entirely agreeable to listen to, but stated that Black ultimately ends up "sounding like a distinct singer with an alluring sort of anti-charisma." The lyrics of the song speak about "hanging out with friends and having fun."{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1660469/rebecca-black-tonight-show.jhtml|title=Rebecca Black Says Internet Haters Don't 'Bug' Her Anymore|last=Kaufman|first=Gil|date=March 23, 2011|work=MTV.com|accessdate=March 31, 2011}} The lyrics reflect the happenings of a day, in the life of a teenager like Black, like eating breakfast and going to school. "She's excited 'cause it's Friday. Which means a weekend full of possibility awaits," a ''[[Plugged In]]'' reviewer concluded.{{cite web|url =http://www.pluggedin.com/music/tracks/2011/rebeccablack-friday.aspx|title =Friday – Rebecca Black|work =[[Plugged In]]|publisher =[[Focus on the Family]]|date =March 14, 2011|last =Asay|first =Paul|accessdate =April 9, 2011}} ==Critical reception== {{Wikinews|'Worst song of all time' becomes YouTube sensation}} The song has received almost universally negative reviews from music critics, for its songwriting, instrumentation, Black's singing voice, and the video choreography. Lyndsey Parker of ''[[Yahoo!|Yahoo! Music]]'' asked if it could be "[[List of music considered the worst|the worst song ever]]."{{cite news |url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/blogs/videogaga/71429/is-youtube-sensation-rebecca-blacks-friday-the-worst-song-ever/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110322133013/http://new.music.yahoo.com/blogs/videogaga/71429/is-youtube-sensation-rebecca-blacks-friday-the-worst-song-ever/|archivedate=March 22, 2011 |title=Is YouTube Sensation Rebecca Black's "Friday" The Worst Song Ever?|last=Parker|first=Lyndsey|work=[[Yahoo!|Yahoo! Music]]|date=March 14, 2011|accessdate=1 March 2016}} On March 29, 2011, it surpassed [[Justin Bieber]]'s "[[Baby (Justin Bieber song)|Baby]]" as the most disliked YouTube video, with 1.17 million dislikes,{{cite web|last=Matyszczyk|first=Chris|title=Rebecca Black passes Bieber as YouTube's most hated video|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17852_3-20048534-71.html|work=CNET News|publisher=[[CNET]]|accessdate=March 30, 2011}}{{Cite news|last=Skarda|first=Erin|title=Rebecca Black Passes Justin Bieber as Most 'Disliked' on YouTube|publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/03/30/rebecca-black-passes-justin-bieber-as-most-disliked-on-youtube/|accessdate=April 2, 2011|date=March 30, 2011}} and once had over 3 million "dislikes", accounting for 88% of the total ratings of the video. The video was later removed, although it has since been officially re-uploaded.Youtube - {{YouTube|kfVsfOSbJY0|Rebecca Black - Friday - Official Music Video}} The co-writer and producer of "Friday", Clarence Jey, said about the song that "the concept we feel seems to have crossed a lot of boundaries, for the better or worse." Observers have called it "bizarre," "inept," and "hilariously dreadful."{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/14/rebecca-blacks-friday_n_835495.html|title=Rebecca Black's 'Friday' Becomes Internet Sensation (VIDEO)|last=Hroncich|first=Patrick|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=March 14, 2011|accessdate=March 14, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2011/03/14/rebecca-black-friday-music-video/ |title=Rebecca Black's 'Friday': The Internet's latest bizarre music video obsession|last=Lynch|first=Joseph Brannigan|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=March 14, 2011|accessdate=March 14, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/03/14/rebecca-blacks-bizarrely-bad-video-for-friday-is-this-for-real/|title=Rebecca Black's Bizarrely Bad Video for 'Friday': Is This For Real? |last=Gibson|first=Megan |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=March 14, 2011|accessdate=March 14, 2011}} The song and Black herself were "savaged" on social networks across the Internet,Lee, Ann. [http://www.metro.co.uk/music/858162-rebecca-black-savaged-on-twitter-over-youtube-hit-video-friday Rebecca Black savaged on Twitter over YouTube hit video Friday]. ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]''. 2011-03-15. Retrieved March 15, 2011. while being seen as a "YouTube laughing stock."{{cite news|last=Holland|first=Tina|title=What\'s this talk of a feud between Demi Lovato, Selena Gomez and Rebecca Black?|url=http://www.metrowny.com/editorial/470-Whats_this_talk_of_a_feud_between_Demi_Lovato,_Selena_Gomez_and_Rebecca_Black.html|accessdate=November 10, 2012|newspaper=Metro WNY|date=March 19, 2011|location=Cheektowaga NY}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} On YouTube, the video was met with negative comments and video responses, including comments interpreted as "violent".{{YouTube|qaYvhblaIAM|Rebecca Black Receives Death Threats}} [[ABC News]] Kevin Rutherford, a columnist for [[Billboard magazine|Billboard]] magazine, wrote, "Black's video for 'Friday' is one of those rare occurrences where even the most seasoned critics of Internet culture don't know where to begin. From the singing straight out of Auto-Tuned hell to lyrics such as 'Tomorrow is Saturday / And Sunday comes afterwards / I don't want this weekend to end' and a hilariously bad rap about passing school buses, 'Friday' is something that simply must be seen and heard to be fully appreciated."{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/viral-videos/472547/rebecca-blacks-friday-a-viral-sensation-for-all-the-wrong|title=Rebecca Black's 'Friday' a Viral Sensation for All the Wrong Reasons |last=Rutherford|first=Kevin|date=March 14, 2011|work=Billboard.com|accessdate=March 15, 2011}} Many other reviewers also singled out the lyrics in particular for criticism,{{cite web|url=http://www.b2cmarketinginsider.com/entertainment/rebecca-black-and-the-art-of-being-bad-019477|title=Rebecca Black and the Art of Being Bad|last=Ribeiro |first=Ricky|date=March 16, 2011|work=b2cmarketinginsider.com|accessdate=March 17, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.b2cmarketinginsider.com/entertainment/rebecca-black-so-bad-its-a-viral-hit-rebecca-blacks-friday-019184|title=Rebecca Black: So Bad It’s a Viral Hit; Rebecca Black’s "Friday"|date=March 15, 2011|work=b2cmarketinginsider.com|accessdate=March 17, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130117135345/http://www.b2cmarketinginsider.com/entertainment/rebecca-black-so-bad-its-a-viral-hit-rebecca-blacks-friday-019184|archivedate=January 17, 2013|df=mdy-all}} which were described as "overly simple and repetitive" by [[TNT (magazine)|''TNT Magazine'']].{{cite web|url=http://www.tntmagazine.com/tnt-today/archive/2011/03/16/rebecca-black-worst-song-friday-tops-japan-earthquake.aspx|title=Rebecca Black: 'worst song' Friday tops Japan earthquake + VIDEO|date=March 16, 2011|work=TNT|accessdate=March 17, 2011}} Jim Edwards of [[BNET]] and Doug Gross of [[CNN]] both noted that the rap break from the considerably older rapper was "creepy."''{{cite web|url=http://www.bnet.com/blog/advertising-business/worst-video-ever-how-rebecca-black-8217s-8220friday-8221-explains-the-future-of-pop-music/7898|title=Worst Video Ever? How Rebecca Black’s "Friday" Explains the Future of Pop Music|last=Edwards|first=Jim|date=March 16, 2011|accessdate=March 17, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.kansascity.com/2011/03/16/2729365/rebecca-blacks-friday-goes-viral.html|title=Rebecca Black's 'Friday' goes viral for all the wrong reasons|last=Gross|first=Doug|date=March 16, 2011|work=Kansas City Star|accessdate=March 17, 2011}} ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' ''ranked it number two on a list of "Top 10 Songs with Silly Lyrics."''{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/completelist/0,29569,2059182,00.html|title=Top 10 Songs with Silly Lyrics|accessdate=April 2, 2011|date=March 16, 2011|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''}}{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2059182_2059179_2059215,00.html|title=Top 10 Songs with Silly Lyrics (2. Rebecca Black, 'Friday')|accessdate=April 2, 2011|date=March 16, 2011|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''}}'' Despite the overwhelmingly negative reviews, a few reviewers had terrible things to say about the song and video. ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' writer Joseph Lynch noted that there was "something sickeningly catchy about this tune that keeps you coming back for more." ''Rolling Stone'''s Perpetua stated, "When you see this video, you immediately notice everything that it does 'wrong', but it actually gets a lot of things about pop music right, if just by accident." ''[[OK!]]'' Magazine also noted that "some are calling the 13-year-old signed singer the next Justin Bieber."{{cite web|url=http://www.okmagazine.com/2011/03/rebecca-blacks-friday-best-youtube-cover-videos-and-no-bob-dylan-didnt-write-it/|title=Rebecca Black’s "Friday": Best YouTube Cover Videos (And No, Bob Dylan Didn’t Write It) |last=Talarico|first=Brittany|date=March 16, 2011|work=okmagazine.com|accessdate=March 17, 2011}} After watching the video, singer [[Chris Brown (American entertainer)|Chris Brown]] said: "Honest opinion? It was great. I'll be jammin' to it on ''Friday'', ''Friday''."{{cite web|title = Watch Chris Brown Watch the Rebecca Black 'Friday' Music Video|url = http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2011/03/chris_brown_friday.html|publisher = New York Media|accessdate=March 27, 2011|date=March 17, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2011/03/chris-brown-explains-nude-photo-weighs-in-on-rebecca-black/1|title=Chris Brown explains nude photo, weighs in on Rebecca Black|last=Oldenburg|first=Ann|date=March 18, 2011|work=USA Today|accessdate=March 18, 2011}} Fellow teenage singer [[Miley Cyrus]] denied that she had criticized Black, saying "I ''am'' a fan" and that she sang "Friday" while driving.{{cite news | url=http://www.eonline.com/uberblog/marc_malkin/b234395_miley_cyrus_misquoted_i_love_rebecca.html | title=Miley Cyrus Misquoted: "I Love Rebecca Black!" | accessdate=April 3, 2011 | author=Malec, Brett | date=April 2, 2011 | publisher=E!}} [[Simon Cowell]] praised Black, saying "I love her [and] the fact that she's got so much publicity. People are so upset about the song, but I think it's hysterical. [...] Anyone who can create this much controversy within a week, I want to meet. I love people like that."{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20475031,00.html|title=Rebecca Black's Biggest Fan – Simon Cowell!|date=March 18, 2011|author=Shira, Dahvi|work=People|accessdate=March 21, 2011}} He observed that "any song to do with the weekend annoys you. It reminds me of '[[Saturday Night (Whigfield song)|Saturday Night]]'... It's what we call a 'hair-dryer song,' a song girls sing into their [[hair dryer]]s as they're getting ready to go out. But the fact that it's making people so angry is ''brilliant''."{{cite news | url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2011/03/18/simon-cowell-x-factor-paula-abdul-la-reid-rebecca-black/ | title=Simon Cowell scoop: The 'X Factor' star talks L.A. Reid, Paula Abdul...and Rebecca Black | accessdate=March 21, 2011 | author=Karger, Dave | date=March 18, 2011 | publisher=Entertainment Weekly}} Cowell advised Black not to "listen to anyone over the age of 18. I'm being deadly serious. Whatever she's done has worked. Whether you like her or not, she's the most talked-about artist in America right now. Nobody over the age of 18 should understand her or like her.
