So she should just do it her way."{{cite news | url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2011/03/simon_cowell_1.html | title=Simon Cowell on The X Factor and the Only Contestant He Knows From This Season’s Idol | accessdate=March 26, 2011 | author=Adalian, Josef | date=March 25, 2011 | publisher=New York}} Patrice Wilson released his sequel to the song "Friday" on May 6, 2012, titled "Happy", focusing on Saturdays.{{cite web|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2012/5/prweb9479781.htm |title=The maker of Rebecca Black's "Friday," Patrice Wilson, releases the official sequel to "Friday" |publisher=Prweb.com |date=May 7, 2012 |accessdate=August 11, 2012}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7l8wZbqTww0&feature=uploademail |title=Patrice Wilson-Happy (The Official Sequel To Friday). |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=August 11, 2012}} Rebecca Black released her own sequel, entitled "[[Saturday (Rebecca Black song)|Saturday]]", in December 2013.{{cite web|url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2013/12/07/saturday-rebecca-black-friday-music-video/|title='Saturday': Rebecca Black releases follow-up song to 'Friday' - The Music Mix - EW.com|work=EW.com}}{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/rebecca-black-16-moves-on-from-friday-to-saturday-20131210-2z3qr.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=Rebecca Black, 16, moves on from Friday to Saturday}} ==Chart performance== By March 21, 2011, the "Friday" music video had been viewed more than 30 million times on YouTube.{{cite news |title= Rebecca Black 'Friday' music video and song could earn her hundreds of thousands of dollars |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music/2011/03/22/2011-03-22_rebecca_black_friday_music_video_and_song_could_earn_her_hundreds_of_thousands_o.html|last=Roberts |first=Soraya|work=[[NYDailyNews]]|date=March 22, 2011|accessdate=March 22, 2011|location=New York}} ''[[Forbes]]'' estimated that as of that date, Black and ARK Music had earned $20,000 from YouTube's revenue-sharing program,{{cite news | url=https://blogs.forbes.com/chrisbarth/2011/03/21/mock-rebecca-black-all-you-want-shes-laughing-to-the-bank/ | title=Mock Rebecca Black All You Want, She’s Laughing To The Bank | accessdate=March 21, 2011 | author=Barth, Chris | date=March 21, 2011 | publisher=Forbes}} and ''[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]'' estimated iTunes sales of approximately 43,000 copies, roughly equivalent to $26,700 in [[Royalties#Music|royalties]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/industry/digital-and-mobile/rebecca-black-s-first-week-sales-not-bad-1005084972.story|title=Rebecca Black's First-Week Sales: Not Bad, But Not In The Millions ...|date=March 22, 2011|first=Glenn|last=Peoples|work=[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|location=Nashville|accessdate=March 22, 2011}} Within a week after being released on [[iTunes]], it had jumped to 19 on their sales chart, on March 19, 2011.{{cite news |url=https://blogs.forbes.com/meghancasserly/2011/03/18/rebecca-black-andrea-canning-good-morning-america-friday/|title=Rebecca Black’s GMA Bullying: Best Friday Ever |last=Cassidy |first=Meghan|work=[[Forbes]]|date=March 18, 2011|accessdate=March 18, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.longislandpress.com/2011/03/20/rebecca-black-rebecca-black-friday/|title=Rebecca Black : Rebecca Black Friday|last=Sinclair|first=Jessica|work=[[Long Island Press]]|date=March 20, 2011|accessdate=March 21, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110322180659/http://www.longislandpress.com/2011/03/20/rebecca-black-rebecca-black-friday/|archivedate=March 22, 2011|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/social-media/8395876/Social-media-hatred-sends-Rebecca-Black-up-the-pop-charts.html|title=Social media hatred sends Rebecca Black up the pop charts|last=Barnett |first=Emma|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=March 21, 2011|accessdate=March 21, 2011 |location=London}} "Friday" debuted on the US [[Hot Digital Songs]] chart at number 57{{cite web|title=Billboard Hot Digital Tracks/Songs Biggest Gainers for April 2, 2011|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2011-04-02/digital-songs?order=gainer|work=Billboard|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=April 2, 2011}} and went on to peak at number 38.{{cite web|title=Billboard Hot Digital Tracks/Songs Biggest Falls for April 16, 2011|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2011-04-16/digital-songs?order=drop|work=Billboard|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=April 2, 2011}} "Friday" debuted on the [[New Zealand Singles Chart]] at number 33 on March 21, 2011. The song entered the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] at number 72 and rose to 58 the next week.{{Cite news|url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart_watch/74347/week-ending-march-27-2011-songs-katy-moves-up/|title=Week Ending March 27, 2011: Songs: Katy Moves Up|date=March 30, 2011|first=Paul|last=Grein|work=Chart Watch|publisher=[[Yahoo! Music]]|accessdate=March 30, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110404023202/http://new.music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart_watch/74347/week-ending-march-27-2011-songs-katy-moves-up|archivedate=April 4, 2011|df=mdy-all}} It sold 87,000 copies in the United States over its first two weeks and has gone on to sell 442,000 copies, as of December 2013.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5840354/rebecca-blacks-saturday-follows-friday-onto-hot-100 |title=Rebecca Black's 'Saturday' Follows 'Friday' Onto Hot 100 |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=December 18, 2013 |accessdate=December 18, 2013}} The song also received airplay in Sweden.{{cite web|title=Songlist Swedish P3|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/latlista.aspx?programid=164&date=2011-03-29|work=P3 Sverige|publisher=P3 Sverige|accessdate=March 29, 2011}} In the United States, it was played 12 times from March 16 to 22, considered low for a ''Hot 100'' song.{{cite web|title=Not *That* Fun: Rebecca Black Gets Played Just 12 Times on Radio|url=http://mashable.com/2011/03/25/rebecca-black-radio/|publisher=Mashable|author=Ehrlich, Brenna|accessdate=January 19, 2012}} Despite the song's strong performance elsewhere, Georgina Kelly claimed in late March 2011 that her daughter had not received any money from the song's sales to that point in time, saying "We haven't received a dime from anywhere." ==Music video== ===Development and summary=== The concept for the music video is based on the lyrics and presented as a typical Friday for Black.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/russell-smith/how-to-be-an-instant-internet-superstar-for-a-fee/article1944533/|title=How to be an instant Internet superstar – for a fee |last=Smith|first=Russell|date=March 16, 2011|work=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=March 17, 2011|location=Toronto}} She wakes up and goes to school, meeting her friends on the way. In the evening, after debating whether to sit in the front or back of a convertible, Black and her friends {{cite news |title = Better than Rebecca Black |author = Cohen, Cokey |newspaper = Yale Daily News |date = March 24, 2011 |url = http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2011/mar/24/weekend-better-rebecca-black/ |accessdate = March 24, 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110429045324/http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2011/mar/24/weekend-better-rebecca-black/ |archivedate = April 29, 2011 |df = mdy-all }} ride the car to a party at 7:45 pm.{{cite news|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/fanfare/2011/03/16/teen-girls-pop-video-mercilessly-dissected-by-internet-masses/|title=Teen girl’s pop video mercilessly dissected by Internet masses|date=March 15, 2011|work=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=March 17, 2011}} [[Patrice Wilson]] appears near the end of the song to deliver a short rap.{{cite news|last=Vestal|first=Shawn|title=Who is the rapper in the Rebecca Black "Friday" video? Meet 'Pato' Patrice Wilson|url=http://starcasm.net/archives/90562|accessdate=March 19, 2011|newspaper=starcasm.net|date=March 17, 2011}}{{cite news|last=Hawks|first=Asa|title=Spokane vortex goes viral with ‘Friday’ song|url=http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2011/apr/22/spokane-vortex-goes-viral-with-friday-song/|accessdate=March 19, 2011|newspaper=The Spokesman-Review|location=Spokane WA|date=April 22, 2011}} The video was shot on January 6, 2011 at Black's father's house with friends and family as [[extra (actor)|extra]]s, and requiring multiple takes over 12 hours. Some of those extras became stars in their own right; her friends [[Benni Cinkle]], Amanda Cooper and Hayley Grodt.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} Ark Music, according to Black's parents, cautioned them and her that they should not expect her to become famous. Black hoped that her friends and family would enjoy watching the video on YouTube and that it would perhaps help her to later begin a singing career.{{r|larsen20110317}} ===Reception=== The video was posted on February 10, 2011 and received 4,000 views, enough to please Black,{{r|larsen20110317}} before comedian [[Michael J. Nelson]]'s Twitter account and a ''[[Tosh.0]]'' blog post, "Songwriting Isn’t for Everyone", drew attention to it on March 11, 2011, turning the video into a [[viral video|viral hit]]. Criticism of the song's lyrics, the use of [[Auto-Tune]] on Black's vocals, as well as the content of the video also caused it to become viral. On May 9, 2011, comments became subject to prior approval for posting. Two days later, commenting was disabled altogether and archives removed. By June 15, 2011, the video had more than 166 million views, and 3.2 million "dislikes" from YouTube users against just 454,000 "likes". It also peaked in the top 20 most watched YouTube videos of all time. After reading the harsh reviews of "Friday", Black said that "those hurtful comments really shocked me." Ark Music offered to take the video down from YouTube, but Black refused the offer, saying that she did not wish "to give the haters the satisfaction that they got me so bad I gave up."{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/music/858451-rebecca-black-lashes-out-at-friday-haters-and-refuses-to-quit-as-singer|title=Rebecca Black lashes out at Friday 'haters' and refuses to quit as singer|last=Lee|first=Ann|date=March 18, 2011|work=Metro|accessdate=March 18, 2011}} Black's father has accompanied her in public to guard against potential accosters. In response to criticism over the song's significant use of Auto-Tune, Black performed an acoustic version during an interview with [[ABC News]], which earned over 180,000 dislikes on YouTube (84% of total ratings) by November 2011.{{YouTube|3CBzT2pv1Jc|Rebecca Black Sings 'Friday' Acoustic}} Later in the interview Black's mother, Kelly, stated that she was "angry and upset" after Black was brought to tears by comments, such as "I hope you go cut yourself and die" and "'I hope you cut yourself and get an eating disorder so you'll look pretty."{{cite video |people=Andrea Canning |title=Rebecca Black: 'Don't Think I'm the Worst Singer' |url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/video/rebecca-black-dont-think-im-worst-singer-13164800 |format=Streaming |medium=Television broadcast |publisher=Good Morning America |location=New York NY |archiveurl=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/video/rebecca-black-dont-think-im-worst-singer-13164800 |archivedate=March 18, 2011 |accessdate=January 16, 2012 |time=2:25 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1367627/Rebecca-Black-teen-YouTube-hit-branded-worlds-worst-singer-cries-criticism.html|title='I cried over all the nasty comments': How did an innocent wannabe like Rebecca Black become America's most reviled teenager?|date=March 18, 2011|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=March 18, 2011|location=London}}{{cite journal|last=Schwartz|first=Alison|title=Rebecca Black Cried Over All the Nasty Comments|journal=People|date=March 18, 2011|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20474741,00.html|accessdate=January 16, 2012|publisher=Time Inc.}} Black said, however, that soon she was able to ignore such comments,{{cite web|url=http://uk.eonline.com/uberblog/b231712_rebecca_black_defends_friday_lameness.html|title=Rebecca Black Defends "Friday" Lameness, Drags Justin Bieber Into It|last=Serpe|first=Gina|date=March 18, 2011|work=eonline.com|accessdate=March 18, 2011}} and asked [[Justin Bieber]], her idol, to perform a duet with her.{{cite news|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/03/18/its-friiiiday-let-the-rebecca-black-media-blitz-begin/|title=It's Friiiiday: Let the Rebecca Black Media Blitz Begin|last=Carbone|first=Nick|date=March 18, 2011|work=TIME|accessdate=March 18, 2011}} Although Bieber has not released an official announcement regarding the offer, he posted on Twitter "sunday comes after saturday? weird."{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/technology-news/cut-and-die-the-web-loves-to-hate-rebecca-black-20110321-1c2tz.html |title='Cut and die': the web loves to hate Rebecca Black |last=Moses |first=Asher |date=March 21, 2011 |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |accessdate=March 24, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xPufQ0n6?url=http://www.smh.com.au/technology/technology-news/cut-and-die-the-web-loves-to-hate-rebecca-black-20110321-1c2tz.html |archivedate=March 24, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} Bieber later sang part of the chorus at one of his concerts. ''[[Rolling Stone|Rolling Stone's]]'' Perpetua again praised Black after the interview and said, "She is actually a pretty decent singer. [...] She is a total sweetheart. [...] Black comes off as a well-adjusted, happy and grateful kid."{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/what-you-need-to-know-about-teen-viral-phenom-rebecca-black-20110318|title=What You Need to Know About Teen Viral Phenom Rebecca Black|last=Perpetua|first=Matthew|date=March 18, 2011|work=Rolling Stone|accessdate=March 18, 2011}} He also pointed out Black's intention to donate part of the profits from the song to [[arts integration|school arts programs]] and [[Humanitarian response to the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|relief efforts in Japan]] following the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]]. Benni Cinkle, who became known as "that girl in pink" and appears during the second verse of the video, released her own song entitled "Can You See Me Now" and created an anti-bullying organization (That Girl In Pink Foundation) due to the negative response she got from "Friday".{{cite news|last=Hawgood|first=Alex|title=No Stardom Until After Homework|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/17/fashion/how-teenagers-handle-the-webs-instant-fame.html?_r=1|accessdate=January 15, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=July 15, 2011|location=New York NY}}{{cite web|url=http://www.patriotledger.com/opinions/x1797072194/JOHN-REILLY-A-face-in-the-crowd-of-cyberbully-victims|title= A face in the crowd of cyberbully victims|first=John|last=Reilly|publisher=The Patriot Ledger|date=July 19, 2011|accessdate=September 3, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://popcrush.com/benni-cinkle-can-you-see-me-now-video/|title=Benni Cinkle Addresses Teen Issues In "Can You See Me Now" Video|first=Amanda|last=Hensel|publisher=Pop Crush|date=September 2, 2011|accessdate=September 3, 2011}} The video for "Friday" was later placed at number one in the ''[[NME]]'' list of "50 Worst Music Videos".[http://www.nme.com/list/50-worst-music-videos-ever/253198/page/5 50 Worst Music Videos Ever] Retrieved 27th January 2013. ===Controversy=== Not long after the "Friday" video went viral on YouTube, Black and her mother, Georgina Kelly, got into legal issues with Ark Music over rights to the song. In a March 29, 2011 letter from Kelly's lawyer to Ark Music, it was alleged that Ark Music failed to fulfill the terms of their November 2010 agreement by not giving her the song and video's master recordings, by claiming Black as exclusively signed to the label, and by exploiting the song without permission – for example, selling a "Friday" [[ringtone]]. While Wilson stated that Kelly "will get the masters and the song ... [t]hey can have it all", and agreed that Black was not exclusive to Ark, his attorney claimed that Ark owns the copyright for the song and the November agreement is invalid.{{cite news | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/exclusive-rebecca-black-fighting-ark-music-factory-over-friday-20110401?print=true | title=Exclusive: Rebecca Black Fighting Ark Music Factory Over 'Friday' | accessdate=April 1, 2011 | date=April 1, 2011 | publisher=Rolling Stone}} In June 2011, Ark Music Factory started charging $2.99 to watch the music video on YouTube.{{cite news | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/13839127 | title=Rebecca Black's "Friday" removed from YouTube | accessdate=June 20, 2011 | date=June 20, 2011 | publisher=BBC}} Black's initial response was through a message through her Twitter account saying: "Thanks for all the messages regarding the $2.99 fee added to Friday video, I have ''nothing'' to do with this!!" On June 16, 2011, YouTube took down the official video for "Friday". Instead a message in place of the video read: "This video is no longer available due to a copyright claim by Rebecca Black. Sorry about that." A spokesman for Rebecca Black said her legal team had asked YouTube to take the video down because of an ongoing legal dispute with the song's producers Ark Music Factory. Ark Music Factory responded by saying it was disappointed that Black decided to have the video pulled from YouTube despite the two parties being in "good faith negotiations". It added: "There's been an ongoing, open dialogue with our company. So we were blindsided to get a 'Take Down Notice' alleging copyright infringement instead of a call or e-mail from Rebecca's representatives. Our use of the video has fully been authorized (as evidenced by four uninterrupted months and 160 million-plus viewings without objection) by both Ms. Black and the copyright holder. Regardless, we are going to continue to take the high road and work out the complaint as soon as possible, so that the million-plus people who watch Friday for free each day can continue to enjoy the video."{{cite news | url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2011/06/17/rebecca-black-friday-controversy-statement/ | title=Rebecca Black's 'Friday' controversy: Video production company says it was 'blindsided' by YouTube removal | accessdate=June 20, 2011 | date=June 20, 2011 | publisher=Entertainment Weekly}} On September 16, 2011, the video was restored to YouTube, on Black's official channel. ==Cover versions and popular culture== ===''Glee'' Cast cover=== {{Infobox song | name = Friday | cover = Friday-by-glee-cast.png | alt = | border = yes | type = single | artist = ''[[Glee (season 2)|Glee]]'' cast | album = Glee: The Music - The Complete Season Two | released = May 10, 2011 | format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | recorded = 2011 | studio = | venue = | genre = | length = | label = | writer = [[Clarence Jey]], [[Patrice Wilson]] | producer = [[Clarence Jey]], [[Patrice Wilson]] | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} A cover version was released by the cast of [[Glee (season 2)|season two]] of the television series ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]''.{{cite web|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2011/05/06/glee-covers-rebecca-blacks-friday-listen-to-it-here-then-hate-yourself-for-it/|title=Glee covers Rebecca Black's "Friday" - Listen to it here, hen hate yourself for it|date=May 6, 2011|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=May 9, 2011}} The cast performed it on the show as well. The official release features cast members Puck ([[Mark Salling]]), Artie ([[Kevin McHale (actor)|Kevin McHale]]) and Sam ([[Chord Overstreet]]) on vocals, as part of the prom festivities on the "[[Prom Queen (Glee)|Prom Queen]]" episode that aired on May 10, 2011. Series co-creator [[Ryan Murphy (writer)|Ryan Murphy]] explained to ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' the use of the viral hit as a tribute to popular culture. He said: "There’s a rule for it that's explained in the show. The Glee Club is hired to perform songs for the prom and they were told by the principal to please do popular songs that the kids know." Murphy noted that ''Glee''{{'}}s "Friday" cover offers a different take since it's sung by males for other 17-year-olds: "The show pays tribute to pop culture and, love it or hate it, that song is pop culture."{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/ryan-murphy-explains-glees-use-186469|title=Ryan Murphy Explains 'Glee's' Use of Rebecca Black's 'Friday' (Exclusive)|date=May 9, 2011|first=Shirley|last=Halperin|first2=Lesley|last2=Goldberg|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=May 9, 2011}} ;Charts {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |- ! Chart (2011) ! Peak
position |- | Australia ([[ARIA Charts|ARIA]]){{cite web|url=http://ariacharts.com.au/pages/chartifacts.htm |title=Chartifacts - Week Commencing: 6th June 2011 |publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]] |date=June 6, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zFvuw9oF?url=http://ariacharts.com.au/pages/chartifacts.htm |archivedate=June 7, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} | align=center|74 |- | Canada ([[Canadian Hot 100]]){{cite web|url=http://en-ca.nielsen.com/content/dam/nielsen/en_ca/documents/pdf/newsletters/billboard_canadian-update/Nielsen%20Music%20Canadian%20Update.pdf |format=PDF |title=Nielsen Music: Canadian Update (May 13, 2011) |work=[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |accessdate=May 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ymUtEtX5?url=http://en-ca.nielsen.com/content/dam/nielsen/en_ca/documents/pdf/newsletters/billboard_canadian-update/Nielsen%20Music%20Canadian%20Update.pdf |archivedate=May 18, 2011 |df=mdy }} | align=center|33 |- {{singlechart|Ireland|46|artist=Glee Cast|song=Friday|year=2011|week=20|accessdate=May 19, 2011}} |- |UK Singles ([[UK Singles Chart|Official Charts Company]]){{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/5980/glee-cast/|title=GLEE CAST|publisher=[[The Official Charts Company]]|accessdate=May 19, 2011}} | style="text-align:center;"|46 |- | US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]{{Cite news|url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart_watch/74366/week-ending-may-15-2011-songs-idol-boosts-tyler/|title=Week Ending May 15, 2011. Songs: Idol Boosts Tyler|date=May 18, 2011|first=Paul|last=Grein|work=Chart Watch|publisher=[[Yahoo! Music]]|accessdate=May 19, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110528031436/http://new.music.yahoo.com/blogs/chart_watch/74366/week-ending-may-15-2011-songs-idol-boosts-tyler/|archivedate=May 28, 2011|df=mdy-all}} | align=center|34 |} {{clear}} ===Other versions and performances=== {{multiple image | footer = There have been multiple covers of the song, including on the television series ''Glee'', in concert by Justin Bieber, Odd Future and Katy Perry, separately | align = right | image1 = Mark Salling Glee Premiere.jpg | width1 = 98 | alt1 = A young man has a mohawk hairstyle. | caption1 = Mark Salling of ''Glee'' | image2 = Justin Bieber April 2011.jpg | width2 = 104 | alt2 = A teenage boy sings while wearing sunglasses. | caption2 = Justin Bieber | image3 = Katy Perry 2011 7.jpg | width3 = 112 | alt3 = A woman in a silver outfit in hoisted by two men. | caption3 = Katy Perry }} On April 1, 2011, "Friday" was performed by [[Stephen Colbert]], [[Jimmy Fallon]], [[Taylor Hicks]] and [[The Roots]] on ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]''. The New York Knicks City Dancers joined in.{{cite news |title=Watch Stephen Colbert and Jimmy Fallon Perform Rebecca Black’s ‘Friday’ on Late Night |url=http://tv.gawker.com/#!5788237/watch-stephen-colbert-and-jimmy-fallon-perform-rebecca-blacks-friday-on-late-night |publisher=''[[Gawker]]'' |first=Matt |last=Cherette |date=April 1, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110402144321/http://tv.gawker.com/#!5735192/ |archivedate=April 2, 2011 |df=mdy }}{{cite news |title=Stephen Colbert and Jimmy Fallon sing Rebecca Black's 'Friday'|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2011/04/02/stephen-colbert-jimmy-fallon-friday/|work=Entertainment Weekly |first=Darren|last=Franich |date=April 2, 2011}} Jimmy Fallon released "Friday" as part of his 2012 Warner Records album, ''[[Blow Your Pants Off]]'', which featured high-profile acts such as [[Paul McCartney]] and [[Bruce Springsteen]]. The album won [[Grammy Award for Best Comedy Album|Best Comedy Album]] at the 2013 [[Grammy Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/386489/2013-grammy-awards-winners-the-complete-list|title=2013 Grammy Awards Winners: The Complete List |date=February 10, 2013 |publisher=[[E!]]|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} The song has also been covered in a recording by [[Richard Cheese]],{{cite web |url=http://www.richardcheese.com/rcdiscography.html |title=Richard Cheese - Discography |publisher=[[Richard Cheese]] |accessdate=December 31, 2011}} and live in concerts by [[Todd Rundgren]],{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jPJjZMD9zgg/|title=Todd Rundgren - Friday (encore) (Cleveland Agora 10-12-12)|newspaper=Youtube|date=October 12, 2012}} [[Odd Future]],{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2298064/odd-future-dances-to-rebecca-black-friday/|title=Odd Future Dances To Rebecca Black's 'Friday,' Internet Explodes - MTV{{'-}}|date=May 13, 2011|first=Jamie|last=Peck|publisher=MTV. [[Viacom]]|accessdate=June 16, 2017}} [[Nick Jonas]],{{cite web|url=http://buzzworthy.mtv.com/2011/03/21/nick-jonas-rebecca-black-friday/|title=Nick Jonas Covers Rebecca Black's 'Friday{{'-}}|date=March 21, 2011|first=Eliot|last=Glazer|publisher=MTV. [[Viacom]]|accessdate=April 19, 2011|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110423192211/http://buzzworthy.mtv.com/2011/03/21/nick-jonas-rebecca-black-friday|archivedate=April 23, 2011|df=mdy-all}} and [[Justin Bieber]].{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/justin-bieber-sings-rebecca-blacks-172994|title=Justin Bieber Sings Rebecca Black's 'Friday,' Britney Spears' 'Baby One More Time' (Video)|date=March 31, 2011|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=April 19, 2011}} Singer [[Katy Perry]] performed the song on selected dates during her ''[[California Dreams Tour]]'', including at the Rod Laver Arena,{{cite web |url=http://www.gigwise.com/news/62868/Katy-Perry-Covers-Rebecca-Blacks-Friday |title=Katy Perry Covers Rebecca Black's 'Friday' |author=Gregory, Jason |date=May 3, 2011 |work=[[Gigwise]] |publisher=Giant Digital |accessdate=May 7, 2011}} Newcastle Entertainment Centre, TD Garden,{{cite news|last=Reed|first=James|title=Katy Perry’s sparkly dreams come to life at Garden|url=http://articles.boston.com/2011-06-20/ae/29680368_1_teenage-dream-california-gurls-california-dreams|accessdate=January 16, 2012|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=June 20, 2011|location=Boston MA}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes}} Air Canada Centre{{cite web |url=http://www.torontosun.com/2011/06/30/toronto-has-sweet-tooth-for-katy-perry|title=Toronto has a sweet tooth for Katy Perry |author=Stevenson, Jane|date=June 30, 2011|work=[[Toronto Sun]]|publisher=Canoe Network|accessdate=July 3, 2011}} and the 1stBank Center.{{cite web|last=Davies|first=Bree|title=Review: Katy Perry at 1STBANK Center, 7/26/11|url=http://blogs.westword.com/backbeat/2011/07/review_katy_perry_at_1stbank_c.php|work=Denver Westword|publisher=Denver Westword, LLC.|accessdate=January 16, 2012|location=Denver CO|date=July 27, 2011}} During the August 5 concert at the Nokia Theatre L.A. Live, Rebecca Black joined Perry onstage, performing the song as a duet.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/rebecca-black-joins-katy-perry-220071 |title=Katy Perry Joined Onstage by Rebecca Black on LA Show's Opening Night |author=Halperin, Shirley |date=August 7, 2011 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |accessdate=August 11, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60rPqsgEM?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/rebecca-black-joins-katy-perry-220071 |archivedate=August 11, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy}} Numerous parodies of "Friday" have been uploaded to YouTube and become viral in their own right.{{cite news |title= Rebecca Black’s "Friday": Best YouTube Cover Videos (And No, Bob Dylan Didn’t Write It)|author=Talarico, Brittany|url=http://www.okmagazine.com/2011/03/rebecca-blacks-friday-best-youtube-cover-videos-and-no-bob-dylan-didnt-write-it/|newspaper= [[OK!]]|date=March 16, 2011|accessdate=April 23, 2011}}{{cite news|title=Rebecca Black "Friday" Covers Abound: Singer Gets "Censored" in Latest Parody Round-Up |author=Talarico, Brittany |url=http://www.okmagazine.com/2011/03/rebecca-black-friday-covers-abound-singer-gets-censored-in-latest-parody-round-up/ |newspaper=[[OK!]] |date=March 21, 2011 |accessdate=April 23, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110330154236/http://www.okmagazine.com/2011/03/rebecca-black-friday-covers-abound-singer-gets-censored-in-latest-parody-round-up/ |archivedate=March 30, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy}} [[Conan O'Brien]] and [[Andy Richter]] also made a joint parody entitled "Thursday" on the ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]'' show on [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]].{{cite news |title=The worst pop song of all time? - 10 million YouTube hits for Rebecca Black's 'Friday'|last=Glazer |first=Elliot|url= http://buzzworthy.mtv.com/2011/03/22/conan-obrien-rebecca-black-thursday/|publisher=MTV|date=March 22, 2011|accessdate=May 10, 2011}} The YouTube phenomenon [[Bad Lip Reading]] was launched when an anonymous music and video producer replaced the audio to the "Friday" video with new music and lyrics about gang fighting.{{cite journal|title=Exclusive: The Bad Lip Reader Speaks |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/blogs/national-affairs/exclusive-the-bad-lip-reader-speaks-20111007 |first=Tim |last=Dickinson |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=October 7, 2011 |accessdate=May 3, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62OWbugn1?url=http://www.rollingstone.com/politics/blogs/national-affairs/exclusive-the-bad-lip-reader-speaks-20111007 |archivedate=October 13, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy}} "Gang Fight", released in March 2011, earned Bad Lip Reading a million hits and thousands of subscribers, with many spoofs soon following. Black appears as herself in the music video of [[Katy Perry]]'s single "[[Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)]]". She appears as the host of a party in the house next door to that of "Kathy Beth Terry". At the end of the video, "Terry" attempts to blame the excesses of the party (which had subsequently moved to her own house) on Black, only for her parents ([[Corey Feldman]] and [[Debbie Gibson]]) to disbelieve her.{{cite web|last=Anderson|first=Kyle|title=Katy Perry's 'Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)' video welcomes Rebecca Black, Corey Feldman, Hanson to the party of the year: Watch it here|url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2011/06/13/katy-perry-last-friday-night-video/|work=Entertainment Weekly|publisher=Entertainment Weekly Inc.|accessdate=January 16, 2012|location=Atlanta GA}} [[ARK Music Factory]] launched its "Ark's TGI Friday Covers" project, showcasing cover versions of "Friday" by well-known artists alongside other user-submitted tributes, re-works, and parodies of the song/video and inviting users to submit their versions for relaying through Ark Music Factory's site.{{cite web|title=Ark’s TGI Friday Covers|url=http://arkmusicfactory.com/profiles/blogs/arks-tgi-friday-covers|publisher=ARK Music Factory|accessdate=January 16, 2012|author=Ark Master|date=June 10, 2011}} In November 2012, multiple outlets suggested that Nicole Westbrook was "the new Rebecca Black", on release of Patrice Wilson's "It's Thanksgiving".{{cite news|last=Abrams|first=Natalie|title=Is Nicole Westbrook the New Rebecca Black? Listen to "It's Thanksgiving"|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/entertainment/tv/tvguide/article/Is-Nicole-Westbrook-the-New-Rebecca-Black-Listen-4024623.php|accessdate=11 November 2012|newspaper=Seattle Post-Intelligencer|date=9 November 2012|agency=TV Guide|location=Seattle WA}}{{cite news|last=Judkis|first=Maura|title="It’s Thanksgiving" dance song sings praises of mashed potatoes|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/arts-post/post/its-thanksgiving-dance-song-sings-praises-of-mashed-potatoes/2012/11/09/2733f6e0-2a7e-11e2-b4e0-346287b7e56c_blog.html|accessdate=11 November 2012|newspaper=Washington Post|date=9 November 2012|location=Washington DC|quote=Calling Westbrook the new Rebecca Black isn’t that much of a stretch — it seems to be what she’s aiming for.}}{{cite news|last=Capotorto |first=Alexandra|title=Nicole Westbrook's 'It's Thanksgiving' is the new Rebecca Black 'Friday'|url=http://popcrush.com/nicole-westbrook-its-thanksgiving-rebecca-black/|accessdate=11 November 2012|newspaper=PopCrush|date=9 November 2012|location=New York NY}} [[Kohl's]] Department Stores used a modified version of the song as its 2011 Black Friday advertising jingle. The hook "It's Friday, Friday, gotta get down on Friday" was changed to "It's Black Friday, Black Friday, Gotta go to Kohl's on Black Friday".{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/fashion/black-friday-2011-rebecca-black-song-friday-kohl-holiday-shopping-commercial-article-1.980713?localLinksEnabled=false|title=Black Friday 2011: Rebecca Black song ‘Friday’ used in Kohl’s holiday shopping commercial|last=Goldwert|first=Lindsay|date=November 21, 2011|work=[[New York Daily News]]|accessdate=November 22, 2011}} Black made her national television debut by performing a mash-up of the song along with her second single, "[[My Moment (Rebecca Black song)|My Moment]]", during [[America's Got Talent (season 7)|''America's Got Talent'''s]] result night for the YouTube Special round on August 10, 2011. The round featured various acts who have auditioned via YouTube.{{cite news|title=No auto-tune! Rebecca Black tries to prove her critics wrong by performing LIVE on America's Got Talent|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2024756/Rebecca-Black-tries-prove-critics-wrong-singing-LIVE-Americas-Got-Talent.html|accessdate=January 22, 2012|newspaper=Daily Mail UK|date=August 11, 2011|location=London}} Rebecca Black sang an acoustic version of the song on ''[[Good Morning America]]''.{{cite news|title=Rebecca Black 'Friday' Acoustic Version|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3CBzT2pv1Jc|newspaper=Youtube|date=March 21, 2011}} Rebecca performed Friday along with "My Moment", live in Suncorp Place, Sydney as a part of Telstra's 4G LTE network launch.{{cite news|title=Rebecca Black Friday live, and My Moment|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QkMRls-E-XE|newspaper=Youtube|date=September 26, 2011}} She also sang "Friday" live on ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]''.{{cite news|title=Rebecca Black - Interview & Friday (LIVE)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FTb1pA3a3VI |publisher=YouTube|date=July 18, 2011}} On May 5, 2017 Norwegian metal vocalist and YouTuber Leo Moracchioli uploaded a metal cover of "Friday" to his popular YouTube channel.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9mHDAYutrC0 On National French Fry Day 2018,[http://time.com/money/5335914/free-french-fries-deals-national-french-fry-day-2018/ ''TIME'': Free french fries deals - National French Fry Day 2018] YouTube personality [[Miranda Sings]] in collaboration with [[Dunkin Donuts]], released an adapted version of Friday, as part of the Donut Fries marketing strategy.[https://news.dunkindonuts.com/blog/miranda-sings-and-rebecca-black-come-together-to-celebrate-fry-day-at-dunkin DunkinDonuts News: Miranda Sings and Rebecca Black come together to celebrate Fry Day at Dunkin] ==Charts== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- ! scope="col" | Chart (2011) ! scope="col" | Peak
position |- |Australian Digital Tracks ([[ARIA Charts|ARIA]]){{cite web|url=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20110530-1606/Issue1100.pdf|title=The ARIA Report: Week Commencing 28 March 2011|publisher=[[Pandora Archive]]|accessdate=July 18, 2011}} | style="text-align:center;"|40 |- | [[Brasil Hot 100 Airplay]] (''[[Billboard Brasil]]'')"Brasil Hot 100 Airplay". Billboard Brasil (Brasil: bpp) (2): 96. March 2011. | style="text-align:center;"|66 |- | Brazil Pop Songs (''[[Billboard Brasil]]'')"Brasil Hot Pop & Popular Songs". Billboard Brasil (Brasil: bpp) (2): 97. March 2011. | style="text-align:center;"|79 |- {{singlechart|Billboardcanadianhot100|61|artist=Rebecca Black}} |- {{singlechart|Ireland|46|artist=Rebecca Black|song=Friday|year=2011|week=13|accessdate=April 1, 2011}} |- {{singlechart|New Zealand|33|artist=Rebecca Black|song=Friday|refname=nzpeak|accessdate=March 22, 2011}} |- {{singlechart|UK|60|date=20110403|accessdate=April 3, 2011}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardhot100|58|artist=Rebecca Black}} |- |US [[Heatseekers Songs]] (''[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]])''{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/Rebecca-Black/chart-history/heatseekers-songs|title=Rebecca Black Chart History (Heatseekers Songs)|date=April 9, 2011|work=[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]}} | style="text-align:center;"|1 |} ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= {{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CD2LRROpph0 |title=Rebecca Black - Friday (OFFICIAL VIDEO) |date=February 10, 2011 |work=YouTube |accessdate=May 14, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615211127/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CD2LRROpph0 |archivedate=June 15, 2011}}}} ==External links== {{Portal|Music}} * {{youtube|kfVsfOSbJY0|"Friday"}} * Eriq Gardner, "[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/rebecca-blacks-friday-taken-youtube-202893 Rebecca Black's 'Friday' Taken Off YouTube (Analysis)]", ''The Hollywood Reporter'', June 17, 2011. A legal explanation for takedown. * [https://twitter.com/michaeljnelson/statuses/46331722522042369 Originating tweet] by @michaeljnelson, March 11, 2011 {{good article}} {{Rebecca Black}} [[Category:2011 controversies]] [[Category:2011 singles]] [[Category:2011 songs]] [[Category:ARK Music Factory]] [[Category:Debut singles]] [[Category:Internet memes]] [[Category:Music controversies]] [[Category:Rebecca Black songs]] [[Category:Viral videos]] [[Category:YouTube music videos]] [[Category:Friday]] [[nl:Friday (Rebecca Black)]]

page.title: Gaddafi loyalism after the 2011 Libyan Civil War

revision.comment: Disambiguate [[Saif al-Islam]] to [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi]] using [[:en:Wikipedia:Tools/Navigation_popups|popups]]
revision.text:
[[File:Flag of Libya (1977-2011).svg|thumb|300px|right|Flag of the [[Great Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya|deposed government of Muammar Gaddafi]], used as a symbol by loyalists]] '''Gaddafi loyalism after the [[2011 Libyan Civil War|Libyan Civil War]]''' refers to sympathetic sentiment towards the overthrown government of [[Muammar Gaddafi]], who was [[Death of Muammar Gaddafi|killed]] in October 2011. It has been responsible for some of the [[Post-civil war violence in Libya|ongoing postwar violence]] in Libya, though the degree of its involvement has been disputed in a number of instances.
Sympathy for Gaddafi and his fallen government is viewed highly negatively by current Libyan authorities—both the legal government and extralegal militias—and parts of general society in postwar Libya, and even accusations of it can provoke harsh responses. In May 2012, the democratically elected postwar government passed legislation imposing severe penalties for anyone giving favourable publicity to Gaddafi, his family, their regime or ideas, as well as anything denigrating the new government and its institutions or otherwise judged to be damaging to public morale.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/05/03/211978.html |title=Libya grants immunity to ‘revolutionaries’ |publisher=Alarabiya.net |accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref> Derisively called ''tahloob'' ("algae") by anti-Gaddafi Libyans,<ref name="IPS">{{cite news |last=Frykberg |first=Mel |date=14 August 2012 |title=Gaddafi Loyalists Up In Arms |url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2012/08/gaddafi-loyalists-up-in-arms/ |newspaper=[[Inter Press Service]] |location= |publisher= |accessdate= }}</ref> suspected loyalists have faced strong persecution following the war. Perhaps 7,000 loyalist soldiers, as well as civilians accused of support for Gaddafi are being held in government prisons. [[Amnesty International]] has reported large scale torture and other mistreatment and executions, of those perceived as enemies of the new government.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news/libya-al-gaddafi-loyalists-risk-revenge-death-sentences-2013-08-02 |title=Libya: al-Gaddafi loyalists at risk of ‘revenge’ death sentences | Amnesty International |publisher=Amnesty.org |date= |accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/24/libya-illegal-detentions-un-report |title=Libyan rebels detaining thousands illegally, Ban Ki-moon reports | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/2012/11/13/plight-of-foreigners-in-libya-worse-than-under-qaddafi-claims-amnesty-international/#axzz2l2J1rH8v |title=Plight of foreigners in Libya "worse than under Qaddafi" claims Amnesty International |publisher=Libya Herald |date= |accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20120127/world/-Libya-militias-army-torturing-detainees-.404071#.UoqIJ38gGK0 |title=‘Libya militias, army torturing detainees’ |publisher=timesofmalta.com |date=2012-01-27 |accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref>
Reports and rumours of organised pro-Gaddafi activity have persisted since the war's end. The [[Libyan Popular National Movement]] was organised in exile on 15 February 2012 (the first anniversary of the protests that led to the civil war) by former officials in the Gaddafi government. The party, banned from participating in Libyan elections, may have also cultivated links with armed pro-Gaddafi groups in Libya. Statements from the party sometimes appear on websites affiliated with the so-called "Green Resistance" (after the sole colour of Gaddafi's flag), a term sometimes used by sympathisers to refer to supposed pro-Gaddafi militant groups.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gaddafi supporters outside Libya form new grouping|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-17071596|work=[[BBC]]|date=2012-02-17|accessdate=2012-04-20}}</ref><ref name="akhram">Nkrumah, Gamal. [http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2012/1087/re10.htm Libya's apocalyptic slough]. ''Al Akhram Weekly''. 2012-03-01.</ref><ref name="2014-01-22" />
==2011==
===End of the civil war=== Following Gaddafi's fall, several states, such as [[Venezuela]], refused to accept the [[National Transitional Council]] as the legitimate government, opting to continue recognising the former Gaddafi government. In Libya, loyalists either fled to foreign countries or went into hiding to avoid prosecutions. Shortly before his capture, Gaddafi's son [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi|Saif al-Islam]] appeared on Syrian pro-Gaddafi television on 22 October in an attempt to rally remaining loyalists claiming "I am in Libya, I am alive and free and willing to fight to the end and take revenge."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/313227 |title=Libya's NTC claim Saif al-Islam Gaddafi captured alive, uninjured |publisher=Digitaljournal.com |accessdate=20 November 2011}}</ref>
===Zawiya fighting=== Several days of fighting between fighters from Zawiya and fighters from Warshefana erupted in early November after the fighters from Warshefana set up a checkpoint on a highway near Zawiya and began challenging fighters from the city. Other reports stated that the groups were fighting over the Imaya military base, with Zawiya fighters claiming to be fighting Gaddafi loyalists. Zawiya field commander Walid bin Kora claimed that the Warshefana, riding in vehicles with "Brigade of the Martyr Muhammad Gaddafi" written on them and flying Gaddafi's green flag, had attacked his men. He also claimed that his men captured pro-Gaddafi "mercenaries" from sub-Saharan Africa.<ref>{{cite news|last=Holmes |first=Oliver |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/12/us-libya-clashes-idUSTRE7AB0HU20111112 |title=Fighters clash again near Tripoli, several dead |publisher=Reuters |date= 12 November 2011|accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref> NTC figures, however, denied that they were Gaddafi loyalists, blaming the clashes instead on a misunderstanding. The fighting resulted in between 7 and 14 dead. The [[National Transitional Council]] claimed to have resolved the issue over the weekend of the 12 and 13 of November following a meeting with elders from Zawiya and Warshefana.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=14 November 2011 |title=Libyan factions in deadly clashes near Zawiya |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15726099 |newspaper=BBC News |location= |publisher= |accessdate= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=13 November 2011 |title=Deadly factional clashes erupt in Libya |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2011/11/2011111341559598501.html |newspaper=Al Jazeera |location= |publisher= |accessdate= }}</ref>
===Capture of Saif al-Islam Gaddafi=== On 19 November, [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi|Saif al-Islam]] and four loyalist fighters were captured west of the town of [[Ubari]] near Sabha in southern Libya.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.indiavision.com/news/article/international/243165/gaddafis-son-hires-mercenaries-to-flee/| title=Gaddafi's son hires mercenaries to flee|date=31 October 2011|work=[[Indiavision News]]}}</ref> A nomad who had been hired to guide them in their planned escape to Niger secretly told government forces where Saif al-Islam and his two-vehicle convoy would be passing through. Acting on this information, the Zintan brigade blocked off the area and arrested them on sight. Saif al-Islam was taken to Zintan by plane and, pending trial, he is kept in detention by the Zintan militia.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8902994/Libya-conflict-brewing-over-trial-of-Saif-al-Islam-Gaddafi.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Richard | last=Spencer | title=Libya: conflict brewing over trial of Saif al-Islam Gaddafi | date=20 November 2011}}</ref>
===Bani Walid ambush=== On 23 November, clashes erupted as a National Transitional Council militia tried to apprehend a suspected loyalist in Bani Walid, which was one of the last pro-Gaddafi strongholds in the civil war. At least seven people were reported killed, five of them NTC militia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/11/23/178863.html |title=Fresh clashes in Libya’s Bani Walid; U.N. says 7,000 held in militia prisons |publisher=Alarabiya.net |accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref>
==2012==
===Sirte=== In January 2012, residents of [[Sirte]], Gaddafi's hometown, attacked a military camp associated with the NTC on the outskirts of the city.<ref name="Time"/>
===Zuwara clashes=== On 1 April, between 21 and 34 Zuwara militiamen were detained by members of a neighbouring town's militia. Fighters from Ragdalein stated that they captured the men after months of abuses by a Zuwara brigade, including the looting of property. For their part, the Zuwara local council head accused Ragdalein of being a hub of Gaddafi loyalists.<ref>{{cite news|last=Al |first=Rami |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2017890745_apmllibya.html |title=Militias: Clashes near Libya's Tunisia border |publisher=Seattle Times |date=2 April 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> A third version of the events came from the government Interior Ministry which stated that the trouble started when a Zuwara hunting party close to nearby al-Jumail shot and killed a person from that town by mistake.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/01/libya-clashes-idUSL6E8F10ST20120401 |title=Libyan PM visits scene of tribal clashes in desert |publisher=Reuters|date= 1 April 2012|accessdate=6 August 2012 |first=Marie-Louise |last=Gumuchian}}</ref> The hunters were then arrested but released later. Another Zuwara council head claimed that the men were tortured before being released and stated that Zuwara came under mortar and anti-aircraft fire by militias from both Ragdalein and al-Jumail.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE83109H20120402 |title=Rival militias exchange fire in western Libya |publisher=Reuters |date=2 April 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref>
On 3 April, reports emerged that the fighting in the Zuwara area was still continuing with at least one Zuwara militiaman killed and five wounded. The losses for militia from Ragdalein and al-Jumail were not known. Clashes were reported at the entrance to Ragdalein while groups in al-Jumail were shelling Zuwara.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/03/us-libya-zuwara-idUSBRE8320H220120403 |title=Government fails to halt western Libya militia clash |publisher=Reuters |date= 3 April 2012|accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> At least 14 were killed and 80 injured.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFL6E8F382U20120403 |title=Militia clash in west Libya kills 14 people |publisher=Reuters |date=3 April 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref>
On 4 April, the fighting escalated with the use of tanks and artillery. The reported number of dead was said to had risen to 26, eight from Zuwara and 18 from the outlying towns, and another 142 Zuwarans were wounded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/04/04/205432.html |title=Fresh clashes erupt in western Libya between former rebels, killing 26 |publisher=Al Arabiya |date=4 April 2012 |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://m.apnews.com/ap/db_15716/contentdetail.htm?contentguid=6NzaSgJe |title=Clashes in rival towns kill 22 in western Libya |agency=Associated Press |date= |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref> Unconfirmed reports rose up the death toll to 48 killed in the clashes.<ref>[http://unsmil.unmissions.org/Portals/unsmil/Documents/Briefing10May2012.pdf The situation in Libya] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202233801/http://unsmil.unmissions.org/Portals/unsmil/Documents/Briefing10May2012.pdf |date=2013-12-02 }} UN Security Council, 6768th meeting, 10 May 2012.</ref> [[BBC News]] aired a report on the story, confirming a number dead. The report also aired an interview with a wounded man from Zarawa, claiming to have been attacked by what he called "Gaddafi loyalists".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-17606457 |title=BBC News - At least 14 killed in Libya clashes around Zuwara |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2012-04-04 |accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref> There is no confirmation as to whether or not the clashes had anything to do with the guerrillas.
===Ghat skirmishes=== On 6 April, French leading newspaper ''[[Le Figaro]]'' reported that a dozen people were killed near the border town of [[Ghat, Libya|Ghat]] on 1 and 2 April in fighting between former pro-Gaddafi Tuaregs and the Zintan tribe.<ref>{{cite web|language=French|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/international/2012/04/05/01003-20120405ARTFIG00976-en-libye-aussi-les-touaregs-se-battent-pour-leur-territoire.php |title=En Libye aussi, les Touaregs se battent pour leur territoire |publisher=Lefigaro.fr |date= |accessdate=6 August 2012}}</ref>
The town of Ghat, in the deserts of southwest Libya, was a stronghold of Gaddafi during his reign. It was the last town in Libya to recognise the new government. Since the fall of Gaddafi, it has been suspected of continuing to be a base of loyalist sentiment. No area in Libya has had as many officials disbarred due to links to the Gaddafi government. The present government has banned its two council members, the local council leader, the secretary to the council, its financial controller, the head of security services, and the heads of the sanitation department and the border guards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/02/10/ghat-a-former-qaddafi-stronghold-struggles-to-keep-up-with-libyan-revolution/#axzz2lgC1eXQW |title=Ghat: a former Qaddafi stronghold struggles to keep up with Libyan revolution |publisher=Libya Herald |date= |accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref>
===Zintan clashes=== Tribal clashes in Zintan broke out on 17 June, after a Zintan man was killed after stopping at a checkpoint while attempting to transport tanks from a weapons depot in Mizda to Zintan.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18474834 | work=BBC News | title=Troops sent to quell clashes in western Libya | date=17 June 2012}}</ref> While the Zintanis had played a prominent role fighting in favour of the NTC during the civil war, the neighbouring Mashashya tribe had chosen to side with the Gaddafi government during the civil war.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/06/20126176734750314.html|title=Troops sent to quell clashes in western Libya|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2015}}</ref>
The Mashashya tribe chose to side with the Gaddafi government, whilst fighters from Zintan played a prominent role, fighting in favour of the NTC.<ref name="aljazeera1"/> This, combined with a dispute over land and bitterness over prisoners of war from Mashashya, led to the fighting. It is unclear if Green Resistance had a role in instigating the violence.
As a result of the fierce fighting between the different tribes, government troops were deployed to the area on 17 June. The area was subsequently declared a military zone. The deployment of soldiers and imposition of a government enforced ceasefire<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tripolipost.com/articledetail.asp?c=1&i=8587|title=Libyan Government Sends Troops to Quell Fighting in West of Country,|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2017}}</ref> managed to prevent further clashes, with government spokesman Nasser al-Manaa declaring that fighting had ended on 18 June.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-18529139 | work=BBC News | title=Libya's tribal clashes leave 105 dead | date=20 June 2012}}</ref>
===Tripoli=== In August 2012, claims surfaced of loyalist remnants attempting to smuggle weapons into Libya in an effort to destabilise the government.<ref name="IPS"/> A member of the group in Tripoli's Abu Salim neighbourhood, a former pro-Gaddafi stronghold, claimed in an August 2012 interview that loyalist militia were rebuilding their strength and waiting for the right moment to move against the new government.<ref name="IPS"/> [[Al-Saadi Gaddafi|Saadi Gaddafi]] was claimed to support the group whilst under house arrest in Niger.<ref>[http://www.worldbulletin.net/?aType=haber&ArticleID=127512 Gaddafi's son leading former regime's revival] ''World Bulletin''. 2014-01-24</ref> He warned in early 2012 that he was in contact with sleeper cells who were organising underground resistance.<ref name="IPS"/> In addition to his son Saadi, Muammar Gaddafi's nephew Ahmad Gaddaf al-Damm, living in hiding in Egypt, was also accused of supporting violent pro-Gaddafi activity. Col. Khamid Bilhayr of the Libyan National Army claimed that other loyalist figures outside the country were sending large quantities of money and support to loyalist groups inside Libya.<ref name="Time"/>
Others claim that despite the group's rhetoric, its operations were limited to bombings and minor instances of sabotage.<ref name="IPS"/> They were believed to have been behind a bombing outside the headquarters of the Military Police on 10 August.<ref name="IPS"/> On 19 August, two people were killed and up to five were injured when a car bomb went off at dawn near the former military academy for women. Another car bomb exploded at the same time near the interior ministry, but no one was harmed. The bombings occurred on the eve of the anniversary of the [[Battle of Tripoli (2011)|Battle of Tripoli]]. Tripoli's head of security, Col. Mahmoud Sherif, blamed Gaddafi loyalists for the attack, and the following day Libyan authorities announced they had arrested 32 members of a pro-Gaddafi network in connection with the bombings.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=20 August 2012 |title=Libya holds 32 'Gaddafi loyalists' over Tripoli attack |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-19314714 |newspaper=BBC News |location= |publisher= |accessdate=14 November 2013 }}</ref>
On the same day as the arrests, a bomb was placed under the car of an Egyptian diplomat. The bomb exploded, but nobody was injured. The incident was also blamed by the government on Gaddafi loyalists.<ref name="Time">{{cite news |last=Sotloff |first=Steven |date=24 August 2012 |title=The Bomb Attacks in Libya: Are Gaddafi Loyalists Behind Them? |url=http://world.time.com/2012/08/24/the-bomb-attacks-in-libya-are-gaddafi-loyalists-behind-them/ |newspaper=Time |location=Tripoli |publisher= |accessdate=14 November 2013 }}</ref>
===Raid on Katibat Al-Awfiyah brigade=== On 23 August, Interior ministry spokesman Abdelmonem al-Hur claimed that more than a hundred tanks and twenty-six rocket launchers were seized from an alleged pro-Gaddafi militia (named ''Katibat Al-Awfiyah'', or Brigade of the Faithful), during a government raid on their campsite in [[Tarhuna]]. The operation ended with one of the fighters killed, eight wounded and thirteen detained—including the commander—and accused of being linked with the 19 August Tripoli bombings. Three fighters managed to escape.<ref>{{cite news|title=At least 12 killed in tribal clash in Libya|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/48772032/ns/world_news-africa/t/least-killed-tribal-clash-libya/#.UE81B3kZRO0|work=[[NBC]]|agency=Reuters|date=23 August 2012|accessdate=11 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Libya seizes tanks from pro-Gaddafi militia|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-19364536|publisher=BBC|date=24 August 2012|accessdate=10 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Tanks seized from pro-Gaddafi militia|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/breaking-news/tanks-seized-from-pro-gaddafi-militia/story-e6freoo6-1226457112174|publisher=[[The Courier-Mail|Courier Mail]]|date=24 August 2012|accessdate=11 September 2012}}</ref>
===Death of Omran Shaban=== Omran Shaban, the man held most responsible for the extrajudicial killing of Gaddafi, was abducted by suspected Gaddafi loyalists in Bani Walid in July. He was imprisoned and tortured for two months before being released in September due to government pressure on Bani Walid. He was sent to France for medical treatment, but died of his wounds the same month.<ref name="reuters.com">{{cite news|last=Shuaib |first=Ali |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/08/us-libya-tensions-baniwalid-idUSBRE89715B20121008 |title=Libya's Bani Walid is shelled in standoff over rebel's death |publisher=Reuters |date= 8 October 2012|accessdate=25 January 2013}}</ref> The rebels responsible have so far eluded capture or death.
===Bani Walid=== {{main|Siege of Bani Walid (2012)}}
On 9 September, local militia in Bani Walid drove government forces from the town. Initial reports claimed that a supposed Gaddafi loyalist group called "[[Brigade 93]]" was responsible for the takeover,<ref>{{cite news|author=Rami Al-Shaheibi And Maggie Michael |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/01/24/libya-gaddafi-bani-walid_n_1226960.html |title=Libya: Gaddafi Loyalists Seize Bani Walid |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= 24 January 2012|accessdate=2014-01-02}}</ref><ref name="BBC Bani Walid">{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-16690010 |title= Libya fighting: Four die in Gaddafi loyalists clash |work=BBC News |date=23 January 2012 |accessdate=23 January 2012}}</ref> although the Bani Walid town elders later denied this, and proclaimed support for the removal of Gaddafi. The elders stated that the accusations of pro-Gaddafi sympathies were orchestrated by the media, and that the town instead was fighting for the removal of the NTC military administration of the town and its replacement by a local council.<ref name="Reuters">{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFL5E8CO1LY20120124?sp=true |title=Former Gaddafi stronghold revolts against Tripoli|work=Reuters |date=24 January 2012 |accessdate=27 January 2012}}</ref>
===Brak ambush=== On September 21, government forces were ambushed by alleged Gaddafi loyalists in the city of [[Brak, Libya|Brak]] in south west Libya. Nine soldiers were killed in the attack, with no information of casualties from the attackers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/09/22/239444.html|title=Nine Libyan forces killed in clashes with Qaddafi loyalists|work=Al Arabiya|date=22 September 2012|accessdate=28 September 2012}}</ref>
==2014== On 18 January, the Libyan air force attacked targets in the south of Libya because of unrest blamed on forces loyal to slain leader Muammar Gaddafi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/libya-air-force-south-834/|title=Libyan air force attacks targets in south after gunmen storm airbase|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2015}}</ref> The government also declared a state of emergency after Gaddafi loyalists took over the Tamahind air force base near the southern city of [[Sabha, Libya|Sabha]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2014/01/18/346409/libya-declares-state-of-emergency/|title=PressTV-Libya declares state of emergency|publisher=|accessdate=6 April 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227101642/http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2014/01/18/346409/libya-declares-state-of-emergency/|archivedate=27 February 2014|df=}}</ref> On 22 January ''[[Voice of Russia]]'' featured a report with Libyans who claimed that much of the southern half of the country as well as Bani Walid had fallen under the control of the "Green" Gaddafi loyalists, and that some foreign Libyan embassies were flying the Gaddafi-era green flag in support. The interviewed Libyans claimed to be fighting against a Western-backed "puppet government" with ties to [[Al-Qaeda]], and charged that [[Qatar]] was paying [[Sudan]]ese pilots to bomb their positions.<ref name="2014-01-22">[http://voiceofrussia.com/2014_01_22/Green-Libyan-flags-are-waving-once-again-Interview-7710/ Green Libyan flags are waving once again - Interview]. ''The Voice of Russia''. 2014-01-22.</ref> On the other hand, the more government-friendly ''[[Libya Herald]]'' newspaper reported that a large contingent of Gaddafi-friendly fighters were scattered near Ajilat as they tried to aid other Gaddafi-loyalists in Sabha, with five of them killed. The report claimed that if the events were part of a coordinated movement, "it does not appear to be well organised, let alone have any significant or measurable support."<ref>Wahab, Ashraf Abdul. [http://www.libyaherald.com/2014/01/22/qaddafi-supporters-heading-to-ajilat-killed-in-sabratha-report/ Qaddafi supporters heading to Ajilat killed in Sabratha: report]. ''Libya Herald''. 2014-01-22.</ref>
On 22 January, the Libyan [[General National Congress]] passed Decree 5/2014, ''Concerning the Cessation and Ban on the Broadcasting of Certain Satellite Channels'', aimed at censoring pro-Gaddafi satellite television stations such as al-Khadra (The Green Channel) and al-Nedaa (the Libyan Popular National Movement's channel). [[Reporters Without Borders]] subsequently issued a statement calling for the withdrawal of the decree.<ref>Reporters Without Borders. [http://allafrica.com/stories/201401310769.html?viewall=1 Libya: Freedom of Information in Jeopardy in Post-Gaddafi Libya]. ''AllAfrica''. 2014-01-30.</ref>
On 24 January, nine soldiers were killed and 27 injured near Tripoli in clashes with Gaddafi loyalists.<ref>[http://www.afriquejet.com/news/730-army-9-soldiers-killed-in-clashes-with-gunmen.html Army: 9 soldiers killed in clashes with gunmen] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140130052152/http://www.afriquejet.com/news/730-army-9-soldiers-killed-in-clashes-with-gunmen.html |date=2014-01-30 }}. ''Afrique en Ligne''. 2014-01-24.</ref>
==2015== On August 4 "dozens" of Gaddafi loyalists staged a rare public demonstration in Benghazi (the only pro-Gaddafi gathering in the city as of yet), chanting pro-Gaddafi slogans and waving the flag of the [[History of Libya under Muammar Gaddafi|Jamahiriya]], in response to [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi|Saif al-Islam Gaddafi's]] death sentence. The protest was later dispersed after anti-Gaddafi militia opened fire and threw rocks, although no one was reported injured.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-libya-security-idUSKCN0Q91WT20150804|title=Gaddafi loyalists stage rare protest in eastern Libya|date=4 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2017|via=Reuters}}</ref> Continuous fighting was also alleged to have erupted between pockets of pro-Gaddafi militants and [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIL]] forces in Gaddafi's former hometown of [[Sirte]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/nation/IS-Fight-With-Gaddafi-Group-Delays-Release-of-2-Remaining-Indians/2015/08/05/article2958110.ece|title=IS Fight With Gaddafi Group Delays Release of 2 Remaining Indians|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2017}}</ref> Furthermore, protests were reported across the Libyan south, in particular the city of [[Sabha, Libya|Sabha]], where at least four protestors were reported dead after opponents opened fire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/death-sentence-verdicts-spark-pro-qaddafi-protests-803699087|title=Death sentences spark pro-Gaddafi protests|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2017}}</ref> Protests were also reported in Tobruk, triggering a large counter-demonstration from those in favour of the 2011 revolution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.libyaobserver.ly/news/gaddafi-loyalists-march-tobruk|title=Gaddafi loyalists march in Tobruk - The Libya Observer|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2017}}</ref> Another protest happened on August 7 in Bani Walid, a city that was a stronghold of pro-Gaddafi loyalists.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?t=40&v=jo4k_p6wflg|title=بني وليد اليوم Libya ~ Bani Walid 07 August, 2015|first=|last=Tarache Cabarte|date=7 August 2015|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2017|via=YouTube}}</ref>
==2016== On 5 May, Gaddafi loyalists alongside with soldiers loyal to [[Khalifa Haftar]] captured the town of [[Zella, Libya|Zella]] after an intense battle with [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant in Libya]] fighters near [[Sirte]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mobile.almasdarnews.com/article/gaddafi-loyalists-capture-town-near-isils-stronghold/|title=Gaddafi loyalists capture town near ISIL’s stronghold|date=5 May 2016}}</ref> On 23 December, a Gaddafi loyalist [[Afriqiyah Airways Flight 209|hijacked a plane]] which was flying from Sabha to Tripoli and was diverted to Malta.
==2017==
{{Empty section|date=March 2018}}
==2018== [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi]], the son of Gaddafi announced on March 22, 2018 that he will run for president.<ref>http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/saif-al-islam-gaddafi-run-libya-election-president-797962259</ref><ref>https://www.rt.com/news/421984-gaddafi-saif-unite-libyans/</ref><ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/03/20/gaddafis-son-saif-run-libyan-president-2018-elections/</ref>
In September hundreds of Gaddafi supporters escaped from a prison in Tripoli in a mass jail break during clashes in the city between the [[Government of National Accord|UN-backed government]] and the 7th brigate.
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Libyan Civil War}}
[[Category:Aftermath of the Libyan Civil War (2011)]] [[Category:Libyan Civil War (2011)]] [[Category:Libyan Civil War (2014–present)]] [[Category:Muammar Gaddafi]] [[Category:Political movements in Libya]] [[Category:Politics of Libya]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use British English|date=July 2015}} {{more footnotes|date=October 2014}} The '''Gaiety Theatre''' is a [[listed building|category B listed]] performing arts venue in [[Ayr]], [[Scotland]].<ref>[http://hsewsf.sedsh.gov.uk/hslive/hsstart?P_HBNUM=21522 Historic Scotland - Gaiety Theatre]</ref> It is noted for its interior [[rococo]] features, its atmosphere and its acoustics.
The Ayr Gaiety was built in 1902, reconstructed after a fire in 1904, its façade remodeled in 1935, and further reinstated after a fire in 1955. In 1995, an annex was constructed, including a new café, box office, dressing rooms and studio space. After a faltering start, which saw several years as a cinema after World War I, the theatre was bought by Ben Popplewell, from Bradford who already had a track record of success running the Pavilion theatre on Ayr seafront. For fifty years the Popplewell family ran the theatre – latterly as part of the Glasgow Pavilion business. During this time the Gaiety developed a reputation as a variety theatre with a ‘summer’ variety show – the Gaiety Whirl – which ran for 26 weeks at its height. Many Scottish and UK stars appeared regularly on its stage, and several started their careers there. The programme offered more than a summer show however, with several weeks of Shakespeare and regular transfers from Glasgow Citizens theatre, being part of a varied offer. After seventy years in private ownership the local Council acquired the Gaiety theatre freehold in 1974. It then operated as a municipal theatre under direct local authority management. The programming had much in common with the Popplewell years, with the Gaiety Whirl still a feature and the, by now, popular panto at the core of the programme. But the scope of performances developed and, while the family oriented theme continued, a wider range of presentations developed, including controversial shows such as Borderline Theatres production of Dario Fo’s Mistero Buffo and a touring version of Oh Calcutta! After many years of successful operation the theatre began to lose audiences and the Council felt the revenue subsidy it provided and the requirement for capital investment required a new approach. In January 2009 the theatre closed, leaving Ayr without a theatre – as the Civic Theatre, which had mainly presented drama, had been closed and demolished a little earlier due to asbestos contamination problems.
==South Ayrshire Council forced closure==
The closure met with considerable opposition and dismay among many Ayr residents, particularly since it appeared that the required capital and revenue investment to reopen the theatre would not be available. A public meeting attracted over 400 attendees, the future of the theatre was a key issue in the local press, many Scottish performers expressed their dismay and there was extensive discussion on social media.
In early 2009 South Ayrshire Council invited tenders to take on the theatre management. Ayr Gaiety Partnership (AGP), a charity formed by local residents for the purpose in Summer 2009, secured preferred bidder status. Just over three years later, having secured financial backing from the Council and Scottish Government, as well as from local fundraising, AGP took on a 99-year lease of the theatre with a vision to do much more than simply re-open the building. Ayr Gaiety Partnerships vision is 'to re-energise the performing arts in South Ayrshire, with the Gaiety Theatre as the hub of a network of venues that will stimulate the cultural life and economic prosperity of the area ensuring that Ayr will once again be a key destination for all those interested in the performing arts.'
==Re-opening in 2012==
From the start the organisation set ambitious social, economic and cultural goals. But the first priority was to re-open with a successful panto. On 11 December 2012, after many last minute challenges, the Gaiety re-opened for what turned out to be a sell-out run of over 40 performances of the panto Cinderella.
==Ayr Gaiety Partnership==
The Ayr Gaiety Partnership is a charitable body formed by local community figures, with membership open to local residents. The directors at present are: Ian Welsh, David Quayle, Chris Fremantle, Graham Peterkin, and Professor Gayle McPherson.
Membership is open to local residents and others with an interest in the theatre. Ayr Gaiety Partnership's first General Meeting is set to take place on 13 October 2014.
==Staff & Volunteering at The Gaiety== The new Ayr Gaiety is unlike most theatres in the UK because it is largely run through voluntary effort. Most of the people undertaking front of house, technical, fundraising, marketing and maintenance are doing so on a voluntary basis. Although the volunteering effort overall is led by the Executive Director and Board- each volunteer team is supported and led by one of the staff team members.
The Gaiety's current full-time staff team consists of just nine employees led by Executive Director Jeremy Wyatt.
==Scotland's 1st Learning Theatre== The School of Media, Culture & Society at the [[University of the West of Scotland]] (UWS) and the Gaiety Theatre officially launched Scotland’s first Learning Theatre on Friday 19 September 2014. The launch event, which saw representatives from UWS, the Gaiety, as well as the [[National Theatre of Scotland]] in attendance, marks the first stage in the development of the partnership Learning Theatre, which will provide a centre for education, training and research in the area of performance and theatre craft.
UWS enjoys close links with the Gaiety and the University’s new BA Technical Theatre degree, delivered in conjunction with the Theatre, had its first intake in September. The course, the only one of its kind in the country, offers thorough vocational training for those looking to work in stage management and theatre production. Students will gain professional knowledge of the industry and will be prepared for a variety of employment opportunities from small-scale theatres to large multi-media events, venues and festivals. The course is aimed at those with a range of theatre, performance, production and related HND qualifications to enable them to build to a degree award in Technical Theatre. Students from the University's undergraduate Performance programme also make regular use of the theatre's facilities.

{{nofootnotes|date=October 2008}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Haitian Heritage Month |type = cultural |image = |imagesize = |caption = |official_name = |nickname = |observedby = United States |litcolor = |longtype = Heritage, cultural, ethnic |significance = Celebration of [[Haiti]]an contributions |begins = May 1 |ends = May 31 |date = |frequency= annual |duration=1 month |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = }}
'''Haitian Heritage Month''' is a celebration in the United States of [[Haiti]]an heritage and culture. It was first celebrated in [[Boston, Massachusetts]], in 1998. Tele Kreyol, one of the Boston Haitian Access Television programs, celebrated the whole month of May with a series of programs on Haitian history, culture, and contributions to the world. The month-long celebration has continued with such activities as parades, flag raisings, and exhibits organized by [[Haitian Americans|Haitian-Americans]] United, Inc. (H.A.U.) in collaboration with several Haitian organizations in the [[New England]] area.
The Haitian community of [[Palm Beach County, Florida]], which started the Heritage celebration in 2001, contributed greatly to make the Heritage Month first a statewide celebration, and then, a national one in the United States. South Florida congressman [[Kendrick B. Meek]] introduced unsuccessfully a bill in the [[United States House of Representatives]] in 2004 and 2006 to recognize the month of May as Haitian-American Heritage Month in the United States. President [[George W. Bush]] and his wife [[Laura Bush]] sent a letter in May 2005 to congratulate the Haitian-American community for the heritage month and organized a celebration at the [[White House]] the same year.
Since 1998, several governors, members of state senates and houses of representatives, mayors and city councilors have issued annual citations and proclamations, recognizing the Haitian Heritage Month celebration in their states or cities.
In 2008, the Haitian Heritage Month/Flag Day was celebrated with parades, festivals, schools activities, and flag raising ceremonies in the following cities and counties in the U.S.:
{{col-begin}} {{col-3}} ; Connecticut * [[Norwich, Connecticut|Norwich]] ; Florida * [[Broward County, Florida|Broward County]] * [[Delray Beach, Florida|Delray Beach]] * [[Palm Beach, Florida|Palm Beach]] * [[Miami Beach, Florida|Miami Beach]] * [[Miramar, Florida|Miramar]] * [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]] * [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]] * [[Ft. Lauderdale, Florida|Ft. Lauderdale]] * [[Boca Raton, Florida|Boca Raton]] * [[Collier County, Florida|Collier County]] * [[Palm Bay, Florida|Palm Bay]] {{col-3}} ; Georgia * [[Atlanta]] ; Illinois * [[Chicago]] ; Massachusetts * [[Boston]] * [[Brockton, Massachusetts|Brockton]] * [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]] * [[Lawrence, Massachusetts|Lawrence]] * [[Malden, Massachusetts|Malden]] * [[Waltham, Massachusetts|Waltham]] ; New Jersey * [[Irvington, New Jersey|Irvington]] * [[Trenton, New Jersey|Trenton]] {{col-3}} ; New Hampshire * [[Manchester, New Hampshire|Manchester]] ; New York * [[Brooklyn]] * [[Spring Valley, New York|Spring Valley]] ; Pennsylvania * [[Philadelphia]] ; Rhode Island * [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]] ; Virginia * [[Roanoke, Virginia|Roanoke]] {{col-end}}
The Haitian Heritage Month celebration is an expansion of the Haitian Flag Day, a major patriotic day celebration in Haiti and the Diaspora. Haitian President [[Dumarsais Estimé]] started the Flag Day celebration with parades, cultural and athletic events in many cities in Haiti in the 1930s, when he was minister of education under President [[Sténio Vincent]]. Estime wanted to commemorate annually the creation of the [[Flag of Haiti|Haitian flag]] on May 18 to encourage the development of patriotic sentiments among Haitian youth.
Beside the Flag Day celebration, the month of May carries a number of significant historical and cultural traditions that Haitians are proud to make aware of and to pass on to future generations. In Haiti, May 1 is celebrated as Labor and Agriculture Day. May 2 used to be Flower Day. The Congress of Arcahaie that united black and mulatto officers to fight together for Haiti's independence is remembered from May 15 through 18. The revolutionary general, [[Toussaint Louverture]], was born on May 20, 1743. Teacher's Day is May 17, University Day May 18, and Mother's Day is celebrated on the last Sunday of May. For Haitian [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholics]], May is the month of [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Mary]], the mother of [[Jesus]].
== References == * ''Histoire d'Haïti: De l'independance a nos jours'' by [[Odette Roy Fombrun]] * ''Boston Haitian Reporter'', May 2008 – Vol 7 Issue 5 * ''Boston Haitian Reporter'', June 2001
== External links == * http://www.haitianheritagemonth.net * http://www.hauinc.org
