===Tyre allocation=== Tyres are allocated at each event as follows:<ref>https://www.v8scglobal.com/inside-supercars/2018-supercars-tyre-rules/</ref> {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%; text-align: center" |- ! rowspan="2"| Event ! width="120" colspan="3" | Tyre Allocation |- ! {{tooltip|Hard|Hard compound slick tyres}} ! {{tooltip|Soft|Soft compound slick tyres}} ! {{tooltip|Wet|Wet weather tyres}} |- | align="left"| [[Adelaide 500]] | 28 | 0 | 16 |- | align="left" | [[Melbourne 400]] | 0 | 16 | 12 |- | align="left" | [[Tasmania SuperSprint]] | 0 | 24 | 12 |- | align="left" | [[Phillip Island 500]] | 28 | 0 | 12 |- | align="left" | [[Perth SuperSprint|Perth SuperNight]] | 0 | 24 | 12 |- | align="left" | [[Winton SuperSprint]] | 0 | 24 | 12 |- | align="left" | [[Darwin Triple Crown]] | 0 | 24 | 12 |- | align="left" | [[Townsville 400]] | 0 | 28 | 12 |- | align="left" | [[Ipswich SuperSprint]] | 0 | 24 | 12 |- | align="left" | [[The Bend SuperSprint]] | 0 | 24 | 12 |- | align="left" |[[Auckland SuperSprint]] | 32 | 0 | 12 |- | align="left" | [[Bathurst 1000]] | 36 | 0 | 24 |- | align="left" | [[Gold Coast 600]] | 0 | 28 | 20 |- | align="left" |[[Sandown 500]] | 0 | 32 | 20 |- | align="left" | [[Newcastle 500]] | 0 | 28 | 12 |- |}
==Notable events== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | image1 = Bathurst 1000 2005 3.jpg | caption1 = Cars on track during the [[2005 Bathurst 1000]]. | width1 = 200 | image2 = 2008 Clipsal 500 Podium.jpg | caption2 = Drivers on the podium during the [[2008 Clipsal 500]]. | width2 = 200 | image3 = Whincup leads 2014 Sydney NRMA 500.JPG | caption3 = The field on lap one at the [[2014 Sydney NRMA 500]]. | width3 = 200 }}
===Bathurst 1000=== {{main article|Bathurst 1000}}
The Bathurst 1000, also known as the "Great Race" and held in some form since [[1960 Armstrong 500|1960]], is the most famous race on the Supercars calendar,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.craiglowndes.com.au/News/091012.htm | title=Frustrating Day at Bathurst | work=CraigLowndes.com.au | quote=...for much of Australia's most famous motor race. | accessdate=29 March 2013}}</ref> as well as the longest both in terms of race distance and race time. The race is run over 161 laps of the [[Mount Panorama Circuit]], 1000 km in total, with the race taking between six and seven hours to complete. The event has attracted crowds of nearly 200,000 people.<ref name="V8TV" /> The [[Peter Brock Trophy]], named after nine-time Bathurst 1000 winner [[Peter Brock]], is awarded to the winners of the race. The trophy was introduced in [[2006 Bathurst 1000|2006]] following Brock's death in a crash at the [[Targa West]] rally one month prior to the race.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/Sport/Peter-Brock-Trophy-to-last-a-lifetime/2006/10/06/1159641505059.html | title=Peter Brock Trophy to last a lifetime | work=smh.com.au | publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald | date=6 October 2006 | accessdate=29 March 2013}}</ref>
===Sandown 500=== {{main article|Sandown 500}}
The Sandown 500 was first held as a six-hour race in [[1964 Sandown 6 Hour International|1964]]<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/motor-sports/v8-supercars/v8-supercars-stars-tell-speed-how-to-win-this-weekends-dick-smith-sandown-500/story-fn2ms9um-1226473877148#.UVeUTxwzhyI | title=V8 Supercars stars tell SPEED how to win this weekend's Dick Smith Sandown 500 | work=The Daily Telegraph | publisher=Fox Sports News | last=Kelly | first=Rick | date=14 September 2012 | accessdate=31 March 2013}}</ref> and has been labelled as the traditional "Bathurst warm-up" race.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.speedcafe.com/2012/09/08/crimsafe-endurance-countdown-episode-6-return-of-sandown-500/ | title=Crimsafe Endurance Countdown, Episode 6, Return of Sandown 500 | work=SpeedCafe | date=8 September 2012 | accessdate=31 March 2013}}</ref> Like the Bathurst 1000, the Sandown 500 is run over 161 laps. Due to the shorter track length of [[Sandown Raceway]], the race is only 500 km and runs for between three and four hours. The Sandown 500 was not held for Supercars from 1999 to 2002 and from 2008 to 2011. During these years, the 500 km endurance races took place at [[Queensland Raceway]] (1999–2002)<ref>{{cite web | url=http://v8supercar-racing.com/queensland-raceway.shtml | title=Queensland Raceway | publisher=V8 Supercar Racing | accessdate=31 March 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140801135129/http://v8supercar-racing.com/queensland-raceway.shtml | archivedate=1 August 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> and the [[Phillip Island Grand Prix Circuit]] (2008–2011).<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.carsguide.com.au/blogs-and-stuff/craig-lowndes/sandown_500_back_where_it_belongs/ | title=Sandown 500 back where it belongs | last=Lowndes | first=Craig | work=CarsGuide.com.au | quote=Over the past four years the 500km race has been staged at Phillip Island... | date=11 September 2012 | accessdate=31 March 2013}}</ref>
===Adelaide 500=== {{main article|Adelaide 500}} The Adelaide 500 has been held since [[1999 Sensational Adelaide 500|1999]] and has become the traditional season-opening event.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.news.com.au/breaking-news/the-2013-clipsal-500-will-keep-its-traditional-season-opening-spot-as-tickets-go-on-sale-today/story-e6frfkp9-1226486392849 | title=The 2013 Clipsal 500 will keep its traditional season opening spot as tickets go on sale today | last=Dale | first=William | work=SPEED | publisher=News Limited | date=2 October 2012 | accessdate=1 April 2013}}</ref> It is run on a shortened version of the former Adelaide Grand Prix Circuit. Consisting of two 250 km races run on Saturday and Sunday, the event has been labelled the most physically demanding by the drivers, due to the length of each race, the nature of the circuit and the effect of the heat.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.morrisfinance.com.au/news/clipsal-500-adelaide-preview-2013 | title=2013 Clipsal 500 Adelaide Preview | work=Morris Finance Ltd. | date=28 February 2013 | accessdate=1 April 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130409213821/http://www.morrisfinance.com.au/news/clipsal-500-adelaide-preview-2013 | archivedate=9 April 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The event's format was changed for 2014, with the Saturday race being replaced with a pair of 125 km races.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.v8supercars.com.au/news/2014-clipsal-500-details-revealed | title=2014 Clipsal 500 Details Revealed | work=V8Supercars.com.au | date=14 November 2013 | accessdate=15 January 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140117075255/http://www.v8supercars.com.au/news/2014-clipsal-500-details-revealed | archivedate=17 January 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The event attracts crowds of over 250,000 people<ref name="V8TV" /> and is the only event to be inducted into the [[V8 Supercar Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.clipsal.com.au/trade/news/archive_news/2005/clipsal_500 | title=Clipsal 500 inducted into Motor Sport Hall of Fame | work=Clipsal.com.au | year=2005 | accessdate=1 April 2013}}</ref> The Adelaide 500 was the first carnival-style event which would become common in the ten years after its inception, with music concerts held during the night.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.clipsal500.com.au/the_attractions/overview/the_concerts | title=The Concerts | publisher=Clipsal500.com.au | accessdate=1 April 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130413110845/http://clipsal500.com.au/the_attractions/overview/the_concerts | archivedate=13 April 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Gold Coast 600/ 500=== {{main article|Gold Coast 600}} The Gold Coast 600 was introduced in [[2009 V8 Supercar Championship Series|2009]] after the American [[IndyCar Series]] elected not to return to the Surfers Paradise circuit that year. The [[A1 Grand Prix]] series was scheduled to fill the void left by IndyCar,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2009-02-17/gold-coast-indy-undergoes-name-change/298424 | title=Gold Coast Indy undergoes name change | work=ABC News | date=17 February 2009 | accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref> however the owners of the series went into [[liquidation]] in June 2009 and,<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financialcrisis/5664677/British-A1-Grand-Prix-arm-stalls.html | title=British A1 Grand Prix arm stalls | last=Harrington | first=Ben | work=The Telegraph | date=27 June 2009 | accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref> as a result, the A1 Grand Prix cars were withdrawn from the event.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/a1-shambles-is-the-pits-anna/story-e6freoof-1225787873936 | title=A1 shambles is the pits, Anna | last1=Passmore | first1=Daryl | last2=Stannard | first2=Damien | work=The Courier Mail | date=17 October 2009 | accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref> In order to compensate for this, Supercars introduced a new four-race format, with two 150 km races held on each day.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.speedcafe.com.au/2009/10/18/v8-teams-prepared-for-extra-miles-at-supergp/ | title=V8 teams prepared for extra miles in Qld | work=SpeedCafe | date=18 October 2009 | accessdate=7 April 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625121417/http://www.speedcafe.com.au/2009/10/18/v8-teams-prepared-for-extra-miles-at-supergp/ | archivedate=25 June 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2010 the format changed to include two 300 km races and it became a two-driver event. To restore the event's previous international flavour, each team was required to have at least one co-driver with an 'international reputation' (that is, they were recognised for exploits in motorsport outside of Australia).<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.speedcafe.com.au/2010/04/22/stars-confirmed-for-gold-coast-600/ | title=Stars confirmed for Gold Coast 600 | work=SpeedCafe | date=22 April 2010 | accessdate=7 April 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130625114831/http://www.speedcafe.com.au/2010/04/22/stars-confirmed-for-gold-coast-600/ | archivedate=25 June 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> In [[2011 International V8 Supercars Championship|2011]] and [[2012 International V8 Supercars Championship|2012]], all entries required an international co-driver. In 2013 the international co-driver rule was dropped, due to a number of incidents during the 2012 event and the formation of the Endurance Cup, but teams could still choose to employ an international driver for the endurance races.<ref name="Enduro" />
===Newcastle 500=== {{Main article|Newcastle 500}}
In 2004, Supercars introduced the name "Grand Finale"<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.v8dailydump.com.au/events/motorsport/sessionList.tt2?SERIESID=1&EVENTID=200413&YEAR=2004 | title=Grand Finale, Eastern Creek Raceway – Round 13 | publisher=V8 Daily Dump | accessdate=1 April 2013}}</ref> for the final round of the season (having called it "The Main Event" in 2003 and the "V8 Ultimate" in 2001 and 2002).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.v8dailydump.com.au/events/motorsport/sessionList.tt2?SERIESID=1&EVENTID=13&YEAR=2003 | title=The Main Event – Eastern Creek Raceway – Round 13 | publisher=V8 Daily Dump | accessdate=1 April 2013}}</ref> The Grand Finale was held at [[Sandown Raceway]] in 2001 and 2002, [[Sydney Motorsport Park]] in 2003 and 2004, [[Phillip Island Grand Prix Circuit|Phillip Island]] in 2005, 2006 and 2007 and [[Oran Park Raceway]] in 2008. The Grand Finale name was used until 2008 before the Sydney 500 became the final event of the series in 2009.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.news.com.au/breaking-news/homebush-v8-race-gets-go-ahead/story-e6frfkp9-1111117617476 | title=Homebush V8 race gets go ahead | work=News.com.au | date=29 September 2008 | accessdate=1 April 2013}}</ref> The Sydney 500 was held around [[Homebush Street Circuit|the streets]] of [[Sydney Olympic Park]]. Its format was similar to the Adelaide 500, with a 250 km race held on both Saturday and Sunday. Despite having a relatively simple layout, the circuit was one of the more challenging on the calendar – as evidenced in the 2010 title decider when, in wet conditions, the top three championship runners all slid into the wall at the same time – effectively handing the title to [[James Courtney]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/sport/homebush-street-cicruit-throws-up-challenge-to-v8-stars/story-e6frg7mf-1225807089093 | title=Homebush street circuit throws up challenge to V8 stars | work=The Australian | date=4 December 2009 | accessdate=1 April 2013}}</ref> The Sydney 500 was held for the final time in 2016.<ref name="axe">{{cite news | url=http://www.speedcafe.com/2016/03/22/axe-falls-on-sydney-olympic-park-street-race/ | title=Axe falls on Sydney Olympic Park street race | work=Speedcafe | date=22 March 2016 | accessdate=20 April 2016}}</ref> The event at Sydney Olympic Park was replaced with a new street race in [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle]], 150 km north of Sydney, which will consist of the [[Newcastle Street Circuit|streets]] in the eastern suburbs of the city.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.speedcafe.com/2016/09/27/supercars-confirms-five-year-newcastle-deal/|title=Supercars confirms five-year Newcastle deal|publisher=Speedcafe.com}}</ref>
==Media coverage== [[File:Neil Crompton 2014.png|thumb|right|150px|Long-time series commentator [[Neil Crompton]] at the 2014 series test day.]]
===Television=== The series is currently broadcast on [[Fox Sports (Australia)|Fox Sports]] and [[Network Ten]], in a deal worth $241 million.<ref name="SupercarsTV">{{cite news | url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/motor-sports/v8-supercars/v8-supercars-signs-241m-media-rights-deal-with-fox-sports-foxtel-and-ten-network-from-2015/story-fn2ms9um-1226785594801 | title=V8 Supercars signs $241m media rights deal with FOX SPORTS, Foxtel and Ten Network from 2015 | work=[[Fox Sports]] | date=18 December 2013 | accessdate=18 December 2013}}</ref> Fox Sports shows all practice and qualifying sessions live along with the races. Ten shows only seven events live which are Adelaide, Melbourne, Townsville, Sandown, Bathurst, Gold Coast and Newcastle with the rest shown as a highlights package after the races have finished. The coverage is produced by Supercars Media, a specialist production company for Supercars Australia.<ref name="SupercarsTV" /> Supercars Media provides the commentary for each race, with former champion and Bathurst winner [[Mark Skaife]] as lead commentator, along with [[Neil Crompton]] as expert commentator. [[Mark Larkham]], Riana Crehan and former driver [[Greg Murphy]] cover the pit lane. Both Fox Sports and Ten use their own commentary team for pre- and post-race coverage.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.v8supercars.com.au/news/championship/v8-supercars-commentary-team-revealed | title=V8 Supercars commentary team revealed | work=V8Supercars.com.au | date=6 February 2015 | accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref> Supercars Media records the series in [[1080i]] [[high-definition television|high-definition]], with many cars carrying four or more onboard-cameras, though HD coverage is available only to subscribers of [[Foxtel HD]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Bartholomaeus | first = Stefan | url = http://www.speedcafe.com/2015/03/03/jury-out-on-v8-tv-deal-after-solid-start/ | title = Jury out on V8 Supercars TV deal after solid start | publisher = ''Speedcafe'' | date = 3 March 2015}}</ref>
The series had previously been broadcast by the [[Seven Network]], from 1963 to 1996 and from 2007 to 2014,<ref name="Seven">{{cite news | url=http://www.mediaspy.org/2013/01/15/seven-extends-v8-supercars-television-deal/ | title=Seven extends V8 Supercars television deal | last=Washbrook | first=Cyril | work=Media Spy | date=15 January 2013 | accessdate=23 March 2013}}</ref> Network Ten and Fox Sports from 1997 to 2006 and from 2015 onwards,<ref name="C10"/> During the years of Network Ten and Fox Sports continued to broadcast the series once a year for the [[Melbourne 400]] championship races, which are a support category at the Formula One Rolex Australian Grand Prix, which was broadcast by Ten and Fox Sports. Previously when the [[Nine Network]] held the Formula One Rolex Australian Grand Prix broadcast rights in Australia, they would broadcast the Supercars support races at the Formula One Rolex Australian Grand Prix. All support category races were tied up with the Formula One Rolex Australian Grand Prix broadcast rights as a package.
Ten's television series ''[[RPM (TV series)|RPM]]'', which has aired from 1997 to 2008, in 2011 and from 2015 onwards, has covered Supercars, alongside other motorsports. From 2007 to 2014, Seven broadcast a weekly 25-minute show titled ''[[V8Xtra]]'' on non-racing weekends. The dedicated Supercars program covered news and feature items relating to the series. Since 2015, Fox Sports has broadcast a similar show, ''[[Inside Supercars]]'', a weekly one-hour long program featuring a panel led by Rust and Mark Skaife.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.v8supercars.com.au/news/championship/inside-supercars-debuts-this-evening | title=Inside Supercars debuts this evening | work=V8Supercars.com.au | date=3 March 2015 | accessdate=19 September 2015}}</ref> In the same year, Fox Sports also launched an observational show ''[[Supercars Life]]'', featuring behind the scenes footage from race weekends and features on drivers' lives away from the track. In 2018, ''Inside Supercars'' was superseded by a new show on Fox Sports, ''[[Supercars Trackside]]''. Instead of being filmed in a studio midweek, the show is filmed on the Thursday before and the Sunday after each race meeting at the circuit.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.speedcafe.com/2018/03/01/fox-sports-enhances-supercars-tv-experience/|title=Fox Sports enhances Supercars TV experience|last=Howard|first=Tom|date=1 March 2018|publisher=Speedcafe|accessdate=4 March 2018}}</ref>
The television broadcast of the Bathurst 1000 has won a [[Logie Award]] for the Most Outstanding Sports Coverage seven times, most recently for the [[2017 Bathurst 1000]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.supercars.com/news/championship/bathurst-coverage-takes-out-logie-award/|title=Bathurst coverage takes out Logie Award|last=Bartholomaeus|first=Stefan|date=1 July 2018|publisher=''Supercars.com''|accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref> Foxtel broadcast the [[2018 Bathurst 1000]] in [[4K resolution]], the first such broadcast in Australian sport.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.speedcafe.com/2018/09/19/bathurst-to-be-broadcast-in-4k-and-ad-break-free/|title=Bathurst to be broadcast in 4K and ad-break free|last=Howard|first=Tom|date=19 September 2018|publisher=Speedcafe|accessdate=10 October 2018}}</ref>
====Current TV broadcasters==== Supercars races are broadcast on the following channels:<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.motorstv.com/sitemap-and-services | title=Sitemap and services | publisher=Motors TV | accessdate=23 March 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130313010312/http://www.motorstv.com/sitemap-and-services | archivedate=13 March 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.v8supercars.com.au/news/v8-supercars-and-sky-tv-nz-announce-five-year-agreement | title=V8 Supercars and Sky TV NZ Announce Five Year Agreement | work=V8Supercars.com.au | publisher=V8 Supercars Australia | date=27 February 2013 | accessdate=23 March 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130402121246/http://www.v8supercars.com.au/news/v8-supercars-and-sky-tv-nz-announce-five-year-agreement | archivedate=2 April 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.v8scglobal.com/watch-v8-supercars/ |title=Watch V8 Supercars |publisher=V8SC Global |accessdate=30 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130318143147/http://www.v8scglobal.com/watch-v8-supercars/ |archivedate=18 March 2013 }}</ref> {|class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%" |- ! Country ! TV network ! Free/pay ! Live/delayed ! Notes |- | rowspan="2"| [[Australia]] | [[Network Ten]] | align="center"| Free | align="center"| Live/Delayed | Seven events shown live with all others delayed. |- | [[Fox Sports (Australia)|Fox Sports]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Live | Includes live coverage of practice and qualifying sessions. |- | [[Africa]] | [[OSN]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Delayed | |- | [[Asia]] | [[Fox Sports Asia]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Live/Delayed | Only races are shown. |- | [[Brazil]] | [[BandSports]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Delayed | |- | [[Canada]] | [[CBS Sports Network]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Delayed | |- | [[Caribbean]] | [[ESPN Caribbean|ESPN]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Live/Delayed | |- | [[Europe]] | [[Motors TV]] | align="center"| Free/Pay | align="center"| Live/Delayed |- | [[Hungary]] | [[Spíler TV]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Live/Delayed |-
|- | [[Latin America]] | [[ESPN Latin America|ESPN]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Live/Delayed | |- | [[India]] | [[Sony ESPN]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Live/Delayed | |- | [[Malaysia]] | [[Astro (Malaysian satellite television)|Astro]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Live | Only races are shown. |- | [[Middle East]] | [[OSN]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Delayed |- | [[Netherlands]] | [[Ziggo Sport]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Live/Delayed |- | [[New Zealand]] | [[Sky Sport (New Zealand)|Sky Sport]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Live | Includes live coverage of practice and qualifying sessions. |- | [[Thailand]] | [[TrueVisions]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Live | Only races are shown. |- | [[United Kingdom]] | [[FreeSports]] | align="center"| Free | align="center"| 2 week delay | Only races shown. |- | [[United States]] | [[CBS Sports Network]] | align="center"| Pay | align="center"| Delayed | |}
===Other media=== The series has its own live streaming [[pay-per-view]] service, Superview. The service, which started in 2013, currently shows all races as well as qualifying sessions. The service is not available in New Zealand and Australia due to their current broadcasting rights with [[Sky Sport (New Zealand)|Sky Sport]] and [[Fox Sports Australia|Fox Sports]].
The series has its own website, which contains information about the series, drivers, teams and events and news articles, and a radio show, V8 Insiders. News is also featured on motorsport websites such as [[Speedcafe]], [[V8X Magazine]] and Touring Car Times. A media deal with [[News Corp Australia]] has been in place since 2009.
===Video games=== {{main article|Supercars Championship in video games}} Supercars have made several licensed appearances in [[video games]], including in [[Codemasters]]' [[TOCA Touring Car series|''V8 Supercars'' series]] in the 2000s and [[Turn 10 Studios]]' ''[[Forza (series)|Forza]]'' series in the 2010s. From 2011 to 2014, an online championship, sanctioned by Supercars, was contested on [[iRacing]].<ref>{{cite news |last=B |first=Kevin |date=1 August 2011 |title=V8 Supercars to Sanction iRacing.com Series|url=http://www.iracing.com/v8-supercars-to-sanction-iracing-com-series/ |newspaper=iRacing.com |access-date=2 August 2016 }}</ref> In 2017, Supercars launched an [[eSports]] competition using [[Forza Motorsport 6]] and [[Forza Motorsport 7]], which expanded to six rounds in 2018.<ref name="esports17">{{cite web|url=http://www.speedcafe.com/2017/09/08/supercars-announces-new-e-sports-event/|title=Supercars announces new e-Sports event|last=Howard|first=Tom|date=8 September 2017|publisher=[[Speedcafe]]|accessdate=10 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.speedcafe.com/2018/08/31/supercars-to-launch-new-esports-series/|title=Supercars to launch new eSports series|last=Howard|first=Tom|date=31 August 2018|publisher=Speedcafe|accessdate=6 September 2018}}</ref>
==Records== {| class="wikitable" border="1" style="font-size:85%;" |- style="background:#efefef;" !width=20% colspan=3| Driver championships<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.v8dailydump.com.au/v8-championship/championship-history/most-championships/ | title=Most Championships Won | publisher=V8 Daily Dump | accessdate=1 July 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160328033739/http://www.v8dailydump.com.au/v8-championship/championship-history/most-championships/ | archivedate=28 March 2016 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> !width=2% rowspan=14| !width=20% colspan=3| Driver race wins<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.v8supercars.com.au/news/winning-record-in-sight-for-lowndes | title=Winning Record In Sight For Lowndes | work=V8Supercars.com.au | date=3 March 2013 | accessdate=1 July 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130501175303/http://www.v8supercars.com.au/news/winning-record-in-sight-for-lowndes | archivedate=1 May 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> <ref name="Townsville Supercars: Whincup breaks through for 105th win">{{cite news|url=https://twitter.com/Fox_Motorsport/status/899141320635109376|title=Jamie Whincup breaks all-time win record|last=|first=|date=20 August 2017|work=Fox Motorsport|accessdate=20 August 2017|publisher=Fox Motorsport}}</ref>

{{Infobox television | show_name = The Dovekeepers | image = | alt = | caption = | genre = [[Biblical]]
[[Historical Drama]] | runtime = 180 minutes | creator = | based_on = The book ''[[The Dovekeepers (novel)|The Dovekeepers]]'' by [[Alice Hoffman]] | composer = [[Jeff Beal]] | opentheme = | director = [[Yves Simoneau]] | writer = Ann Peacock (teleplay) | executive_producer = [[Roma Downey]]
[[Mark Burnett]]
John Weber
Frank Siracusa
[[Yves Simoneau]] | producer = [[Alice Hoffman]] | starring = [[Cote de Pablo]]
[[Rachel Brosnahan]] | cinematography = [[Guy Dufaux]] | editor = Sylvain Lebel
Isabelle Malenfant | company = Take 5 Productions
Whiz Bang Films
[[Lightworkers Media]]
[[CBS Television Studios]] | distributor = | network = [[CBS]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2015|03|31}} | last_aired = {{End date|2015|04|01}} | country = United States | language = English | location = [[Malta]] | num_seasons = | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | website = http://www.cbs.com/shows/the-dovekeepers | website_title = | related = ''[[Masada (miniseries)|Masada]]'' | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Dovekeepers''''' is a two-part television adaptation based on the book of the same name by [[Alice Hoffman]] from executive producers [[Roma Downey]] and [[Mark Burnett]]. It features the [[Siege of Masada]] by troops of the Roman Empire towards the end of the First Jewish–Roman War.{{cite web|url=http://alicehoffman.com/books/the-dovekeepers/synopsis/|title=The Dovekeepers: Synopsis|publisher=Alice Hoffman|accessdate=4 April 2015}} The program premiered in the United States on March 31, 2015 on [[CBS]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/shows/the-dovekeepers/about/|title=The Dovekeepers|publisher=CBS|accessdate=4 April 2015}} ==Plot== According to the official [[trailer (film)|trailer]], {{cquote|From the producers of ''[[The Bible (TV series)|The Bible]]'', comes the story of a place called Masada, where four extraordinary women faced an army of thousands. A healer accused of witchcraft. An outcast haunted by her past. A woman with the heart of a warrior.|}} '''Tagline:''' The trailer featured the tagline, "Their journey. Their passion. It all leads up to this. Take a stand." ==Main cast== *[[Cote de Pablo]] as Shirah *[[Rachel Brosnahan]] as Yael *[[Kathryn Prescott]] as Aziza *[[Diego Boneta]] as Amram *[[Sam Neill]] as [[Josephus|Flavius Josephus]] *[[Mido Hamada]] as [[Eleazar ben Ya'ir]] *[[Sam Hazeldine]] as [[Lucius Flavius Silva|Flavius Silva]] *[[Jonas Armstrong]] as Yoav *[[Luke Roberts (actor)|Luke Roberts]] as Jachim Ben Simon *[[Fiona O'Shaughnessy]] as Channa *Kenneth Spiteri as Claudius *Diarmaid Murtagh as Wynn *Manuel Cauchi as Josef Bar Elhanan *Andre Agius as Adir *Marama Corlett as Sia ==Episodes== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%; background:#fff; margin:auto;" |- !style="background:#B30713; width:5%;"|Ep. # !style="background:#B30713; width:20%;"|Title !style="background:#B30713; width:20%;"|Original airdate !style="background:#B30713; width:10%;"|Viewers
(million) {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber= 1.1 |Title= Part 1 |OriginalAirDate= {{start date|2015|03|31}} |Viewers= 8.99http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2015/04/01/tv-ratings-tuesday-weird-loners-the-dovekeepers-start-soft-marvels-agents-of-s-h-i-e-l-d-new-girl-hit-lows-the-flash-izombie-flat/382572/ |ShortSummary=Roman historian Flavius Josephus chronicles the lives of three Jewish women during the Romans' siege of Masada in A.D. 73, where more than 900 Jews were able to take refuge at the fortress for months. But first he pressures two of them into telling their versions of the story; Shirah, believed to be the witch of Moab, and Yael, an outcast to her father and neighbors. In order to tell the story, they must first go back to the beginning and share accounts of their pasts. |LineColor=B30713 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber= 1.2 |Title= Part 2 |OriginalAirDate= {{start date|2015|04|01}} |Viewers=6.40http://deadline.com/2015/04/dovekeepers-ratings-down-american-idol-blackish-lmodern-family-abc-1201403344/ |ShortSummary=Shirah and Yael remain in the custody of Flavius Josephus in his house in Rome. They tell of how Shirah's warrior daughter, Aziza joins them in their duty of keepers of the messenger doves in their home. Roman centurions Flavius Silva and Claudius devise a plan in how to get their soldiers into Masada. But to the Jewish [[sicarii]], it's "freedom or death" as they hole up in the last Jewish fortress in [[Judea]] before the fateful day of the siege. |LineColor=B30713 }} |} ==Reception== The adaptation garnered negative reviews: Keith Uhlich of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' writes "True to its title, this romantic-historical miniseries is more fowl than fair. CBS' two-part adaptation of Alice Hoffman's best-selling novel is a cheap, chintzy adventure." while Brian Lowry of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' writes "Designed to play as a moving adaptation of Alice Hoffman's bestseller, ''The Dovekeepers'' is more of a wounded duck."https://variety.com/t/the-dovekeepers/ ==See also== * [[The Dovekeepers (novel)|''The Dovekeepers'' (novel)]] * ''[[Masada (miniseries)|Masada]]'', a 1981 television dramatization of the events at Masada ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.cbs.com/shows/the-dovekeepers}} * {{IMDb title|tt3656138|The Dovekeepers}} * {{TV Guide|678037}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dovekeepers, The}} [[Category:American television films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:2010s American television series]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Television series based on actual events]] [[Category:Television series by CBS Television Studios]] [[Category:Television series by MGM Television]] [[Category:Television series created by Roma Downey]]

{{italic title}} [[Image:TheIslandPoster.jpg|right|frame|Poster for the 2000 Royal National Theatre production]] '''''The Island''''' is a play written by [[Athol Fugard]], [[John Kani]], and [[Winston Ntshona]].
The [[apartheid]]-era drama, inspired by a true story, is set in an unnamed [[prison]] clearly based on [[South Africa]]'s notorious [[Robben Island]], where [[Nelson Mandela]] was held for twenty-seven years. It focuses on two cellmates, one whose successful appeal means that his release draws near and one who must remain in prison for many years to come. They spend their days performing futile physical labor and nights rehearsing in their cell for a performance of [[Sophocles]]' ''[[Antigone (Sophocles)|Antigone]]'' in front of the other prisoners. One takes the part of Antigone, who defies the laws of the state to bury her brother, and the other takes the part of her uncle Creon, who sentences her to die for her crime of conscience. The play draws parallels between Antigone's situation and the situation of black political prisoners. Tensions arise as the performance approaches, especially when one of the prisoners learns that he has won an early release and the men's deep friendship is tested. ''The Island'' bears testament to the resiliency of the human heart.
==Structure== The play has four scenes. It opens with a lengthy mimed sequence in which John and Winston, two cell mates imprisoned on Robben Island, shovel sand in the scorching heat, dumping the sand at the feet of the other man, so that the pile of sand never diminishes. This is designed to exhaust the body and the morale of the prisoners. Later scenes include a [[play within a play]], as Winston and John perform a condensed two-person version of ''Antigone'' by Sophocles.
==History== The play was first performed in Cape Town, at a theatre called [[Space Theatre (Cape Town)|The Space]], in July 1973. In order to evade the draconian censorship in South Africa at the time (plays dealing with prison conditions, etc., were prohibited), the play premiered under the title, ''Die Hodoshe Span''. It was next staged at the [[Royal Court Theatre]] in [[London]], with John Kani and Winston Ntshona portraying John and Winston respectively. The [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production, presented in [[repertory]] with ''[[Sizwe Banzi Is Dead]]'', opened on November 24, 1974 at the [[Edison Theatre]], where it ran for 52 performances.
In an unusual move, Kani and Ntshona were named co-[[Tony Award]] nominees (and eventual co-winners) for Best Actor in a Play for both ''The Island'' and ''Sizwe Banzi Is Dead''.
Over the next thirty years, Kani and Ntshona periodically performed in productions of the play. Notable among them were the [[Royal National Theatre]] in 2000 [http://www.nationaltheatre.org.uk/?lid=1246], reported at the time as their final production, although they went on to star at the [[Old Vic]] in 2002 [http://www.onlinereviewlondon.com/reviews/island.html] and the [[Brooklyn Academy of Music]] in 2004 [http://www.showbusinessweekly.com/archive/222/island.shtml].
==Plot== John and Winston share a prison cell on an unnamed Island. After another day of hard labor and having been forced to run while shackled and then beaten, they return to their cell. They tend each other's wounds, share memories of times at the beach and rehearse for the prisoner-performed concert which is imminent. They are going to perform a scene from an abridged version of ''Antigone'' by Sophocles. John will play Creon and Winston will play Antigone.
When he sees himself in his costume, Winston tries to pull out of playing a female role, fearing he will be humiliated. John is called to the governor's office. He returns with news that his appeal was successful and his ten-year sentence has been commuted to three years: he will be free in three months. Winston is happy for him. As they imagine what leaving prison and returning home will be like, Winston begins to unravel. He doubts why he ever made a stand against the regime, why he even exists. Having said it, he experiences a catharsis, and accepts that he must endure.
The final scene is their performance of ''Antigone''. After John-as-Creon sentences Winston-as-Antigone to be walled up in a cave for having defied him and done her duty towards her dead brother, Winston pulls off Antigone's wig and yells "Gods of Our Fathers! My Land! My Home! Time waits no longer. I go now to my living death, because I honored those things to which honor belongs". The final image is of John and Winston, chained together once more, running hard as the siren wails.
==Characters== * John has been imprisoned for belonging to a banned organization. * Winston, we find out later was imprisoned for burning his passbook in front of the police. This was a serious crime, as the passbook was used to segregate and control the South African people. * Hodoshe, an [[unseen character]]: he is referred to and represented by the sound of a prison whistle. He is a symbol of the apartheid state and racist rule. The literal translation for Hodoshe is "carrion fly" (as mentioned in the play), a large green fly.
==Themes== * [[Racial segregation]] * Obedience and [[civil disobedience]] * Brotherhood * Freedom – bodily freedom, freedom of conscience and freedom of the mind * Memory, imagination, and the transformative power of performance
==Language== Although the play is in English, [[Afrikaans]] and [[Xhosa language|Xhosa]] words are spoken as well.
==Broadway awards and nominations== * Tony Award for Best Play (co-nominee with ''Sizwe Banzi'') * Tony Award for Best Actor in Play (Kani and Ntshona, '''winners''') * Tony Award for Best Direction of a Play (nominee) * [[Drama Desk Award]] for Outstanding Actor in a Play (Kani and Ntshona, co-nominees) * Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Director of a Play (nominee) * Drama Desk Award for Outstanding New Foreign Play (co-nominee with ''Sizwe Banzi'')
==External links== * [http://www.ibdb.com/production.asp?id=3496 Internet Broadway Database listing] * [http://www.theatreinchicago.com/playdetail.php?playID=3233 The Island] * [http://www.studymode.com/essays/The-Island-By-Athol-Fugard-149004.html "The Island" by Athol Fugard]
{{Plays by Athol Fugard}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Island, The}} [[Category:1973 plays]] [[Category:Broadway plays]] [[Category:South African plays]] [[Category:Plays by Athol Fugard]] [[Category:Plays based on Greek and Roman plays]] [[Category:Plays based on actual events]] [[Category:Plays about apartheid]] [[Category:Plays set in South Africa]] [[Category:Islands in fiction]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = Yahoo! GeoCities | logo = Yahoo! Geocities.png | url = {{URL|www.geocities.co.jp}} | commercial = Yes | type = [[Web hosting]] | registration = Yes | owner = [[Yahoo! Japan]] | author = [[David Bohnett]] and John Rezner | alexa = {{Decrease}} 1,179 ({{as of|2016|11|26|alt=November 2016}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web |url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/geocities.co.jp |title= Geocities.co.jp Site Info |publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2016-11-26 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170218050931/http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/geocities.co.jp |archivedate= 2017-02-18 |df= }}</ref> | logocaption = 2009–present logo. | launch date = {{start date and age|1994|11}} | current status = Being discontinued in [[Japan]]; defunct in the [[United States]], [[Canada]], and [[Europe]] }}
'''Yahoo! GeoCities''' is a soon-to-be defunct [[web hosting service]]. It was founded in November 1994<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/jan/29/business/fi-2730|title=Yahoo to Buy GeoCities for $3.9 Billion in Stock - latimes|work=[[LA Times]]|date=1999-01-29|accessdate=2016-03-14|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20160315054132/http://articles.latimes.com/1999/jan/29/business/fi-2730|archivedate=2016-03-15|df=}}</ref> by [[David Bohnett]] and [[John Rezner]], and was called '''Beverly Hills Internet''' ('''BHI''') for a very short time before being named '''GeoCities'''.<ref name=podcast>McCullough, Brian. [http://www.internethistorypodcast.com/2015/05/david-bohnett-founder-of-geocities/ "DAVID BOHNETT, FOUNDER OF GEOCITIES"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150528095940/http://www.internethistorypodcast.com/2015/05/david-bohnett-founder-of-geocities/ |date=2015-05-28 }} (interview podcast). ''Internet History Podcast''. May 11, 2015.</ref> On January 28, 1999, GeoCities was acquired by [[Yahoo!]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yhoo.client.shareholder.com/press/timeline.cfm |title=Yahoo! Inc. - Company Timeline |work=[[Wayback Machine]] |date=2008-07-13 |accessdate=2016-07-19 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080713214826/http://yhoo.client.shareholder.com/press/timeline.cfm |archivedate=2008-07-13 |df= }}</ref> at that time it was the third-most visited website on the [[World Wide Web]]. In its original form, site users selected a "city" in which to place their [[web page]]s. The "cities" were named after real cities or regions according to their content—for example, [[computer]]-related sites were placed in "SiliconValley" and those dealing with [[entertainment]] were assigned to "Hollywood"—hence the name of the site. Shortly after its acquisition by [[Yahoo!]], this practice was abandoned in favor of using the Yahoo! member names in the URLs.
In April 2009, approximately ten years after Yahoo! bought GeoCities,<ref name="cnn1999"/> the company announced that it would shut down the United States GeoCities service on October 26, 2009.<ref name="PCMagGeo">{{cite web| url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2350024,00.asp| title=Yahoo Sets the Date of GeoCities' Death| last=Fox| first=Geoff| date=2009-07-10| publisher=PCMag.com| accessdate=2010-11-05| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100831064914/http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2350024,00.asp| archivedate=2010-08-31| df=}}</ref><ref name="TechCrunch">{{cite web | first=Leena | last=Rao | title=Yahoo Quietly Pulls The Plug On GeoCities | url=https://techcrunch.com/2009/04/23/yahoo-quietly-pulls-the-plug-on-geocities/ | date=2009-04-23 | work=[[TechCrunch]] | accessdate=2009-04-30 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20090501112554/https://techcrunch.com/2009/04/23/yahoo-quietly-pulls-the-plug-on-geocities/ | archivedate=2009-05-01 | df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2009/10/geocities-closing.html |title=GeoCities' time has expired, Yahoo closing the site today |first=Mark |last=Millian |publisher=LA Times (blog) |date=2009-10-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121221025310/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2009/10/geocities-closing.html |archivedate=2012-12-21 |df= }}</ref> There were at least 38 million user-built pages on GeoCities before it was shut down.<ref>{{cite web |last=Shechmeister |first=Matthew |url=https://www.wired.com/rawfile/2009/11/geocities |title=Ghost Pages: A Wired.com Farewell to GeoCities |publisher=Wired.com |date=2009-11-03 |accessdate=2012-02-20 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120115003059/http://www.wired.com/rawfile/2009/11/geocities |archivedate=2012-01-15 |df= }}</ref> The GeoCities Japan version of the service will shut down at the end of March 2019.<ref name="GeocitiesJ"/>
== Neighborhoods == In 1996, GeoCities had 29 "neighborhoods," which had groupings of content created by the "homesteaders" (GeoCities users).<ref name="Neighborhoods1996">"[https://web.archive.org/web/19961219233921/http://www.geocities.com/homestead/homedir.html 29 Neighborhoods]." ''GeoCities''. December 19, 1996. Retrieved on April 30, 2009.</ref> By 1999, GeoCities had additional neighborhoods and refocused existing neighborhoods.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/19990209135604/http://geocities.com/neighborhoods/ Visit these neighborhoods]." ''GeoCities''. February 9, 1999. Retrieved on April 30, 2009.</ref>
{{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * [[Area 51|Area51]] and Vault: Science fiction and fantasy, [[conspiracy theories]] * [[Athens]] and Acropolis: Teaching, education, reading, writing, and philosophy * [[Augusta, Georgia|Augusta]]: Golf * Baja: Off-road SUVs and adventure travel * [[Bourbon Street|BourbonStreet]]: [[Jazz music]], [[Cajun food]], [[New Orleans]] and [[Southern United States]] topics * [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]: Theater<!-- American spelling --> and performing arts * [[Cape Canaveral|CapeCanaveral]] and Lab: Science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and aviation * [[Capitol Hill|CapitolHill]]: Politics and government * [[College Park, Maryland|CollegePark]] and Quad: University life * [[Colosseum]], Field and Loge: Athletics and sports * EnchantedForest: Topics of interest to children * Eureka: Small business and home offices * [[Fashion Avenue]]: Fashion * Heartland and Plains: Parenting and family (originally also focused on pets)<ref name="Neighborhoods1996"/> * [[Hollywood]] and Hills: Films and actors * HotSprings: Health and fitness * [[Madison Avenue|MadisonAvenue]]: Advertising * [[Detroit|MotorCity]]: Automobiles and racing and dodge cars * [[Napa Valley|NapaValley]]: Wine, [[gastronomy]] * [[Nashville]]: Country music * [[Rive Gauche (Paris)|LeftBank]]: Romance, poetry, and the arts (for Paris-related topics such as food and culture around 1996)<ref name="Neighborhoods1996"/> {{col-2}} * [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]]: Military * Petsburgh: Pets * PicketFence: Home improvement and real estate * Pipeline: Extreme sports * RainForest: Conservation * [[Rodeo Drive|RodeoDrive]]: Shopping and upscale lifestyles * [[Research Triangle|ResearchTriangle]]: Research and development, technology * [[Silicon Valley|SiliconValley]], Heights, Park, and Pines: Computers, hardware, programming, and technology * [[SoHo]] and Lofts: Art and writing * [[South Beach|SouthBeach]] and Marina: A "high-style hot spot for hanging out, meeting and greeting, seeing and being seen." * [[Sunset Strip|SunsetStrip]], Vine, Alley, Palms, Studio and Towers: Music such as blues, grunge, punk rock, and rock 'n roll * TheTropics and Shores: Travel and vacations * [[CBS Television City|TelevisionCity]]: Television * [[Times Square|TimesSquare]] and Arcade: Computer and video games * [[Tokyo]]: Far East-related topics, including anime * [[Vienna]]: Ballet, classical music, and opera * [[Wall Street|WallStreet]]: Business and finance * [[Wellesley College|Wellesley]]: Women-related topics * [[West Hollywood, California|WestHollywood]]: Gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender topics * [[Yosemite]]: Outdoor recreation including climbing, hiking, rafting, and skiing {{col-end}}
== GeoCities Marketplace == In 1999, GeoCities had an online commercial presence with GeoCities Marketplace. It included the GeoStore, which sold GeoCities-branded merchandise. Users cashed in GeoPoints in the store.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/19990209074656/http://www.geocities.com/marketplace/ "GeoCities Marketplace"]. ''GeoCities''. February 9, 1999. Retrieved on May 1, 2009.</ref>
== GeoCities Japan == Prior to the takeover by [[Yahoo!]], GeoCities had a Japanese subsidiary, GeoCities Japan. GeoCities Japan was headquartered in the Nihonbashi Hakozaki Building in the [[Nihonbashi]] area of [[Chūō, Tokyo]].<ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/19990221225412/http://www.geocities.co.jp/features/recruit/ スタッフ募集]." ''GeoCities Japan''. February 21, 1999. Retrieved on April 30, 2009.</ref>
As of February 10, 2016, GeoCities Japan was still online, with no signs of upcoming closure. Its member sites are still accessible, and it is still accepting new account registrations, but now all services are only available in [[Japanese language|Japanese]].<ref name="GeocitiesJ">{{cite web |url=https://info-geocities.yahoo.co.jp/close/index.html |title=Yahoo!ジオシティーズ |publisher=Geocities.yahoo.co.jp |date= |accessdate=2018-10-01 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224041126/http://geocities.yahoo.co.jp/ |archivedate=2012-02-24 |df= }}</ref>
On October 1, 2018, Yahoo! Japan announced the closure of GeoCities Japan effective March 31, 2019.<ref>{{citenews|url=https://japan.cnet.com/article/35126373/|work=[[CNET]] Japan|title=Yahoo! GeoCities service to shut down at the end of March 2019|language=Japanese|date=October 1, 2018|accessdate=October 1, 2018}}</ref>
=== Japan neighborhoods === GeoCities Japan has the following neighborhoods:<ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/19990220082428/http://www.geocities.co.jp/neighborhoods/ コミュニティ]." ''GeoCities Japan''. Retrieved on April 30, 2009.</ref>
* {{nihongo|WallStreet|ウォール街|''Wōrugai''}}: Finance and business * {{nihongo|Epicurean Table|エピキュリアンテーブル|''Epikyurian Tēburu''}}: Dining * {{nihongo|Colosseum|コロシアム|''Koroshiamu''}}: Outdoor sports and health * {{nihongo|SiliconValley|シリコンバレー|''Shirikon Barē''}}: Computers and the internet * {{nihongo|SilkRoad|シルクロード|''Shiruku Rōdo''}}: Travel * {{nihongo|Technopolis|テクノポリス|''Tekunoporisu''}}: Science and high technology * {{nihongo|Berkeley|バークレイ|''Bākurei''}}: Education and student life * {{nihongo|Heartland|ハートランド|''Hātorando''}}: Family and pets * {{nihongo|Hollywood|ハリウッド|''Hariuddo''}}: Films and performing arts * {{nihongo|Playtown|プレイタウン|''Pureitaun''}}: Video games * {{nihongo|Broadway|ブロードウェイ|''Burōdowei''}}: Pop, rock music, and concerts * {{nihongo|Milano|ミラノ|''Mirano''}}: Fashion, design, and shopping * {{nihongo|Milkyway|ミルキーウェイ|''Mirukīwei''}}: Dating * {{nihongo|MotorCity|モーターシティ|''Mōtā Shiti''}}: Automobiles and motorcycles
== History == [[File:VeryFirstGeologo.png|thumb|The first GeoCities logo (1995–1998)]]
GeoCities began in mid-1995 as BHI, which stood for Beverly Hills Internet, a small Web hosting and development company in Southern California.<ref name=Business_Wire>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Beverly+Hills+Internet,+builder+of+interactive+cyber+cities,+launches...-a017190114 |title=Beverly Hills Internet, builder of interactive cyber cities, launches 4 more virtual communities linked to real places; SiliconValley, CapitolHill, Paris and Tokyo offer free homesteads to residents of BHI's 'GeoCities' |work=Business Wire |date=July 5, 1995 |accessdate=2013-08-22}}</ref>
The company created its own [[Web directory]], organized thematically in six "neighborhoods". The neighborhoods included "Colosseum," "Hollywood," "RodeoDrive," "SunsetStrip," "WallStreet," and "WestHollywood". In mid-1995, the company decided to offer users (thereafter known as "Homesteaders") the ability to develop free home pages within those neighborhoods. During the sign-up process, new members chose to which neighborhood they wanted to belong. This neighborhood became part of the member's Web address along with a sequentially assigned "street address" number to make the URL unique (for example, <nowiki>"www.geocities.com/RodeoDrive/number"</nowiki>). Chat, bulletin boards, and other elements of "community" were added soon after, helping foster rapid growth. On July 5, 1995 GeoCities added additional cities, including "CapitolHill," "Paris," "SiliconValley," and "Tokyo."<ref name=Business_Wire/> By December 1995, the company, which now had a total of 14 neighborhoods, was signing up thousands of Homesteaders a day and getting over six million monthly page views. GeoCities never enforced neighborhood specific content; for example, a "Hollywood" homesteader could be nothing but a college student's home page, which would be more appropriate for another neighborhood. The company decided to focus on building membership and community, and on December 15, 1995, BHI became known as GeoCities after having also been called Geopages.<ref name=AllBusiness>[http://www.allbusiness.com/marketing-advertising/marketing-advertising/7191644-1.html "Beverly Hills Internet, Builder of Web Communities, Changes Name to GeoCities; Monthly Page."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211170054/http://www.allbusiness.com/marketing-advertising/marketing-advertising/7191644-1.html |date=2008-12-11 }} ''Business Wire''. Thursday December 14, 1995. Retrieved on May 1, 2009.</ref> At that point GeoCities was headquartered at 9401 Wilshire Boulevard in [[Beverly Hills]].<ref name=AllBusiness/> By December 1996 it was headquartered on the third floor of 1918 Main Street in [[Santa Monica, California|Santa Monica]], with an office on the 8th floor of 125 Park Avenue in [[New York City]].<ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/19961219234521/http://www.geocities.com/BHI/ad_info.html Advertising and Sponsorship Information]." ''GeoCities''. December 19, 1996. Retrieved on April 30, 2009.</ref> [[File:Geocitiesoriginallogo.png|thumb|The second and last GeoCities logo of 1998–1999]] Over time, many companies, including [[Yahoo!]], invested extensively in GeoCities and, with the introduction of paid premium services, the site continued to grow. In May 1997, GeoCities introduced [[advertising|advertisements]] on its pages. Despite negative reaction from users, GeoCities continued to grow. By June 1997, GeoCities was the fifth most popular site on the Web, and by October of that year the company had signed up its millionth Homesteader.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}
In June 1998, in an effort to increase brand awareness, GeoCities introduced a [[watermark]] to user Web pages. The watermark, much like an [[Digital on-screen graphic|onscreen graphic]] on some television channels, was a transparent floating [[GIF]] which used JavaScript to stay on the bottom right side of the browser screen. Many users felt the watermark interfered with the design of their Web site and threatened to move their Web pages elsewhere. The implementation of the watermark preceded the widespread adoption of [[CSS]] and standardized [[Document Object Model|DOM]] and had cross-browser issues. However, GeoCities said in a press release that feedback regarding the watermark had been overwhelmingly positive.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://news.cnet.com/GeoCitizens-fume-over-watermark/2100-1023_3-212596.html |date = 1998-06-28 |title = GeoCitizens fume over watermark |first = Jim |last = Hu |publisher = CNet |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090805102516/http://news.cnet.com/GeoCitizens-fume-over-watermark/2100-1023_3-212596.html |archivedate = 2009-08-05 |df = }}</ref>
The company went public in August 1998, listing on the [[NASDAQ]] exchange with the code GCTY. The [[Initial public offering|IPO]] price was $17, rising rapidly after launch to a peak of over $100. By 1999 GeoCities was the third-most visited Web site on the World Wide Web, behind [[AOL]] and [[Yahoo!]].<ref name="MarshallVNU">Marshall, Rosalie. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20090426073628/http://www.vnunet.com/vnunet/news/2241092/yahoo-closing-geocities Yahoo closing Geocities web hosting service]." ''[[vnunet]]''. April 24, 2009. Retrieved on April 30, 2009.</ref> The headquarters had moved to 4499 Glencoe Avenue in Los Angeles, near the [[Marina del Rey]] area of [[Los Angeles County]].<ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/19990202213836/http://geocities.com/main/info/company/contact/ Contact GeoCities]." ''GeoCities''. Retrieved on February 22, 1999. April 30, 2009.</ref>
=== Acquisition by Yahoo! === [[File:FirstGeocitiesYahoo.png|thumb|The first Yahoo! GeoCities logo (1999-2009).]] In January 1999, near the peak of the [[dot-com bubble]], GeoCities was purchased by Yahoo! for $3.57 billion in stock, with Yahoo! taking control on May 28.<ref name="cnn1999">{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/1999/01/28/technology/yahoo_a/|date=1999-01-28|title=Yahoo! buys GeoCities|publisher=CNN.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180407170332/http://money.cnn.com/1999/01/28/technology/yahoo_a/|archivedate=2018-04-07|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/the_company_file/264577.stm |date = 1999-01-29 |title = Yahoo! moves in on GeoCities |first = Chris |last = Nuttall |publisher = BBC News |accessdate = 2009-06-03 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090427174659/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/the_company_file/264577.stm |archivedate = 2009-04-27 |df = }}</ref><ref name="Narasimhandeath">Narasimhan, Balaji. "[http://www.mid-day.com/lifestyle/2009/apr/270409-Geocities-former-websites-IT-Adda-Bangalore-Yahoo-Anglefire-Tripod.htm The death of GeoCities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090711152822/http://www.mid-day.com/lifestyle/2009/apr/270409-Geocities-former-websites-IT-Adda-Bangalore-Yahoo-Anglefire-Tripod.htm |date=2009-07-11 }}." ''[[MID-Day]]''. April 27, 2009. Retrieved on May 3, 2009.</ref> The acquisition proved extremely unpopular; users began to leave ''en masse'' in protest at the new [[terms of service]] put out by Yahoo! for GeoCities.<ref name="NYTimes">{{cite news |url = http://emoglen.law.columbia.edu/LIS/archive/webright/geocities-changes.html |date = 1999-06-30 |title = Yahoo Angers GeoCities Members With Copyright Rules |publisher = nytimes.com |accessdate = 2009-06-03 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090725074140/http://emoglen.law.columbia.edu/LIS/archive/webright/geocities-changes.html |archivedate = 2009-07-25 |df = }}</ref> The terms stated that the company owned all rights and content, including media such as pictures. Yahoo! quickly reversed its decision.<ref name="NYTimes" /> In July 1999, Yahoo! switched from neighborhoods and street address [[Uniform Resource Locator|URL]]s for homesteaders to "vanity" URLs through members' sign-up names to Yahoo! (<nowiki>"www.geocities.com/membername"</nowiki>). This service was previously offered only as a premium.
In 2001, amid speculation by analysts that GeoCities was not yet profitable (it having declared an $8 million loss for the final quarter of 1998), Yahoo! introduced a for-fee premium hosting service at GeoCities<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.forbes.com/2001/08/28/0828yahoo.html |date = 2001-08-28 |title = A Community That Stays Together, Pays Together |first = Betsy |last = Schiffman |publisher = Forbes |accessdate = 2009-06-03 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090721164925/http://www.forbes.com/2001/08/28/0828yahoo.html |archivedate = 2009-07-21 |df = }}</ref> and reduced the accessibility of free and low-price hosting accounts by limiting their data transfer rate for Web page visitors; since that time the data transfer limit for free accounts was said to be limited to 3 GB per month, but was enforced as a limit of about 4.2 MB per hour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/ygcpagebuilderhelp/message/29988|title=Data Transfer|accessdate=2010-06-05}}</ref> The paid accounts were later unified in the Yahoo! Web Hosting service, with higher data transfer limits.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://geocities.yahoo.com/ps/info3/index.php |title=GeoCities PLUS and WebHosting Starter|accessdate=2010-06-05 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20051123234834/http://geocities.yahoo.com/ps/info3/index.php |archivedate = 2005-11-23}}</ref> During 2001, a rumor began that GeoCities was to close; the chain e-mail making that claim cited a ''[[The New York Times]]'' article that stated the opposite.<ref>"[http://www.snopes.com/computer/internet/geocities.asp GeoCities Closing]." ''[[Snopes]]''. April 25, 2009. Retrieved on May 3, 2009.</ref>
=== Closure === On April 23, 2009, Yahoo! announced that it would be closing its [[United States]] branch of GeoCities, and stopped accepting new registrations, though the existing GeoCities accounts remained active.<ref name="TechCrunch" /> In late June 2009, Yahoo! updated the GeoCities home page to indicate: "GeoCities is closing on October 26, 2009."<ref name="PCMagGeo" /><ref>"[http://help.yahoo.com//l/us/yahoo/geocities/close/close-03.html What if I didn't save my files and images?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809185002/http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/geocities/close/close-03.html |date=2011-08-09 }}" Yahoo! Geocities. Retrieved on August 7, 2011.</ref> GeoCities joined a long list of other services discontinued by Yahoo, such as Farechase, [[Yahoo! Music Radio|LAUNCHcast]], My Web, Audio Search, Pets, [[Yahoo! Live|Live]], Kickstart, [[Yahoo! Briefcase|Briefcase]], Webmessenger, and [[Yahoo! Teachers|Teachers]].<ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/20090427153850/http://www.calgaryherald.com/Technology/Yahoo%2Babandoning%2BGeoCities/1530841/story.html Yahoo! abandoning GeoCities]." ''[[Reuters]]'' at ''[[Calgary Herald]]''. April 24, 2009. Retrieved on August 7, 2011.</ref>
With the closure of GeoCities in the U.S., Yahoo! no longer offers free Web page hosting except in [[Japan]].<ref name="BBCPullPlug">"[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/8016211.stm Yahoo pulls the plug on GeoCities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090501013210/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/technology/8016211.stm |date=2009-05-01 }}." ''[[BBC]]''. April 24, 2009. Retrieved on May 5, 2009.</ref> Yahoo! encouraged users to upgrade their accounts to the fee-based Yahoo! Web Hosting service.<ref>{{cite web |author=Yahoo! |title=GeoCities will close later this year. |url=http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/geocities/geocities-05.html |publisher=Yahoo! Help |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gXDlsd8n?url=http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/geocities/geocities-05.html |archivedate=May 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="GeoCities_Closing">{{cite web|url = http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/geocities/close/|title = GeoCities Closing|accessdate = 2009-10-30|last = [[Yahoo!]]|authorlink = |date = October 2009|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091018205426/http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/geocities/close/|archivedate = 2009-10-18|df = }}</ref>
Rupert Goodwins, the editor of ''[[ZDNet]]'', perceived the closure of GeoCities as an end of an era; he described GeoCities as "the first proof that you could have something really popular and still not make any money on the internet."<ref name="BBCPullPlug"/> Vijay Mukhi, an internet and cyber security expert quoted in the ''[[Business Standard]]'', criticized Yahoo's handling of GeoCities; Mukhi described GeoCities as "a lost opportunity for Yahoo! They could have made it a [[Facebook]] if they wanted." [[Rich Skrenta]], the CEO of [[Blekko]], posted on [[Twitter]] an offer to take over GeoCities from Yahoo! in exchange for 50% future revenue share.<ref>D'Monte, Leslie. "[http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/yahoo-writes-geocities-obituary/356196/ Yahoo! writes GeoCities' obituary] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090722062102/http://www.business-standard.com/india/news/yahoo-writes-geocities-obituary/356196/ |date=2009-07-22 }}." ''[[Business Standard]]''. Retrieved on April 25, 2009. April 30, 2009.</ref>
In response to the closure, rival Web hosting services began to compete for the websites leaving GeoCities. For instance, [[Germany|German]] Web host [[Jimdo]] started the "Lifeboat for GeoCities" service to encourage GeoCities users to put their Web sites on Jimdo.<ref name="MarshallVNU"/><ref>"[http://www.jimdo.com/2009/04/23/jimdo-s-lifeboat-for-geocities Jimdo's Lifeboat for GeoCities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503033115/http://www.jimdo.com/2009/04/23/jimdo-s-lifeboat-for-geocities/ |date=2009-05-03 }}." ''Jimdo''. Retrieved on April 30, 2009.</ref> ''Geocities-closing.com'', started by GeoCities competitor [[uCoz]], is a similar project launched to save GeoCities websites.<ref>"[http://www.zmogo.com/web/geocities-shuts-it-doors-and-thousands-of-sites-could-be-lost/ GeoCities Shuts It Doors and Thousands of Sites Could be Lost, But There Are Other Options] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091011043156/http://www.zmogo.com/web/geocities-shuts-it-doors-and-thousands-of-sites-could-be-lost/ |date=2009-10-11 }}." Retrieved on October 8, 2009.</ref><!-- Please do not list any other Web services *unless* other reliable sources cover particular hosting services responding to GeoCities's closure -->
Many of the pages formerly hosted by GeoCities remained accessible, but could not be updated, until 2014. Attempts to access any page using the original GeoCities URL now forward to [[Yahoo! Small Business]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Geocities has shut down|url=https://smallbusiness.yahoo.com/geocities|publisher=Yahoo! Small Business|accessdate=4 July 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704005606/https://smallbusiness.yahoo.com/geocities|archivedate=4 July 2015|df=}}</ref>
== Archiving GeoCities websites == Shortly after the GeoCities closing announcement, the [[Internet Archive]] announced a project to archive GeoCities pages, stating "GeoCities has been an important outlet for personal expression on the Web for almost 15 years." Internet Archive made it their task to ensure the thoroughness and completeness of their archive of GeoCities sites.<ref name="Archive1">{{cite web |url = https://archive.org/web/geocities.php |title = Saving a Historical Record of GeoCities |accessdate = 2009-08-17 |last = [[Internet Archive]] |authorlink = |year = 2009}}</ref> The website InternetArchaeology.org also archived and is showcasing artifacts from GeoCities.<ref name="InternetArchaeology.org">{{cite web |url = http://www.crunchgear.com/2009/10/10/internet-archaeology-in-which-the-sordid-past-of-the-internet-is-preserved-forever/ |title = Internet Archeology: In which the internet's sordid past is preserved and curated |accessdate = 2009-10-20 |last = Tech Crunch |authorlink = |year = 2009 |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091013092417/http://www.crunchgear.com/2009/10/10/internet-archaeology-in-which-the-sordid-past-of-the-internet-is-preserved-forever/ |archivedate = 2009-10-13 |df = }}</ref> The operators of the website Reocities downloaded as much of the content hosted on GeoCities as they could before it shut down, in an attempt to create a mirror of GeoCities, albeit an incomplete one.<ref>"[http://reocities.com/ Welcome to ReoCities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091029040412/http://www.reocities.com/ |date=2009-10-29 }}." ''Reocities''. 2009. Retrieved on October 27, 2009.</ref>
Another site which is attempting to build an archive of defunct GeoCities websites is GeoCities.ws.<ref>[http://geocities.ws GeoCities.ws] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091030064548/http://www.geocities.ws/ |date=2009-10-30 }}. Retrieved 12 December 2009.</ref> There is no formal relationship between GeoCities and geocities.ws, as it is a completely different company. Many sites were automatically duplicated from GeoCities to geocities.ws many months after the closure of GeoCities. Geocities.ws also promised free hosting, and for 8 years this has been the case, {{as of|2018|01|lc=y}}. Other sites with this purpose are Geociti.es<ref>{{cite web| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101221131741/http://geociti.es/| title=Geocities is Dead; An Archive Team Exhibit| url=http://geociti.es/| publisher=Geociti.es| accessdate=2013-01-09| archivedate=2010-12-21}}</ref>(closed 2011), [[WebCite]], and [http://www.Oocities.org Oocities.org].
On the first anniversary of GeoCities' closing, [[Archive Team]] announced that they would release a [[torrent file]] archive of 641 GB (prior to [[7z]] compression, it was approximately 900 GB of data),<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ascii.textfiles.com/archives/2720|title=Archiveteam! The Geocities Torrent|last=Scott|first=Jason|date=2010-10-27|work=ASCII by Jason Scott|access-date=2018-01-16|language=en-US|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180308092306/http://ascii.textfiles.com/archives/2720|archivedate=2018-03-08|df=}}</ref> and did so on October 29, 2010.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20101029/03055711647/archive-of-geocities-released-as-a-1tb-torrent.shtml|title=Archive Of Geocities Released As A 1TB Torrent|last=Masnick|first=Mike|work=Techdirt|date=2010-10-29|publisher=Floor64|access-date=2018-01-16|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116081516/https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20101029/03055711647/archive-of-geocities-released-as-a-1tb-torrent.shtml|archivedate=2018-01-16|df=}}</ref> On April 9, 2011, Archive Team released a patch for the first GeoCities torrent.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.archiveteam.org/archives/geocitiespatch/ |title=GeoCities Patch |publisher=Archiveteam.org |date= |accessdate=2012-02-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110410095858/http://www.archiveteam.org/archives/geocitiespatch/ |archivedate=2011-04-10 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.archiveteam.org/index.php?title=GeoCities_Torrent_Patch&diff=3543&oldid=3541|title=Difference between revisions of "GeoCities Torrent Patch" - Archiveteam|website=www.archiveteam.org|date=2011-04-09|language=en|access-date=2018-01-16|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116002445/https://www.archiveteam.org/index.php?title=GeoCities_Torrent_Patch&diff=3543&oldid=3541|archivedate=2018-01-16|df=}}</ref>
== Selected traffic statistics == The domain ''geocities.com'' attracted at least 177 million visitors annually by 2008 according to a [[Compete.com]] study.<ref>{{cite web |author=United States |url=http://siteanalytics.compete.com/geocities.com?metric=uv |title=GeoCities attracts almost 180m visitors online yearly |publisher=Siteanalytics.compete.com |date= |accessdate=2012-02-20 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111220113602/http://siteanalytics.compete.com/geocities.com/?metric=uv |archivedate=2011-12-20 |df= }}</ref>
ComScore stated that the GeoCities had 18.9 million unique visitors from the U.S. in March 2006. In March 2008 GeoCities had 15.1 million unique U.S. visitors. In March 2009 GeoCities had 11.5 million unique visitors, a 24% decline from March 2008.<ref name="TechCrunch"/>
== Litigation == In 1999, a complaint was instituted against GeoCities stating that the corporation violated the provisions of the [[Federal Trade Commission Act]] under {{UnitedStatesCode|15|45}}, which states in relevant part, "Unfair methods of competition in or affecting commerce, and unfair or deceptive acts or practices in or affecting commerce, are hereby declared unlawful." The FTC found that GeoCities was engaged in deceptive acts and practices in contravention to their stated privacy act. Subsequently, a consent order was entered into which prohibits GeoCities from misrepresenting the purpose for which it collects and/or uses personal identifying information from consumers. A copy of the complaint and order can be found at [https://web.archive.org/web/20090511204518/http://www.ftc.gov/os/decisions/docs/Volume127.pdf#page=94 127 F.T.C. 94] (page 94).<ref name=ftc127>[http://www.ftc.gov/os/decisions/docs/Volume127.pdf#page=94 FTC.gov] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511204518/http://www.ftc.gov/os/decisions/docs/Volume127.pdf |date=2009-05-11 }}</ref>
The litigation came about in this way: GeoCities provided free home pages and e-mail address to children and adults who provided personally identifying and demographic information when they registered for the Web site. At the time of the complaint, GeoCities had more than 1.8 million members who were "homesteaders." GeoCities illegally permitted third-party advertisers to promote products targeted to GeoCities' 1.8 million users, by using [[personally identifiable information]] obtained in the registration process. These acts and practices affected "commerce" as defined in Section 4 of the Federal Trade Commission.<ref name=ftc127/>
The problem GeoCities faced was that it placed a privacy statement on its New Member Application Form and on its Web site promising that it would never give personally identifying information to anyone without the user's permission. GeoCities sold personal information to third parties who used the information for purposes other than those for which members gave permission.<ref name=ftc127/>
It was ordered that GeoCities would not make any misrepresentation, in any manner about its collection or use of personal identifying information, including what information will be disclosed to third parties. GeoCities was not allowed to collect personal identifying information from any child if GeoCities had actual knowledge that the child did not have his parents' permission to provide the information.<ref name=ftc127/>

{{update|reason=missing after 2015|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox Film Festival | name = Yubari International Fantastic Film Festival | image = | caption = | number = | location = [[Yūbari, Hokkaidō]] | language = International | website = http://yubarifanta.com/index_pc.php?ct=main.php&langue=21002 }}
The {{nihongo|'''Yubari International Fantastic Film Festival'''|ゆうばり国際ファンタスティック映画祭|Yūbari kokusai fantasutikku eiga sai}}, also sometimes called YIFFF, is held in a resort-like environment in the small town of [[Yūbari, Hokkaidō|Yūbari]] on the northernmost Japanese island of [[Hokkaidō]]. From 1990 to 1999, the festival was known as the Yubari International Fantastic Adventure Film Festival.<ref name="info">{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223234307/http://yubarifanta.com/index_pc.php?ct=information.php&langue=21002|archivedate=2012-02-23|url=http://yubarifanta.com/index_pc.php?ct=information.php&langue=21002|title=Yubari International Fantastic Film Festival Information|publisher=[yubarifanta.com]|accessdate=2009-09-17}}</ref>
==History== In 1990, the last coal mine in the Hokkaidō mining town of Yūbari having closed, the city leaders were looking for a way to revitalize the local economy. This was the beginning of the Yubari International Fantastic Film Festival.<ref name="webjapan">{{cite web|url=http://web-japan.org/trends/arts/art050113.html|title=ACTING LOCAL|publisher=[web-japan.org]|date=January 13, 2005|accessdate=2009-09-18}}</ref> The festival was divided into two main programs, a prestigious international competition for young directors, and an Off Theatre program for mostly Japanese amateur, independent and first-time directors. The first year in 1990 had as a special guest, actor [[Jon Voight]] and his daughter, a young starlet named [[Angelina Jolie]]. In 1993, [[Quentin Tarantino]] was at the festival and wrote part of the screenplay for ''[[Pulp Fiction (film)|Pulp Fiction]]'' in his hotel room. Some years later, he paid homage to the town in the name of a character in ''[[Kill Bill: Volume 1]]'', [[List of Kill Bill characters#Gogo Yubari|"Gogo Yubari"]].<ref name="midnight">{{cite web|url=http://www.midnighteye.com/features/go-go-yubari.shtml|title=Go! Go! Yubari|publisher=[Midnight Eye]|last=Mes|first=Tom|date=June 17, 2008|accessdate=2009-09-17}}</ref> In 1996 the festival also had special guest stars, comedians [[Steve Martin]] and [[Martin Short]]. In 2004 the festival drew a record audience of 27,000.<ref name="webjapan"/>
The festival had always been sponsored financially by the city of Yubari but the town filed for bankruptcy in 2007 and that year's festival had to be cancelled. However, the people of Yubari with the assistance of a number of sponsors were able to group together to revive the festival in 2008. The international competition section of the festival had to be dropped but the Off Theatre program for young Japanese directors was retained with the Grand Prize bringing 2 million yen (about $20,000) to the winner. The new Governor's Award was presented by the Governor of Hokkaidō. In addition to the competition section, the festival continued to screen a number of international films by promising directors.<ref name="midnight"/> One of the sponsors for the festival is the giant Japanese satellite broadcasting company [[SKY Perfect|SKYPerfecTV!]] which has also broadcast parts of the program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sptvjsat.com/en/news/news_pdf/090114_Special_Sponsorship_of_Yubari.pdf|title=SKY Perfect JSAT Corporation News Release|publisher= www.sptvjsat.com/|accessdate=2009-09-18|date=January 14, 2009}}</ref> The scaled down 2008 festival drew more than 8800 fans and attendance increased to over 10,500 in 2009.<ref name="unijapan">{{cite web|url=http://unijapan.org/en/festival/japan/yubari-fanta.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120312043700/http://unijapan.org/en/festival/japan/yubari-fanta.html|title=Yubari International Fantastic Film Festival|archivedate=2012-03-12|accessdate=2015-11-09|publisher=[UniJapan]}}</ref>
==Major awards== Award information from:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yubarifanta.com/index_pc.php?ct=archive.php&langue=21002|title=Yubari International Fantastic Film Festival Archive|publisher=[yubarifanta.com]|accessdate=2009-09-17}}</ref>
